Graphical abstractThree new MOFs comprising one mixed-donor ligand (5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid, H3TZI) are synthesized and structurally characterized. JUC-165 features 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels and it performs (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 shows a 2D rarely sandwich-like tri-layer, and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. The fluorescence properties of these three new MOFs were measured at room temperature.

AbstractThree new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn2(TZI)(μ
3-OH)(H2O)2]·(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ
3-OH)(H2O)7]·4H2O (JUC-166), and [Cd(TZI)]·(CH3)2NH2·H2O (JUC-167) (JUC=Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn2+/Cd2+ ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI). JUC-165 exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2 and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and JUC-167 exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm, respectively.

Results and discussionDescription of the crystal structure of JUC-165
Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-165 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmcm. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn2+ cations, 0.25 TZI3− ligand, 0.25 μ
3-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH3)2NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI3− ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as μ
6-η1: η0: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 (
a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3− and one bridging oxygen atom from a μ
3-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI3− ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN2O3 coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two μ
3-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI3− ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] SBU are formed by μ
3-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI3− spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by m-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5×3.0Å2) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the c axis (c). A better insight into the nature of JUC-165 can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H2O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI3− ligand coordinated to five [Zn3(μ
3-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of JUC-165 is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4664 (d).

Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H3TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn2(TZI)(μ
3-OH)(H2O)2]·(CH3)2NH (JUC-165), [Cd5(TZI)3(μ
3-OH)(H2O)7]·4H2O (JUC-166) as well as [Cd(TZI)]·(CH3)2NH2·H2O (JUC-167) were constructed. It’s notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H3TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. JUC-165 featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5×3.0Å2, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4664, JUC-166 performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, JUC-167 exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 42638. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415nm of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167, respectively.

Description of the crystal structure of JUC-166
Single crystal X-ray diffraction of JUC-166 reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group P212121. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd2+ cations, three TZI3−anion, one μ
3-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI3− ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as μ5
-η1: η0: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1 η0 (type (I)), μ5
-η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η1: η0 (type (II)), and μ
7-η0: η1: η2: η2: η1: η1: η0: η1 (type (III)), respectively (
a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd2+ sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen μ
3-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI3− ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one μ
3-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI3− ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI3− ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI3− ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one μ
3-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI3− ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI3−, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3− ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI3−, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI3− ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd–O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)Å, and the Cd–N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as μ
3-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W–H⋯O1, O6W–H⋯O3 and O7W–H···O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).

Flexible effects of the ligands on the frameworksThe H3TZI can be regarded as a partially flexible ligand, where the carboxylate group and the tetrazole/phenl ring can twist and bend freely. In theory, for H3TZI, there are two ultimate conformations (), the planar conformation (mode-a) and the non-planar conformation (mode-b) with the maximum torsion angle achieves to 90.0° of the two parts belong to the ligand. From the structure descriptions above, it exhibits mode-a conformation with the maximum torsion angle of 90.0° in JUC-165. However, two conformations are found in JUC-166, one is the approximative mode-a conformation with torsion angle of just 2.2°, and the other is mode-b conformation with torsion angle of 58.8°and 45.5°. And it is notable that the carboxyl gropes of the three types of linkers twist different angles around the benzene ring in this structure, and even the C–C bond which connect benzene and tetrazolyl rings bent 9.8° and 10.9° respect to the m-benzenedicarboxylate plane in type (I) as well as type (II) linkers, respectively (). Thus, H3TZI performs remarkable flexibility in the framework. In JUC-167, the dihedral between the m-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (mode-b). Obviously, the outstanding flexible effects of H3TZI meet the complex of the various frameworks.

Thermal analysis and PXRD resultsThermal stabilities of three new MOFs materials have been measured (). For JUC-165, it is found that there was a weight loss of 8.94% before 110°C, which corresponds to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH2 molecules (calculated: 9.23%), and the temperature range of 100–280°C can be attributed to the removal of the coordinated waters (experimental: 9.31%; calculated: 7.83%), and then the structure decomposed gradually. The residue was 34.73 % corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calculated: 35.38%). For JUC-166, the weight loss of 12.91% corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 252°C (calculated: 13.56%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 45.08%; calculated: 43.93%). For JUC-167, the weight loss of 9.41% corresponding to the departure of guest (CH3)2NH molecules is observed from 50 to 152°C (calculated: 11.07%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 33.24%; calculated: 31.58%). The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in . The peak positions of the measured PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the simulated patterns.

Luminescence propertiesLuminescent properties of MOFs containing d10 metal centers have attracted intense interest due to their potential applications, such as in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent display, and so on . In this work, the solid-state photoluminescent spectra of H3TZI ligand, JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 have been carried out at room temperature (
). The main emission peak of H3TZI is at 377nm (λex

=326nm), which can be attributed to the π∗
→π or π∗
→n transitions. On complexation of the ligands with Zn2+ or Cd2+ atom, the emission peaks occur at 410nm (λ
ex
=372nm) for JUC-165, 437nm (λ
ex
=337nm) for JUC-166, and 415nm (λ
ex
=320nm) for JUC-167. The Cd2+ ions and Zn2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d10 configuration . So the emissions of these compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. However, for the three complexes, the main emission peak is highly red-shifted by 33, 60 and 38nm, respectively, relative to the free H3TZI ligand. It is known that the replacement of the hydrogen proton by Zn2+ or Cd2+ ions decreases the π∗
→π or π∗
→n gap of the carboxylate ligands, resulting in a red shift of the emission peaks . So the emission can be assigned to the chelation of the ligands to the central metals.

ConclusionsIn conclusion, we have described three MOFs with the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid ligand (H3TZI). JUC-165 and JUC-167 show different 3D frameworks: in JUC-165, infinite strip-shaped chains in which Zn3(μ
3-OH) triangles are interlinked by TZI3− ligands into a 3D structure with the point symbol 4664 topology; in JUC-167, the unique Cd2+ ions are linked by TZI3− ligands with the point symbol 42638 topology. And JUC-166 performs a 3D supermolecular structure by strong H-bonds containing rarely 2D sandwich-like tri-layer. Meanwhile, we discussed the interesting flexibility features of this rigid ligand in details, the mixed-donor ligand exhibits wonderful characteristics coordinated with mental centers. Moreover, the luminescence of JUC-165, JUC-166 and JUC-167 indicated that these MOFs materials may be good candidates for functional materials.

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on 10.7778 mg of a polycrystalline sample of compound 3 from ambient temperature to 1100°C. The TGA data show that three obvious weight loss stages: (1) 100–164°C, weight loss 11.3% possibly corresponding to removing two moles of coordinating water molecules per formula unit (Calc. 11.4%). (2) 200–536°C, weight loss 21.7%. (3) 679–1000°C, weight loss 27.0%.

The structure of 5 has been established previously by X-ray powder diffraction . Herein, we confirm the structure by X-ray single crystal data (
). The measured CuO bond lengths are 1.942(6), 2.044(5) and 2.412(10) Å based on X-ray single crystal data, while they are 1.962(3), 2.048(3) and 2.293(10) or 2.635(8) Å based on X-ray powder data . In addition, the coordinated water molecules is disorder based on X-ray powder data, while it is not disorder based on X-ray single crystal data.

Using the pip in place of the 4,4′-bpy, the title 3-D compound 1 with a different topology from the former was synthesized. With the pip, NiCl2
·6H2O forms a 1-D chained SU. The Ni(II) center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by four Cl− ions and two N atoms from the different pip. The Ni–N bond length [2.118(2)Å] and the average Ni-Cl bond length [2.475Å] are similar to those found in reported [NiCl2(4,4′-bpy)] . Through the μ2-Cl bridges, all of the Ni(II) centers are linked into a zigzag chain, which can be described as an infinite extension of edge-shared NiCl4N2 octahedra. The Ni(pip)2+ unit adopts a cis-type arrangement. It is noticeable that compound 1 displays the different porous shapes in different directions. As shown in 
, in [100] direction, it takes on a trigonal channel with base 6.3Å and height 6.6Å. While in [001] direction, it displays a square hydrophobic channel with the size of 7.9×7.9Å2.

Magnetic propertyMagnetic susceptibility data were determined on the basis of a 10.3mg sample over the temperature of 2–300K at a magnetic field of 1 kG on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. The μeff versus T plot is shown in 
 (left) [μeff
=2.83 (χ
M
T)1/2]. The experimental μeff value at 300 K is 3.11μB, comparable with the theoretically expected value of 2.83μB for a d8 Ni(II) ion with an octahedral geometry. Upon cooling down, μeff increases continuously up to a maximum of 4.8μB at 14K, then drops rapidly down to a value of 1.4μB at 2 K. The 1/χ
M versus T curve is close to be linear when T
>150K [see  (right)], being well fitted by using the Curie Weiss law with C
=1.014emuKmol−1, and θ
=53.97K. On the other hand, zero-field splitting is known to occur for Ni(II) ions, and for isolated ions may induce either an increase or a decrease of μeff value at rather low temperature due to the site distortion of metal ion. Based on both stated above, the observed behavior is thus characteristic of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions within the NiCl2 chains due to a plus θ value, whereas the drop below 14K can be related to antiferromagnetic coupling between the chains as well as the effect of zero-field splitting. A 1-D chain model was used to fit the magnetic data of compound 1, unluckily no ideal result was obtained .

The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320°C.Compound 1, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in 
 (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with λ
<300nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If 1 is excited by wavelengths longer than 300nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for 1, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce4+ ions; Ce3+ ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138cm−1) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480cm−1) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).

One such ligand, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-dioxyquinoxalinedione (H2L′), and its diolate dianion, 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate (L2−), are depicted in 
; for simplicity the two ligands are shown in the tautomeric forms established by crystallography. Our primary goal in this project is to see how much synthetic chemistry can be accomplished by employing the neutral and anionic forms of this and related ligands (e.g. 2,3-dioxypyrazinate(−2) and 4,6-dioxypyrimidinate(−2)) as linkers for the construction of coordination polymers. A secondary goal is to test the antitumour activity and DNA properties of the monomeric (if any) metal complexes with the quinoxaline-based ligands H2L′ and L2−, since such complexes have a tradition in exhibiting such properties . In the preliminary work reported here, we have sought the answers to two main questions: (i) Can copper(II) coordination polymers be made containing the ligands shown in  (or tautomers thereof)? (ii) How effective will these linkers be in mediating magnetic exchange interactions between CuII ions?

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of JUC-188 was measured at room temperature. The characteristic peaks of the as-synthesized sample are closely matched well with those in the simulated patterns from the single crystal structure (a). The results confirmed the phase purity of the as-synthesized bulk crystalline materials. From the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) results, the as-synthesized JUC-188 showed a gradual weight loss before 200°C about 19.78%, corresponding to the loss of one [H2N(CH3)2] cation, two coordinated water and four DMF guest molecules (calculated 19.44%) (b). The main framework of JUC-188 began to collapse with the increasing of heating temperature. The as-synthesized samples were exchanged with MeOH about three days, and activated at room temperature to obtain the activated samples. However, the activated samples didn't have any N2 adsorption, which was mainly ascribed to the collapse of the skeletal structure after removing the solvent molecules (Fig. S2). In addition, the PXRD pattern further indicated that the main framework of the activated samples was collapsed (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the characteristic peaks of adenine and H4L ligands were both found in the FT-IR spectrum of JUC-188, which undoubtedly exhibited that both organic ligands coexisted in JUC-188.

Preparation of [H2N(CH3)2]⋅[Zn4(L)1.5(ad)3(H2O)2]⋅4DMF: A mixture of Zn(NO3)2
⋅6H2O (30mg, 0.1mmol), H4L (15mg, 0.025mmol), adenine (8mg, 0.06mmol) was added in a mixture solution of DMF (4mL) and H2O (0.5mL). Then 0.1mL HNO3 was added in the mixture. The obtain mixture was sealed into a 20mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 135°C for three days. The as-synthesized samples can be obtained after filtration at room temperature. Finally, the yellow block-shaped crystals were washed with fresh DMF and dried in air. Yield: 52.9% (based on the H4L). Graphical abstractUsing the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H2oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·xH2O (Ln=Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered structure with [CaLn(oda)3]− as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H2O)6]2+ ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.

Synthesis of [{Ca(H2O)6}{CaLn(oda)3}2]·4H2O(Ln=Dy (7), Tm (8), Lu (9). The mixture of Ln2O3 (0.10mmol) CaCl2·2H2O (44mg, 0.30mmol) and 2,2-oxydiacetic acid (80mg, 0.60mmol) in 15mL of water was placed in a Teflon-lined 45mL stainless steel acid digestion vessel and heated at 120°C for 2days. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30–50%. Anal. Calc. for C24H44O40Ca3Ln2: C, 20.3; H, 3.1 (7); C, 20.1; H, 3.1 (8), C, 20.0; H, 3.1 (9). Found: C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (7); C, 20.3; H, 2.9 (8), C, 20.1; H, 2.9 (9)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200°C, corresponding to all water molecules. Anal. Calc.: 12.7 (7); 12.6 (8), 12.5 (9). Found: 13.3 (7); 12.4 (8), 11.7 (9)%. Decomposition point, ca. 250°C.

Europium(III) ion is nine-coordinated, being surrounded by O atoms from three independent oda ligands. [Eu(oda)3]3− building blocks are clearly distinguished in the structure (
). The Eu–O distances (2.406(4)Å for the alkoxo group and 2.469(5)Å for the carboxylate groups) are similar to those found in the simple salts of the complex [Eu(oda)3]3− (2.395(2) and 2.495(2)Å, respectively) . The angles subtended by the coordinated oda oxygens at the europium atom in 2 are 63.96(9)° and 73.03(10)°, again very close to those observed in the salts of [Eu(oda)3]3− (63.4(1)° and 74.3(1)°). Therefore, the formation of the 3D structure does not represent a further strain in the atomic disposition of the building block.

Structure of [Co(HPMB)](BF4)2·8MeOH·3.5H2O (3)On complexing HPMB to cobalt(II), a metal ion that generally favours a higher coordination number than does copper(II), the hexadentate ligand utilises all six of its possible oxygen donor atoms in the formation of a contiguous 3D-network. The HPMB ligand is hexanucleating and has crystallographic S
6 symmetry (
(a)), a conformation distinctly different from that seen in 1 and 2. The N⋯O vectors of the pyridone rings are inclined by approximately 58° to the central phenyl ring plane. The geometry at cobalt is also S
6 symmetric ((b)), the cis angles being 88.2(2) and 91.8(2)°; the CoO distances are all 2.075(4) Å. Relative to two of the opposite faces of the CoO6 octahedron, the triads of pyridone rings form a shallow, dish-like arrangement, with the aryl ring planes inclined by only 24° to the plane of the facial oxygen atoms.

AbstractThe furan-2,5-dicarboxyl acid (FDA) is firstly utilized to the construction of MOFs, and the pillars are enlisted in the structural formation by the method of ligand-to-ligand. The pillar properties play an important role in final structure. The flexible bpp (1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane) results in the robust porous [Zn3·(FDA)3·bpp·H2O]·2H2O (1) with high thermal stability (~270°C) and medium CO2 uptake (1.65mmol/g, 273K), and the rigid bipy (4,4′-bipyridine) in 3-/3-D interpenetrated [Zn·(FDA)·bipy]·2H2O (2).

The gas-storage of MOF is of very interest. In this work, the experiments of gas adsorptions (degassed at 200°C) indicate that 1 can adsorb CO2 instead of N2, which is attributed to the strong quadrupole interaction of CO2. The CO2 gas-sorption isotherms for compound 1 at 273K indicate that the BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated to be 234.1 and 262.4m2/g, and the median pore diameter calculated by H-K method is 4.6Å. Compound 1 indicates the medium CO2 uptake about 1.65mmol/g (Fig. S10).

Two new MOFs — porous robust 1 and 3-/3-D interpenetrated 2 — have been synthesized and structurally determined. The structural difference is owing to the properties of ligand-to-ligand pillars (flexible bpp for 1 and rigid bipy for 2). As a result, 1 possesses the permanent and stable pore which is able to uptake CO2, and 2 forms the 3-/3-D interpenetrated net.

AbstractA novel cobalt(II) complex [Co3(oba)3(phen)2]n(H2oba=4,4′-oxybis benzoic acid, phen=1,10-phenanthroline) has been synthesized by hydrothermal method and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, UV–vis, thermal stability and Surface Photovoltage Spectroscopy (SPS). Structural analysis indicated that the complex is a 3D structure with the trinuclear building unit of [Co3(oba)3(phen)2] bridged by the oba ligands. The SPS of complex indicates that there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600nm showing photo-electric conversion properties. There are good relationships between SPS and UV–vis spectra.

Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology, as a very sensitive characterization tool, has been used to detect the charge transitions of the functional semiconductor . Here we report the synthesis , crystal structure , thermal stability and surface photo-electric property of a novel three-dimensional Co(II) complex {[Co3(oba)3(phen)2]n. It is worthy to note that we used SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra to study the surface electron behaviors under light-induced, and there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600nm showing photo-electric conversion properties.

AbstractTwo new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)2/3(bpta)1/4(H2O)2(OH)]⋅solve (1) and [Cd(tpt)(H2bpta)]⋅solve (2) (tpt=2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H4bpta=(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The results show that complex 1 has a 3D bor network structure with 56.9% solvent-accessible volume, and 2 reveals a novol 3,5-coordinated chiral topology with vertex symbol (4.72)(43.62.74.8) and 52.5% accessible void in the structure. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated 1 and 2 were investigated.

Among the multidentate pyridine ligands investigated in this field, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of specially interest in recent years. Its rigidity and triangular geometry can lead to MOFs bearing various structures and interesting topologies when employed in the reactions with metal ions  and the resulted compounds also show attractive properties such as host-guest functions, magnetic and drug delivery . However, in despite of the high solvent-accessible volume of the resulting frameworks or cages, none of the tpt constructed porous frameworks have been studied with their gas adsorption properties to the best of our knowledge. As the combination of tpt and carboxylic acid ligand resulted in MOFs with novel structures and interesting properties , our goal is to design and synthesize porous MOFs with tpt and various carboxylic acid ligands. Herein, we report two novel microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II) and tpt associated with (1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H4bpta) (
). The resulted MOFs were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. Also, the resulted MOFs reveal high solvent-accessible volume and novel topologies. Furthermore, their gas adsorption properties were investigated.

Results and discussionDescription of the crystal structure of 1
The result of X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex 1 crystallizes in high symmetry of cubic form with space group of Pn-3 and the asymmetric unit has a one-sixth Co(II) atom sitting on a special position with a one-sixth occupancy, half of the deprotonated L− ligand, solvent water molecules and methanol molecules. Every Co(II) center in the framework is octahedral coordinated. Considering the balance of the charge, the anionic charge of framework is balanced by a proton H+, which could not be located by X-ray diffraction, but are probably bound to the nucleophilic N atoms of imidazole rings, or one of the solvent water molecules was protonated. As shown in 
a, each Co(II) atom is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L− ligands with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Co–N distance of 2.141(4)Å and N–Co–N bond angles of 91.77(1)°, 88.23(1)° and 180° are typical for the octahedral Co–Nim coordinations . On the other hand, each L− ligand acts as a linear ligand to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co separation of 13.66Å. It is noteworthy that only one of the two nitrogen atoms of the deprotonated imidazol-4-yl group coordinates with the Co(II) atom.

AbstractReported herein are two porous interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the length of organic linker. Shorter BDC linker and [Cd(COO)4] building blocks in 1 generate a rare 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network. But longer NDC linker in 2 produces a self-penetrated 8-connected bcu framework with [Cd3(COO)8] SBUs. 1 and 2 both show selective CO2 adsorption and significantly, 2 exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281cm3·g−1 at 298K and P/P0
=0.95) among all the interpenetrated MOFs.

More recently, we report a 3-fold self-interpenetrated Zn-carboxylate MOF, which presents an unprecedented 1D channel partition via interpenetration into polyhedral cages . The unique structural feature contributed to not only the highest CO2 uptake capacity but also strongest CO2 affinity among the interpenetrated MOFs. As an extension of this work, we demonstrated herein two interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks effectively tuned by the length of organic linkers, namely, {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Cd(BDC)2]}
n
 (1) and {[(CH3)2NH2]2[Cd3(NDC)4]}
n
 (2) (BDC=terephthalic acid, NDC=2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid). As we expected, interpenetrated MOFs 1 and 2 both have small pore sizes, and show selective CO2 adsorption. Significantly, MOF 2 exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281cm3·g−1) at 298K and P/P
0
=0.95 among the interpenetrated MOFs.

Notably, as mentioned above, penetrated Cd-carboxylate frameworks 1 and 2 both possess 1D channel along c-direction. PLATON calculations show that they have 61.8% and 48.6%, respectively, potential guest-accessible volumes. These prominent structure features provoke us to study their porosity. However, the N2 sorption isotherms at 77K indicate negligible uptakes for the MOFs 1 and 2 activated at 80°C, which is probably due to their small pore sizes introduced by the interpenetration and also blocked by the charge-balanced cations. It should be pointed out similar N2 uptake results had also been found in an iso-structure of MOF 2 obtained in DMF solvent . Furthermore, the porosity of these two MOFs was supported by the CO2 adsorption at 195K (Fig. S3a). The corresponding BET surface area is 372m2
g−1 and 154m2
g−1 for 1 and 2, respectively. It should be noted that compound 1 exhibits a pressure-dependent, stepwise CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 195K, which further support the dynamic twofold interpenetrating frameworks.

The low-pressure CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 273K and 298K. Under 1bar, the CO2 uptakes at 273K reach 42cm3·g−1 (1.9mmol·g−1, 8.3wt.%) for MOF 1, and 24cm3·g−1 (1.1mmol·g−1, 4.7wt.%) for MOF 2 (a). At 298K and 1bar, MOFs 1 and 2 can absorb CO2 of 25cm3·g−1 (1.1mmol·g−1, 4.9wt.%) and 13cm3·g−1 (0.6mmol·g−1, 2.6wt.%). Although such CO2 adsorption capacity is not high, these values still outperform many previously reported interpenetrated MOFs such as SNU-71 , YO-MOF  and so on. Compared to the no-interpenetrated MOFs, the CO2 adsorption capacity of 1 is also higher than a lot of famous MOFs such as ZIF-8 , MOF-2 , SNU-31 , and ZIF-100  at 298K and 1atm. Clearly, take the negligible N2 adsorption into account, interpenetrated porous MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit dramatically selective CO2 uptake performance, which may be due to the small pore size introduced by interpenetration and the charged frameworks of 1 and 2.

The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF 2. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound 2 is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298K reaches 281cm3·g−1 under P/P
0
=0.95 (where P
0 is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF 2 is comparable to the values of Basolite A100  and another cadmium(II) MOF  reported by D. F. Li, which are 250cm3·g−1 and 249cm3·g−1, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO2, −NH2, −CH3 and –OCH3 groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF 2 at 298K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.

Results and discussionUsing monoalkyl substituted azoles 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), 2-ethylimidazole (Heim), 3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz), and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) as starting materials, six binary MAFs, namely SOD-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-4), ANA-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-5), SOD-[Zn(mtz)2] (MAF-7), dia-[Zn(mim)2] (MAF-31), qtz-[Zn(eim)2] (MAF-32), and dia-[Zn(etz)2] (MAF-33) were obtained. Single-crystal structures of as-synthesized MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were first described in our previous communications . The N2, H2, CO2, C2H2, and H2O sorption behaviors of isostructural MAF-4 and MAF-7 were also discussed, but the sorption property of MAF-5 has not been observed. Crystal structures of MAF-31  and MAF-32  were reported by other groups very recently, while MAF-33 has not been reported. To better understand the relationship among synthesis, structure, and property, single-crystal structures of guest-free MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were measured and compared with the nonporous compounds.

Thermal and chemical stabilityAs shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400°C) .

Sorption propertyGas sorption isotherms (H2 and N2 at 77K, CO2 at 273 and 298K) were measured for the porous MAFs. The gas sorption data of the SOD frameworks are basically identical to our previous reports measured on the samples synthesized from soluble Zn(II) salts . According to their crystal structures, MAF-4 and MAF-7 show very similar and high porosity, while MAF-7 possesses much higher adsorption affinity for gas molecules. The porosity of ANA framework MAF-5 is lower than the SOD frameworks (), but still larger than most zeolites such as ZSM-5. The gas sorption affinity of MAF-5 is in between MAF-4 and MAF-7 (), because MAF-5 has smaller channel size and contains no pore surface active site.

Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H2O. As illustrated in 
, all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at P/P
0
=0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host–guest interactions are weaker than the guest–guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.

The adsorption of larger molecules for MAF-4, -5, and -7 were semi-quantitatively monitored by TG analyses (). The activated samples of MAF-4, -5 and -7 were exposed in the saturated vapors of toluene (3.3×7.3×7.3Å3) and p-xylene (3.8×6.3×9.1Å3) for 4days before TG measurements. Adsorption on the outer surface is excluded by the observed significant weight losses. The large adsorption of organic molecules for MAF-5 demonstrates its ability as a hydrophobic adsorbate with high organic/water selectivity. As the molecular sizes of toluene and p-xylene are significantly larger than the aperture sizes of the SOD MAFs, structural transformation must occur . PXRD patterns of the solvent-loaded frameworks are reminiscent with the original host frameworks (), implying that the transformations occur during non-equilibrium states, i.e. the small windows only open temporarily to allow guest diffusion .

The obtained porous MAFs show higher chemical stability compared with other preparation methods, which is tentatively assigned to the impact of different impurity. Sample activation is also easier because no high-boiling point solvent is employed. Sorption behaviors of the porous MAFs can be explained by their pore size and surface properties. Due to the complete coordination of nitrogen donors and alkyl-lined pore surface, the imidazolate frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-5 are rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high pore volumes, which can easily adsorb large amount of organic solvent but do not adsorb water even at very high humidity. As the pore size is similar to small aromatic derivatives such as benzene and toluene, MAF-5 is suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water. On the other hand, the large pore MAF-4 exhibits lower adsorption affinity for organic solvents, and significant adsorption arise from capillary condensation. While MAF-7 is isostructural with MAF-4, incorporation of uncoordinated nitrogen donor on the pore surface increases the sorption affinity and lowers the onset pressure of capillary condensation. Finally, the SOD frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-7 can readily adsorb guest molecules obviously larger than their aperture sizes via temporary distortion of their frameworks.

Crystal structure of {[Co2(Hdatrz)(NH2-ip)2]·0.5H2O}n (1)Complex 1 presents a wave-like two-dimensional (2D) layer with dimeric {Co2(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}4+ subunits extended by three-branched NH2-ip2− ligands. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two CoII octahedra, one neutral Hdatrz molecule, two doubly deprotonated NH2-ip2− anions in the same binding mode and half a free water molecule. As shown in 
a, both unique CoII ions are in the distorted N2O4 donor sets defined by one triazolyl group of Hdatrz ligand, one amino group from a NH2-ip2− anion, one bidentate chelating and two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups from three separate NH2-ip2− anions. The Co–O and Co–N separations are between 2.0404(19) and 2.2704(17)Å (), which are comparable with those cobalt(II)-based complexes with triazolyl and carboxylate ligands .

PXRD and thermal stability of 1–4
Experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns of the four bulk products were in good agreement with each other (), indicating their phase purity and the structural consistency as the synthesized samples. TG experiments of 1–4 were carried out in order to explore their thermal stability (). As a result, complex 1 displayed a slight weight-loss process between 60 and 145°C for the release of the lattice water molecule, and was followed by a rapid weight-loss stage between 376 and 550°C for the decomposition of the layered structure. The remaining residue of 1 was calculated to be CoO above 550°C (expt. 25.5%, calc. 25.7%). Complex 2 exhibited one continuous weight-loss process above 100°C, corresponding to the continuous removal of methanol and the combustion of the mixed ligands. The final product of 2 above 445°C was calculated to be CoO (expt. 21.6%, calc. 20.4%). Complex 3 showed a two-step weight-loss stage between 60 and 180°C for the slow release of disordered lattice molecules (expt. 8.3%, calc. 8.4%). Once the temperature was higher than 427°C, the polymeric backbone collapse of 3 occurred, which was completely finished at the highest temperature measured. Complex 4 was thermally stable up to 241°C, and was accompanied by a continuous weight-loss process between 241°C and 315°C for the remove of lattice water molecule (expt. 6.1%, calc. 4.7%). The second obvious weight-loss stage between 370 and 533°C was resulting from the decomposition of the mixed ligands, leaving Co2O3 as final product of 4 (expt. 22.2%, calc. 21.6%).

The metamagnetism of 1 can be rationalized to be a result of the competition between magnetic coupling within the binuclear subunit and the external field. At the low fields, the anti-parallel alignment of the magnetic moments from the binuclear subunits can lead to an antiferromagnetic ordering. Once the field exceeds 13kOe, weak intra-subunit antiferromagnetic interaction can be overcome by the enhanced field to lead to a weak ferromagnetic state of 1.

AbstractFour isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 anologues, [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, 1; Co, 2; Zn, 3; Cd, 4; ntd = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), are urothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA) and Infrared Spectroscopy (IR). The results of TGA and PXRD for these isostructural compounds show that they exhibit distinct thermal behaviors, where the Zn- and Cd-forms are much easier to lose the ligated e-urea molecules from the frameworks than the Mn- and Co-forms. The CO2 sorption properties and photoluminescent properties of compounds 3 and 4 were also investigated.

Herein, we report the urothermal synthesis, structures and properties of four new coordination polymers: [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, 1; Co, 2; Zn, 3; Cd, 4; ntd = 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), by using ethyleneurea hemihydrate as solvent. The most interesting point of this work is the distinct thermal behavior presented by four isostructural compounds 1–4. The Zn- and Cd-forms can breathe out the ligated e-urea molecules at related low temperature; however it is difficult for the Mn- and Co-forms to lose e-urea. The reason for such difference is analyzed and discussed by considering the detailed bonding nature of these compounds.

), indicating the diffusion of CO2 molecules into the channels. The CO2 uptake at 1 atm for 3 and 4 were 6.7 cm3/g and 13.6 cm3/g, respectively. The higher CO2 uptake capacity of 4 than that of 3 may be due to the higher framework stability of 4.

To study the stability of the three compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on polycrystalline samples in nitrogen atmosphere. For 1, the weight loss of 4.08% from 160 to 279°C is equivalent to the loss of one free water molecule per formula unit (ca. 3.96%), indicating the presence of hydrogen bonding interactions. After 317°C, the decomposition of the framework starts. For 2, the thermogravimetric analysis shows that there is no weight loss up to 360°C, where the entirely decomposition of 2 starts. For 3, the weight loss of 6.78% (calculated: 6.61%) from 45 to 134°C, is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit. Complete decomposition of the framework starts after 415°C.

Large size cadmium chalcogenido clusters with ruthenium complex cations are prepared.Cation–anion charge-transfer property is found for these chalcogenido materials.The intensity of photocurrent is related to the cluster size and the chalcogenido elements of the clusters.IntroductionCadmium chalcogenido quantum dots have attracted much attention because of their intriguing and unique optoelectronic properties. Synthetic challenges in this field include controlling the size and size distribution of the nanoparticles and modifying structure . Large nanosized cadmium chalcogenido clusters have not only the definite structures, but also the extremely low limit of the size distribution and high stability. Therefore, a ‘bottom-up’ approach to the synthesis of well defined large cadmium chalcogenido clusters has been recognized as a key to developing the semiconductor quantum dots technologically . These clusters generally fall into three series: supertetrahedral clusters (Tn), pentasupertetrahedral clusters (Pn), and capped tetrahedral clusters (Cn) . The most exploited large size clusters CdQ (Q = S and Se) are the Cn clusters having 17 , 32 , and 54  cadmium atoms in the clusters (). Besides the potential applications as quantum dots, they could serve as model systems and provide synthetic and structural insights into the formation and properties of nanomaterials. The recent challenges in the CdQ clusters field include functionalizing the cluster materials with counterions or substituents having unique photo or electrochemical properties, such as metal 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) complexes and methyl viologe .

Description of charge-transfer propertyOptical diffuse-reflection UV–vis spectra were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. The absorption spectra of the compounds were calculated from the data of diffuse-reflectance and are depicted in 
. Spectra of three C2 compounds are showed in (a). The intense broad bands at about 3.4 eV for 1 (Se) and 2 (Se) and 3.8 eV for 3 (S) with the onset energy about 2.85 eV for 1, 2 and 3.20 eV for 3 are assigned to the cluster-centered excitation, which indicates that the selenide has the narrower energy gap than that of the sulfide. The band at about 2.75 eV is assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations , which is also the evidence of the presence of these cations in the compounds. The onset energy of the MLCT is about 2.1 eV, which extends the photo absorption to the visible range that significantly narrows the energy gaps of the materials. Based on the results of our previous studies, the shoulder peaks in above 2.9 eV are assigned to charge-transfer bands from cluster anion to [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cation (ACCT) , which overlapped with the MLCT band. (b) shows the spectra difference of the C1 and C2 compounds with the same [Ru(Bpy)3]2+ cations. Comparing to C2 cluster, the onset energy 3.10 eV for C1 cluster 4 shifts to the blue side due to the decreased size of the cluster.

AbstractThe three-dimensional coordination polymer [Cd2(4,4′-bipy)2(H2O)3(SO4)2]·3H2O (1) was synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO4·8/3H2O in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C. The compound was characterized by FT-IR, diffuse reflectance UV–Vis, X-ray powder diffraction and single crystal X-ray analysis. The structure features three-dimensional, interwoven networks. Semiquantitative Kurtz–Perry powder measurements showed that 1 possesses a second-order harmonic generation efficiency of ca. 27% of potasium dihydrogen phosphate.

AbstractTo systematically investigate the influence of the positional isomeric effect on the structures of their complexes, we prepared two Zn(II) complexes [Zn4(L1)(PDC)4]·5H2O and [Zn2(L2)2(PDC)2]·3H2O based on a couple of tetrahedral linkers (L1
=tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane; L2
=tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene)methane) in the presence of the carboxylate linkers (PDC=pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid). Their structures and properties can be tuned by variable N-donor positions of the tetrahedral isomers. The X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrate three-dimensional ones of complex 1 and two-dimensional ones of complex 2. This work indicates that isomeric effect of the couple of isomers play an important role in the construction of the Zn(II) complexes. In addition, their thermostability and photoluminescence are also reported in detail.

Thermal analysesThermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in a N2 atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of 1 and 2 and the results are shown in . The TG curve of 1 shows the first weight loss of 5.32% (calcd: 6.1%) in the temperature range of 25–131.3°C, which indicates the loss of lattice molecules per formula unit. The framework retains until 356.4°C, and then starts to decompose, with an accompanying loss of organic linkers. For 2, the weight loss are attributed to the gradual release of the surface and included water molecules is observed in the range of 25–163.1°C (obsd: 16.7% and calcd: 3.6%), the framework retains in the temperature range of 163.1–523.1°C, and then decomposes. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for 1 and 2. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other (


), which shows that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.

Research highlights► Three-dimensional coordination frameworks with different pore size and shape. ► Solvent effect on formation and structure of metal-organic frameworks. ► Selective sorption behavior of CO2 over N2.AbstractTwo new three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (1) and [Zn(INAIP)]·9H2O (2) have been synthesized by reactions of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O with 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalic acid (H2INAIP) in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and N,N-diethylformamide (DEF), respectively. The change of solvent leads to the formation of neutral frameworks with different structure, topology as well as different pore size and shape. The X-ray crystallographic structural analysis revealed that complex 1 is an unusual 3D architecture with (3, 6)-connected rutile (rtl) topology containing two-dimensional (2D) (4, 4) networks, while the 3D framework in 2 has (3, 6)-connected (42·6)2(44·62·86·103) topology with 2D kagomé layers. In addition, the stabilities, luminescence and adsorption properties of the complexes were investigated.

TGA, powder X-ray diffraction and photoluminescent propertiesThe results of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that compound 1 lost its non-coordinated DMF molecules in the temperature range of 30–190°C () . The weight loss of 29.75% is consistent with calculated one of 29.48%. After the loss of the DMF molecules, the 3D framework is stable up to 340°C, followed by further weight loss at high temperature. The end product of decomposition of complex 1 is ZnO with weight percentage 16.33% (calculated: 16.42%). A total weight loss of 31.11% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 25–275°C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 30.97%), and the decomposition of the residue takes place at about 350°C, the end product of decomposition is also ZnO for 2 with weight percentage of 16.62% (calculated: 15.90%). PXRD was used to check the purity of 1 and 2 () .

The photoluminescent properties of 1, 2 and Na2INAIP were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , intense emission bands were observed at 465nm (λex

=390nm) for Na2INAIP, 481nm (λex

=390nm) for 1, 468nm (λex

=390nm) for 2. The emissions in 1 and 2 can be attributed to neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) since the Zn(II) ions are in d10 configuration and difficult to oxidize or to reduce. Therefore the emissions observed in 1 and 2 are tentatively assigned to the π − π
* intraligand photoluminescence due to its resemblance to that of Na2INAIP. On the other hand, the emission band intensity for complexes 1 and 2 is increased and decreased, respectively, in comparison to the one of Na2INAIP, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of water molecules in 2. The results suggest that the complexes 1 and 2 may be good candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials, since they have high thermal stability and are insoluble in common solvents.

Gas sorption propertiesAs discussed above, the frameworks 1 and 2 are stable up to 340°C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140°C for 20h. To verify whether the framework of 1 can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of 1 still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of 1. The crystalline solid of 1 can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10mL DMF for 12h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex 1 is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex 2 shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of 1 and 2 are investigated. The N2 adsorption isotherms for 1 and 2 are shown in 
a and b, it can be seen that no N2 uptake was observed at 77K for 1 and 2, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO2 (195K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO2 increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90cm3 (STP)/g (1.40mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for 1, 43.19cm3 (STP)/g (0.82mmol/g) for 2, approximately 0.48 CO2 and 0.23 CO2 molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for 1 and 2. Fitting the BET equations to the CO2 adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68m2/g for complexes 1 and 2, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption–desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N2 were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N2 (3.64Å), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO2 (−1.4×10−39
Cm2), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO2 adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO2 over N2 that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .

Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu2(COO)4 paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the a axis (grid dimensions of 10.55×9.42Å2, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca4
− take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from a

×

b plane, the framework structure of 1 is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca4
− molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using platon revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2Å3, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1Å3
. From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu2O2] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu4(μ
3-OH)2] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca4
− ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {412.812.104}{43.83}4{46}{86} (d).

The bib ligand takes a bidentate mode to bridges the 4-connected MnII ion to finally form a 2D (4,4) layer if the bib ligand is simplified as a linear linker (b). These 2D (4,4) layers are piled up together in a parallel pattern to exhibit a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 10.2×12.4Å2 along the a axis (). The 3D packing architecture shows large void space of about 711.5Å3, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. However, the available void space is greatly reduced by the CF3SO3
− counterion, which locates in the 1D channel (
a). Interestingly, the overall void volume of the neutral supermolecular framework is still up to about 478.4Å3, i.e. 41.3% of the cell volume, which is filled with the dichloromethane molecule (b). Unfortunately, when the as-synthesized crystals were taken out from the solution, and placed in the air at room temperature for about 1h, the original shape was destroyed and large crystals gradually collapsed into a mass of powder. The XRPD reveals that the collapsed powder was not matched with the crystal sample (). Furthermore, the collapsed powder exhibits no gas adsorption for N2. Thus crystals of 5 may convert into another tight coordination polymer in the air, which is failed to be characterized by the X-ray crystallography although trying our best.

The reaction of L with two equivalents of silver nitrate in a CH2Cl2–MeCN solution afforded after slow evaporation colorless crystals of 1 in high yield, that are suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO3, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in 1. 1 is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The 1HH NMR spectrum of 1 in DMSO-d
6 reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of 1 a strong band at around 1405cm−1 appeared due to the coordinated NO3
− ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag–S binding in the solid state (
). 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cmc21 and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: −x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal 1 having a acentric space group was refined to be −0.01(2), indicating 1 crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in 1 adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a C
2 symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in 
. The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag–S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag–O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C–H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C–H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85Å (c). It is worth mentioning that previously a silver(I) perchlorate complex based on a similar thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(phenylthiomethyl)benzene has been reported, where a structurally related grid-like network was observed . However, the structure of the repeating macrocyclic motif in this network is essentially distinct with that of 1. In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag–O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5Å), in sharp contrast to the C–H⋯π interactions found in 1 (c)

Synthesis and characterization of Ag2(L)(BF4)2·0.25(H2O) (2)The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in 1 encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for 1, and colorless crystals of 2 were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of 2 shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565cm−1, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519cm−1, consistent with the inclusion of BF4
− in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Imma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in 1, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ2-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of 2 (
a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S–Ag1–S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of 2 during the reaction through a bis-μ2-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF4
− that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in 2 are completely different from that in 1, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.

Thermal propertiesThermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for 1–4 are presented in 
. As shown in , compound 1 is stable up to 179°C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179–365°C and 500–645°C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound 2 undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147°C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of 2 (ca. 1.5 H2O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating 2 is hygroscopic in the air. 2 is then decomposed upon heating to 196°C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound 3 proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163°C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212°C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH3CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of 4 occurs at 234°C.

The thermal stability of the highly porous framework of Compound 4 was estimated using thermogravimetric analysis (
). The removal of the guest DMF molecules was observed below about 200°C (observed 18%, calcd 21%). Any ensuing weight loss due to deformation of the resulting dry sample was not observed until 310°C, implying a high stability of the guest-free framework of Compound 4. A similar stability was reported in the three-dimensional coordination polymer [M2(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)L] (L=triethylenediamine, 4,4′-bipyridine) , which has similar network motifs to Compound 4. Characterization of the functionalities based on the highly porous framework of Compound 4 is currently in progress.

Highlights


•
A new acylamide ligand is reported.


•
An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.


•
A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.


A new acylamide ligand is reported.An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.During the past decade, the construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is the current interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, and more and more people have paid considerable attentions to research it, due to its extensive potential applications in catalysis, separation, ion-exchange, magnetism, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . Currently, several extreme interests on MOFs were focused on designing new topological architectures, and pioneers have disclosed many kinds of topological structure, such as NbO, PtS, CdSO4 net, diamond net, rutile net, boracite net, sodalite net, etc.  Carefully checking the structure characters of MOFs, most of them were constructed from the single type of node, and the MOFs assembled from the double type of nodes are relatively less developed, such as the (3, 4) and (3, 6)-connected MOFs . To achieve this goal, the key factor is the choice of suitable organic ligands and metal centers; that is, to achieve the (3, 4)-connected net, one of the best ways is to choose metal centers with a low coordination number such as Zn, Cu, Co as 4-connected nodes and trigonal organic ligands as 3-connected nodes . Fortunately, herein, we report a novel MOF, namely [Zn2(BTC)2(L)] [(Me2NH2)2]·DMF (Me2NH2
=dimethylamine cation, BTC3−
=1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L=N1,N4-bis (pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)), with (3, 4)-connected (6·82)(6·85)(62
·10)(62
·83
·10) topology and self-penetrating motif .

AbstractA lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L) and Tb(NO3)3·6H2O, namely, [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex 1 exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected sqc net. The solid sample of 1 exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of 1 make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.

Here, we designed and synthesized a π-electron rich polycarboxylates ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H4L). Considering that most of the Ln-MOFs exhibit excellent luminescence properties, lanthanide Tb3+ was choosed as the metal connector to synthesize fluorescent MOFs. We employed this ligand to react with lanthanide Tb3+ to construct a new luminescent 3D Tb-MOF [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1). Because the H4L ligand can effectively sensitize the emission of Tb3+, the solid sample of 1 emits high bright green light upon excitation at 354nm. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol exhibit selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives, indicating the Tb-MOF can be a good candidate for fluorescent sensor.

Results and discussionCrystal structure descriptionSingle-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of I-42d. The asymmetrical unit of 1 contains half a Tb3+ ion, half a L4− ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH3)2NH2
+ cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in 
a, the central Tb3+ ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L4− ligands. The Tb–O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb3+ compounds . Two symmetry related Tb3+ ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)Å. Each L4− anion coordinates to 8 Tb3+ ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ2-η1:η1 and μ1-η1:η1 mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit are linked by L4− anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in 1 is 2206.6Å3, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the platon program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L4− anions and the [Tb2(CO2)8] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex 1 can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected sqc network with Schläfli symbol of (43
·63)(412
·616).

Fluorescence behaviors and sensing propertiesThe lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354nm, complex 1 exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb3+ ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621nm can be attributed to the transitions of 5D4–7F
J
 (J
=6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb3+ ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243nm, the free H4L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388nm, which is attributed to the π–π∗ transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex 1 suggests that H4L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb3+ ions. The strongest emission in 1 appears at 545nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of 1 being a fluorescence sensor.

ConclusionsIn conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a novel fluorescent Tb-MOF [(CH3)2NH2][TbL] (1) with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid H4L. The complex exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb2(CO2)8] subunit. The solid-state fluorescent measurements indicated that the ligand H4L can sensitize the fluorescence intensities of Tb3+ ions, resulting in the strong fluorescence emission of Tb-MOF. The fine grinding particles of 1 dispersed in ethanol exhibits a high quenching efficiency for PA. The application of 1 may enable further development of new chemosensors for explosives.

The tetrahedral [ZnN2O2] geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is comprised of two oxygen atoms from two different L4− ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4′-bpy ligands (
(a)). The bond distances of Zn-O and Zn-N are in the range 1.952–2.079Å and the bond angles around the Zn (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 95.38–132.51°. In the compound 1, on the one hand the 4,4′-bpy ligand connects two tetrahedral [ZnN2O2] centres in the 1D metal-pyridyl chains through the N atoms of the pyridyl rings with a separation of 10.9588Å resulting in the formation of a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D metal-pyridyl chain, the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings is 13.022°. Therefore, two pyridyl rings of 4,4′-bpy are not coplanar. On the other hand each L4− ligand connects to four [ZnN2O2] tetrahedrons at four orientational positions by a μ1-η1: η0 monodentate modes forming a 2D network, characterized by the Cphenyl-O…O-Cphenyl torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L4− ligand, and the torsion angle of Cphenyl-O…CH2-CH2, O-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-CH2, CH2-CH2…CH2-O, and CH2-CH2… O-Cphenyl is 178°, 179°, 180°, 179°, and 178° in the L4− ligand, and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings of L4− is 0°, hence all oxygen and carbon atoms of the L4−are mainly coplanar((c)). Finally, the 2D network structures formed by L4− ligand and [ZnN2O2] tetrahedra were interconnected by the 1D metal-pyridyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (15.0977Å×22.2255Å) (
(a)). The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks, with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b)).

ConclusionsIn summary, we successfully designed and synthesized three coordination polymers based on flexible multicarboxylic acid 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L), and one rigid ancillary bridging pyridine linkers 4,4′ -bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) for 1, one flexible ancillary imidazole linkers 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) for 2 and 3. These compounds display interesting and versatile coordination features from 3D to 3D parallel entangled frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that 1–3 are 3D (4,4)-connected bbf topology net with the (64·82)(66) topology. The adjustable channels size of individual 3D framework is realized by using different lengths of co-ligands from byp to bib with keeping similar architectures of compounds 1–3. In compound 3, the assignment of characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra at 580nm correlated with the d-d transitions of Co2+ ions in field of tetrahedral coordination is confirmed by the result of the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of 1 and 2 were investigated, and the emission bands were assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), and the different emission wavelength due to the effect of co-ligands. The solid-state thermal stabilities were investigated. The frameworks of 1, 2 and 3 are stable under 350°C.

Presented here is a microporous formate framework.The HCOO- was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO2 capture.AbstractA metal–organic framework [Mn3(HCOO)6]·DMF (1) with in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent has been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Infrared Spectroscopy (IR) and Elemental analysis (EA). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the b axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces. The desolvated samples exhibit interesting adsorption properties and show high selectivity for the adsorption of CO2 over N2 under ambient conditions.

Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a class of crystalline solid-state material featuring regular and designable channel structures with permanent porosity . Porous MOFs with high surface areas and tunable structures have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their fascinating architectures and intriguing topologies, but also for their potential applications in sensing, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and separation . Flue gases consist of nitrogen (typically more than two-thirds), carbon dioxide, water vapor, oxygen, and minor components such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur oxides. Economical and efficient CO2 capture and storage (CCS) has been attracting tremendous attention due to the culprit for causing the greenhouse effect . Several technologies have been considered for CO2 capture and separation from nitrogen-rich streams, including absorption, adsorption and membranes separations . In particular, for separation of CO2/N2, because of the relatively similar kinetic diameters of the molecules (3.3 and 3.64Å, respectively), it would require materials operating on a size-selective mechanism to possess very small pores, which may limit the diffusion of gases throughout the material. Therefore, to find a suitable pore size material is a necessary condition for CO2/N2 separation. Herein, we report an compound [Mn3(HCOO)6]·DMF (1), synthesized by Mn salt and in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of DMF solvent , which exhibits high CO2 adsorption and selectivity of CO2 over N2 under ambient conditions.

To study the thermal behavior of compound 1, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 were performed on polycrystalline sample to determine its thermal behavior from 25 to 800°C. TGA on the as-synthesized sample of 1 indicated weight loss of 14.72% before 300°C, which corresponding to the release of solvent (DMF) molecules. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that the framework is stable up to ca. 300°C (Fig. S1). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose. We notice that the compound 1 has less thermal stability than that of [Mn3(HCOO)6]·[1,4-dioxane] reported by Kim et al. . We also check the PXRD patterns between the desolvated and as-synthesized samples, and find that the main peaks of the desolvated one shift to high angles (
). Interestingly, after immersing in DMF or MeOH again, it will restore to its original look. We deduce that the guest DMF in 1 is irregular, and has higher boiling point and bigger spatial volume than that of 1,4-dioxane, so the framework of 1 shows a little expansion to encapsule big guest molecule and less thermal stability after releasing the guest.

), which is characteristic of microporous materials. The maximum N2 uptake at 1bar for 1 is 28.36cm3
