A copper molybdate coordination polymer has been synthesized.The coordination polymer was used as an epoxidation catalyst.The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in the epoxidation reactions.AbstractThrough exploitation of hydrothermal synthesis, a mixture of crystals containing blue [CuMoO4(N2C12H8)]·H2O (1) and yellow ([Cu3
ICl(4,4′-bipy)4][CuII(1,10-phen)2Mo8O26]) (4,4′-bipy=4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen=1,10-phenanthroline) (2) were obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound 1 is a new 1-D coordination polymer while compound 2 is a known metal–organic framework. The obtained crystals have been further characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), FT-IR and inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalytic properties of the prepared mixture were investigated in the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) or cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) as oxidants. It was found that the crystals could serve as an active and selective catalyst for the epoxidation of the olefins and allylic alcohols. The catalyst can be recovered easily and reused in the reaction without considerable decrease in activity or selectivity. Moreover, the influence of the type of oxidant and solvent on the conversion of the olefins was studied.

The further heating leads to two residual aqua ligands escaping within 295–360°C with a weight loss of 1.4% (calc. 1.5%). The high releasing temperature of these two aqua ligands can be attributed to their short Tb–Owater bond lengths of 2.367(6)–2.372(7) Å, on the contrary, the other seven aqua ligands are released under lower temperature arising from their longer Tb–Owater bond lengths of 2.391(6)–2.468(6) Å. Thermogravimetric analysisThermogravimetric analysis of 1–4 reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for 1, 35.5% for 2, 36.1% for 3 and 35.8% for 4) until 429°C, 421°C, 431°C and 428°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4′-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4′-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for 1, 36.2% for 2, 36.9% for 3 and 36.3% for 4). In compound 5, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H2O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2′-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).

Description of the crystal structureStructure of {[Zn3(L)(1,4-bdc)3]·2DMF}n(1)X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and features a 3D framework structure, and it consists of three Zn(II) ions (Zn1, Zn2 and Zn1#5, symmetry code: #5 -x+1,-y,-z+1), one L ligand, three bdc2− anions and two uncoordinated DMF molecules. The Zn(II) ions show different coordination geometries. The Zn1 (Zn1#5) ion is five coordinated with a distorted pentahedron coordination geometry, which is fulfilled by four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4 and O5) originating from three independent 1,4-H2bdc ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) of the L ligand with the coordination angles varying from 99.9(9)° to 121.9(6)°. The ZnN bond length is 2.004(3) Å, and the lengths of ZnO bonds are 1.975(3) Å, 1.955(3) Å and 1.930(3) Å, respectively, four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom are located on the five vertices of pentahedron, and the Zn1(Zn1#5) is located in the center of pentahedron (
a). The Zn2 center is six coordinated by six O atoms from six 1,4-bdc2- ions to complete an octahedral geometry with the coordination angles varying from 81.9(6)° to 120.0(0)°. The ZnO bond lengths are 2.036(3) Å, 2.058(3) Å and 2.181(3) Å, severally. The four oxygen atoms (O3, O3#5, O6, and O6#5) are located in the equatorial plane location of octahedral and the two oxygen atoms (O1, O1#5) are located in the axial location of octahedral (
b). Three Zn(II) ions (Zn1, Zn2 and Zn1#5) are bridged by μ
2-1,3-carboxylate and μ
2-carboxylate oxygen atoms to form a trimer (
c), with the Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.205 Å. The dihedral angle between one pyridine ring and one anthracene ring in the same L is 63.9°. The trimers are joined through the scaffolds of 1,4-H2bdc ligands, leading to the formation of a 44
-sqc
 coordination layer and two trimers in a diagonal position are linked by 1,4-H2bdc (
d). The L ligand adopts bidentate bridging coordination, linking the 2D layers to form a 3D framework (
e). Meanwhile, from the topological point of view, Zn2 can be described as 8-connected nodes, and the ligands are regarded as linear linkers. Thus, the structure of 1 can be simplified as a 3D 8-connected framework with the point symbol of (424·64) (
f).

For the sake of researching the framework stability of the complexes 1–3 were shown in Supplementary 2 . The TG shows that the complex 2 undergoes decomposition in two stages, and the complex 3 undergoes decomposition in three stages . For 1, in the whole process of stepwise decomposition until the temperature rise to 500 °C, the final residual of 19.05% may be the mixture of ZnCO3 and ZnO (Calcd 20.17%). For 2, the first loss of 39.34%, occurs between 25 °C and 150 °C, corresponding to the loss of three lattice DMF molecules and two L molecules (Calcd 38.49%). The second that occurs between 300° and 475° are ascribed to the collapse of the framework. The final residual of 9.08% may be the mixture of ZnCO3 and ZnO (Calcd 7.33%). For 3, the first loss, of 9.42%, occurs between 25 °C and 80 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice DMF molecule (Calcd 9.02%). The second occurs between 130 °C and 240 °C, amounting to about 10.09%, corresponding to escape of one lattice DMF molecule (Calcd 9.02%), and the third weight loss between 350 °C and 500 °C amounts to about 60.02%, which is ascribed to the collapse of the framework (Calcd 60.35%), and the final residual of 19.37% may be CdCO3 (Calcd 20.84%).

Fluorescent propertiesIt is known that many d10 metal complexes exhibit luminescence properties. The coordination complexes with the rational selection and design of conjugated organic spacers with metal centers can be efficient for obtaining new luminescent materials . To investigate the luminescence properties of complexes 1–3, the solid-state fluorescent properties of 1–3 as well as the ligand L have been studied at room temperature under the same experimental condition and their emission spectra are given in Supplementary 2 . When excited with 390 nm light, the free L ligand exhibited an emission peak at 470 nm, which originated from ligand internal change transfer. Upon excitation with 390 nm light, complexes 1–3 all display intense photoluminescence, with emission maxima at 474, 440 and 440 nm, respectively. Compared with the free L Ligand, the introduction of Zn(II) and Cd(II) to ligand L led to a weak blue-shift for complexes 2 and 3. On the one hand, because the N atoms coordination to the metal center, the electron transfer to the metal ions and occurs Ligand-to-Metal Charge Transition (LMCT). Moreover, the ligand π* track as the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the metal d track for the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), the electron transfer when subjected to external excitation, resulting in the maximum absorption wavelength of the compounds blue shift. On the other hand, the differences of the peaks for 1 may be resulted from different coordination environments around Zn(II) and Cd(II) centers . In addition, the high-dimensional structures of complexes 2 and 3 lead to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity compared to that of the free ligand. The enhancement of fluorescence intensity of complexes 1–3 can be attributed to the following aspects: firstly, anthracene is a kind of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons with strong fluorescence emission; secondly, the ligand coordination to the metal center and increase plane conjugated system of ligands, which the intraligand π → π* transition occurs more easily; on the other hand, the ligand rigidity enhancement and thus reduces the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway , however, fluorescence enhancement of complexes 1–3.

ConclusionIn summary, three new Zn(II)/Cd(II) complexes with 9,10-di(pyridine-4-yl)anthracene have been successfully constructed and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, element analysis, IR and PXRD. Complexes 1–3 have the 3D network structure. The central metals, reaction solvents and temperatures play crucial roles in the formation of complexes 1–3. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of the complexes 1–3 demonstrate that they have high phase purity. In addition, we studied thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes 1–3. We believe that this study reveals the effectiveness of general solvothermal processing methods which are influenced by the nature of the solvent and reaction temperature. Because of the multi ring structure of the ligand molecule, the solubility of the ligand is reduced and the difficulty coefficient is enhanced. Complexes 1–3 has a novel structure and strong fluorescence properties, which indicated that those complexes can be used as a potential functional materials, for example used in LED lamps. For another, the coordination of the carboxylate group from auxiliary ligand to metal center effectively increase the dimension of the coordination polymers, which provides a potential guiding significance for the synthesis of coordination polymers with multi dimensions.

Crystal structure of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7
·4H2O]∞
In the second compound, namely [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7
·4H2O]∞, as can be seen in 
, the La(III) ion is coordinated by ten oxygen atoms forming a distorted bi-capped dodecahedron. Six out of them come from four (ntc4−) ligands and the four others come from the coordination water molecules. All carboxyl groups of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid are deprotonated, in agreement with the IR spectrum in which no strong absorption peak around 1700cm−1 for –COOH is observed. Two of the four carboxylate groups of (ntc4−) adopt a bidentate chelating mode, while the other two adopt an unidentate chelating mode, chelating four La(III) ions (see ).

Found: C, 28.5; H, 3.1; O, 40.83; La, 23.6; Na, 3.9%.Similar IR spectra have been observed for both hydrated and partially dehydrated compounds. The partial dehydration has been checked and confirmed by thermogravimetric measurements.At last, the partially dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to moisture.Estimated porosity of compound [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞
In order to evaluate the porosity of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7]∞, we have formally removed the crystallization water molecules from the crystal structure of [LaNa[(C10H4)(COO)4](H2O)7
·4H2O]∞ and applied a computational method  based on Connolly’s algorithm . Thanks to this method, the porosity of a partially dehydrated material can be calculated on the basis of its crystal structure. Furthermore, this method allows obtaining the maximal kinetic radius a guest molecule can present for being hosted by the structure. In this case (see 
), it appears that the compound can host molecules with a kinetic radius smaller than 1.5Å, for instance, He (1.3Å) or H2 (1.45Å). The estimated potential porosity, calculated with 1.45Å as probe sphere radius, is actually 757m2
g−1.

Thermal propertiesComplex 1 is very stable in air at ambient temperature and almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, methanol and acetone. Complex 2 is also stable in air at room temperature but soluble in methanol. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1 and 2. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 20 °C min−1. The TGA curve shows that 1 is stable up to 120 °C. A total weight loss of 16.3% occurred in the temperature range 120–230 °C, presumably due to the removal of the guest methanol molecules and the bonded H2O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 16.4%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 230–320 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. The TGA curve shows that 2 is stable up to 100 °C. A total weight loss of 5.6% occurred in the temperature range 100–150 °C, corresponding to the removal of the guest H2O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 5.9%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 380–420 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. Their T
m values have been measured by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and these are 107.2° and 134.9° for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.

The self-assembly process of coordination polymer can also be influenced by some subtle effects (reaction temperature, solvent, et al.), and counterions may show coligand effects. For example, thiocyanate anion has extraordinary varieties in the binding of complexes and shows great potential in building coordination frameworks. It can adopt end-on and end-to-end fashions via the nitrogen and sulfur atoms to bind metal ions. In particular, the end-to-end bridging fashion increases the dimensionality of the coordination network by the interlinking of the 1D chains or 2D networks, and meantime it enhances the interactions between paramagnetic metal-ions. It is worthy to note that cadmium thiocyanate adducts of organic ligands are an important class of complexes for the design and preparation of functional coordination frameworks since Cd(II) ion can form stable double SCN bridged chains .

Luminescence properties of complexes 1–4
Inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers, especially those with d
10 metal centers, have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs) . The luminescent behaviors of complexes 1–4 were studied at room temperature in the solid state. As shown in 
, intense emission bands were observed at 421nm (λ
ex
=338nm) for DPBA-3, 422nm (λ
ex
=345nm) for 1, 431nm (λ
ex
=349nm) for 2, 437nm (λ
ex
=349nm) for 3, 437nm (λ
ex
=399nm) for 4, respectively. Compared to the DPBA-3 ligand, the emission bands of 1, 2, 3 and 4 are 1, 10, 16 and 16nm red shifted, respectively, which was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of metal atom to the ligand. The similar emissions between the ligand and the complexes are also probably contributed by the π–π∗ intraligand fluorescence .

). The weight loss from room temperature to about 300°C can be assigned to the release of all coordinated water, DMF molecules and lattice solvent molecules. The second weight loss from 340°C to 450°C can be attributed to the decomposition of the compound, which is indicated by an exothermal peak at 413°C in the DSC curve. Gas sorption of 2
The porosities of compounds 1 and 2 were evaluated by measuring N2 sorption at 77K. Before the gas sorption measurement, the samples of 2 were vacuum dried at 100°C. The N2 adsorption isotherm (
) exhibits a type-I adsorption behavior, which suggests that 1 and 2 possess permanent porosity. From the adsorption branch of the isotherm, the Langmuir and BET surface areas were calculated to be 347.6 and 267.7m2
g−1, respectively. A whole hysteresis of desorption was observed in the isotherm. The sample also exhibits some gas adsorption toward H2. A similar hysteresis of desorption was also observed in the isotherm of H2.

AbstractTwo new Zn(II) compounds, namely [(CH3)2NH2]2n[Zn3(bpt)2(datrz)2]n (1) and [(CH3)2NH2)]n[Zn2(bptc)(datrz)]n·n(H2O) (2) (H3bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H4bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole), have been obtained by the self-assemble reactions of Zn(NO3)2, 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole, aromatic polycarboxylate ligands under solvothermal conditions. Single crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that both compounds display three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Compound 1 features a trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.62}2{4.64.8}{46.64.85}. Compound 2 displays a binodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {32.62.72}{34.42.64.75}. In addition, the thermal stabilities and luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated in the solid state at room temperature.

Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal analyses of compounds 1 and 2
The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds 1 and 2 have been confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analyses. As shown in 

, the major peak positions of the bulk solids of compounds 1 and 2 match well with those of the simulated patterns based on respective single crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicating that the synthesized compounds are in pure phase. In addition, the thermal behaviors of compounds 1 and 2 were also investigated by thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound 1, there is no obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 30–270 °C, and after 270 °C, the framework started to collapse accompanied by the decomposition of the organic components. The residue of the powder may be ZnO (obsd: 24.98%, calcd: 24.18%) (c). For compound 2, the weight loss corresponding to the departure of the lattice water molecule is observed from to (obsd: 2.72%, calcd: 2.92%). The framework can be stable up to 271 °C, where the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands. Finally, the remnants are 27.52%, corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calcd: 26.24%) (d) (see ).

Photoluminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2
Metal-organic frameworks with d10 transition metal ions have attracted intense interest from chemists owing to their potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this work, the luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 as well as the free ligands (H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz) were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The free H3bpt, H4bptc and Hdatrz ligands display intense emission peaks at 388 nm (λex = 345 nm), 402 nm (λex = 345 nm), 435 nm (λex = 340 nm), respectively, which can be assigned to the π*-n or π*-π transitions (b). Under the excitation light of 340 nm, compounds 1 and 2 show broad emission bands centered at 442 nm and 445 nm, respectively (a). Notably, the luminescent emission peaks of compounds 1 and 2 are similar to that of free Hdatrz ligand with red-shifts of 7 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The absence of the carboxylate-based ligands (H3bpt and H4bptc) emission bands further indicates that the luminescence of compounds 1 and 2 can be attributed to Hdatrz intraligand charge transfer .

ConclusionIn summary, two new luminescent Zn(II) compounds based on 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole mixed with two different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared under solvothermal conditions. The two compounds both possess 3D frameworks but with different topologies. Compound 1 displays a trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network, and compound 2 displays a binodal (4.6)-connected topological network. The high thermal stabilities and intense luminescent properties of compounds 1 and 2 indicate that they can be used as new photoactive materials.

The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO4·8/3H2O in water in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C gave 1 as pure crystalline product in 57% yield. A sample of 256 mg (1.0 mmol) CdSO4·8/3H2O and 156 mg (1.0 mmol) 4,4′-bipyridine was mixed thoroughly and loaded into a thick-walled Pyrex tube. After ∼1.0 ml H2O was added, the tube was frozen with liquid N2, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a flame. The reaction was carried out at 120°C for 24 h to afford colorless single crystals of 1. The product was isolated by acetone washing in 57% yield. The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF, acetone, CH2Cl2, and CH3CN or water. The single crystal X-ray structure analysis showed that 1 crystallizes in the C-centered, noncentrosymmetric space group C2 (No. 5). Crystallographic data for 1, C20H28Cd2N4O14S2, monoclinic C2 (No. 5), a=24.624(1), b=9.7554(5), c=13.5956(7) Å, β=120.663(1)°, V=2809.2(2) Å3, Z=4, ρ
calc=1.980 g cm−3, μ=1.740 mm−1, T=295 K, structure solution and refinement based on 5239 reflections including Friedel mates (3254 unique) with I
o≥3.0σ(I
o) converged at R=0.0342, R
w=0.0481 and goodness-of-fit=1.85. Data were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction based on redundant reflections was applied to the data set. The absolute configuration was unambiguously assigned based on the analysis of the Bijovot pairs and the refinement of the Flack parameter. The absence of inversion center in the structure was also confirmed by MISYM. The refinement of Flack parameter for the chosen configuration gave 0.00020(9) with 5239 reflections where F
c(H) and F
c(–H) differ by more than 0.0001. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd2+ ions, two 4,4′-bipy ligands, two SO4

2− anions, and three coordinate and three crystallization water molecules. The metal centers are first linked by the SO4

2− anions to form the one-dimensional arrays of fused 12-membered rings containing three cadmium, three sulfur and six oxygen atoms (see 
). The arrays are drawn together by hydrogen bonding between the coordinate water molecules and the SO4

2− anions from the adjacent net. The two SO4

2− anions are split into μ2- and μ3-bridging ligands. Thus, Cd(1) is coordinated by a μ2-SO4

2−, a μ3-SO4

2− and two cis-H2O molecules while the Cd(2) is linked by a μ2-SO4

2−, two different μ3-SO4

2− anions and a water. The 4,4′-bipy ligands act as ‘posts’ that connect the cadmium centers to form the one-dimensional [Cd2(4,4′-bipy)2(H2O)3]
n


4+ chains. The coordination of both Cd atoms can best be described as slightly distorted octahedral with four O atoms situated in the square plane and two N atoms occupying the axial positions. 
 depicts the coordination environments of the two Cd atoms. Rather than being parallel, these chains run across each other from two different directions. Thus, the compound forms three-dimensional interwoven networks as shown in 
. The most common coordination modes of the SO4

2− ion are monodentate, bidentate and μ2-bridging, while μ3-bridging is much less frequent . The combination of both μ2- and μ3-bridging in the same structure is hitherto unreported. The fact that 1 crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group can perhaps be attributed to this unusual combination of the two different bridging modes for the SO4

2− anion. We have noticed that the use of simple, weaker coordinating anions such as NO3

− and ClO4

− results in centrosymmetric more often than noncentrosymmetric crystal packing.

Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from ZnII and 4-(2-ethyl-1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.They display 3-fold pcu and 4-fold dia interpenetrating networks.Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn2(2-eiba)3(OH)]
n
 (1) and {[Zn(2-eiba)2](H2O)3}
n
 (2) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.

ExperimentalSynthesis4,4′-Bipyrazolyl originally was synthesized by Trofimenko in a laborious nine step procedure starting with diethyl succinate via 3,4-diformylfuran and 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide intermediates . Unfortunately, bipyrazolyls are inaccessible through Ullmann coupling of 4-halogenated pyrazoles . A more efficient way to 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide, that is the closest precursor to bpz, is hydrolysis of bis-trimethinium salts [(R2NCH)2CC(CHNR2)2]2+.

Solid [(Me2NCH)2CC(CHNMe2)2](ClO4)2 (22.71 g, 0.05 mol)  was added to a solution of NaOH (10.06 g, 0.25 mol) in 60 ml water and the mixture was heated for 12 min on water bath with external temperature at 80–82°C. Total dissolution of perchlorate and evolution of dimethylamine was observed within minutes; slightly yellow solution was acidified with HCl (1:1) to pH 3 and excess of hydrazine hydrate (8.0 ml) was added at once with stirring. Resulting yellow–brown mixture was left overnight, the deposit of bpz was filtered off and recrystallized from aq. DMF to yield 5.51 g (82%) of colorless crystals. They are stable on air and did not melt up to 300°C (!) and very poorly soluble in all usual solvents. Solubility in DMF at r.t. is 0.73 g/100 ml. 1H NMR (Bruker, 400 MHz, DMSO-d6, δ ppm): 7.78 (4H, CH), 12.74 (2H, NH).

Cobalt(II) chloride complexes were synthesized using the layering technique. A typical procedure was as follows: in a glass tube the solution of 0.040 g (0.3 mmol) bpz in 6 ml DMF (first layer), 5 ml of 1:1 DMF/methanol mixture and solution of 0.036 g (0.15 mmol) CoCl2·6H2O in 5 ml MeOH were layered each on the top of the other avoiding interfusion. The crystals of the product grew on walls of the tube as the solutes slowly interdiffused for the period of 7–10 days. The product consists of two complexes, crystals of which were separated manually: [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2DMF (5), light-pink blocks and [Co(bpz)2Cl2]·2CH3OH (6), pink prisms.

An easy, but specific procedure was employed for crystallization of copper(II) coordination polymers. Thus, solutions of 0.110 g (0.35 mmol) CuSiF6·6H2O in 2 ml water and 0.088 g (0.72 mmol) KClO3 in 3 ml water were combined and precipitate of K2SiF6 was filtered off. To the resulting copper(II) chlorate solution 0.094 g (0.70 mmol) of solid bpz was added and the mixture was stored at room temperature for about 50 days that effected total dissolution of the ligand and crystallization of the complex [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](ClO3)2·4H2O (10) as large deep cyan–blue blocks. The yield was 0.14 g (70%). In similar conditions, reaction of solid bpz ligand with aq. solutions of copper(II) salts afforded well-crystalline products: [Cu(bpz)(H2O)3(SO4)]·H2O (1), light-green and [Cu(bpz)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3) (2), green–blue. This procedure, under presence of water soluble aromatics, also allows the preparation of inclusion compounds, cf. [Cu(bpz)2(H2O)2](CF3CO2)2·2H2O·C6H5OH (7), blue prisms.

The phosphonic acid with formula (H2O3PCH2)-NC10H18N-(CH2PO3H2), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound 1 was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404g of Ce(SO4)2
·4H2O (1mmol) with 0.328g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1mmol) in 25ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.

SynthesisIn a typical procedure pytac (0.5mmol), cobalt nitrate or cadmium iodide (0.5mmol), and ammonium vanadate (0.5mmol), were placed in a 23mL Teflon-lined autoclave with 10mL water. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 130°C at 1°C/min and held at that temperature for 72h. At the end of this period, the autoclave was cooled to 80°C at 0.1°C/min and held at that temperature for 12h before cooling to room temperature at the same rate. Cobalt nitrate and pytac were utilized for the synthesis of complex 1. An irregular orange crystal fragment was cleaved from a multi-crystalline mass and used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, and pytac were used in the synthesis of complex 2. An irregular, orange-red crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cadmium iodide and pytac were used to synthesize complex 3. A yellow bar-shaped crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis.

In this work, our strategy for constructing framework was to combine the chalcogenide cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− with La3+. The wide variety of applications that lanthanide complexes have in many fields is well-known , such as contrast agents or luminescent chemosensors, and explains the growing interest to the coordination and supramolecular chemistry of trivalent lanthanide ions . Researches in this field are mainly focused on efficient light converting devices. In a precedent work, we described a new hybrid layered compound La0.75Cl0.25[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅18H2O obtained at room temperature and ambient pressure in acidic solution starting from the cluster [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− and La3+ cation . In this compound, the hanging carboxylate functions of the nitrilotriacetic acid ligand were still available for further coordinations. We thus attempted to engage the free remaining carboxylate functions and hydrothermal conditions proved to be the best strategy for functionalisation.

In a previous work , the pHmetric titration of the [Mo3S4(HNTA)3]2− anion revealed that the three hanging carboxylates deprotonate quasi-simultaneously at pH ~4.5 (pKa ~3.5), leading to [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5−. In the presence of the La3+ cation and at a pH above 4.5, a green precipitate formed at room temperature. All attempts to get crystals from this precipitate under deprotonation conditions (pH>4.5) invariably failed as a result of the high insolubility of the La2[Mo3S4(HNTA)3]3 in these conditions. Crystals of La0.75Cl0.25[Mo3S4(HNTA)3]⋅18H2O were only obtained by working in acidic medium. Thus, hydrothermal synthesis was envisioned as a possible alternative to conventional synthesis and crystals of La2Cl[Mo3S4(NTA)3]⋅17H2O (1) were finally obtained at pH 5 by heating at 100°C for 36hours, followed by a slow cooling rate . Interest of hydrothermal syntheses compared to traditional aqueous reactions is that the reaction conditions are shifted from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain and thereby provides a powerful tool for the synthesis of hybrid materials.

In summary, this work shows that the free hanging carboxylate functions of [Mo3S4(NTA)3]5− anion can be bounded to La(III) ions by hydrothermal synthesis to build a new 3D-network. Our strategy of synthesis reveals to be appropriate to exploit the overall potentialities of this cluster to isolate 3D networks. In further work we will attempt to modify the free carboxylate functions by using a longer alkyl chain to see for instance if 3D networks with interesting properties such as porosities could be achieved.

=0.71073Å). An absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program  based on the Blessing method . The structures were solved by direct methods followed by Fourier difference syntheses using the SHELXTL package. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. H atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Selected interatomic distances (Å) are given in  for (1).

AbstractFour 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz)-based cobalt(II/III) coordination polymers, {[Co2(Hdatrz)(NH2-ip)2]·0.5H2O}
n
 (1), [Co(CH3OH)(Hdatrz)(CH3-ip)]
n
 (2), {[Co2(datrz)2(CH3-ip)]·2.5H2O}
n
 (3) and {[Co(datrz)(NO2-ip)]·H2O}
n
 (4) (NH2-ip2−
=5-aminoisophthalate, CH3-ip2−
=5-methylisophthalate and NO2-ip2−
=5-nitroisophthalate), were hydro-/solvothermally synthesized by changing the substituents attached on the isophthalate coligand, which were structurally and magnetically characterized. Complex 1 is a corrugated layer with dimeric {Co2(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}4+ subunits extended by three-connected NH2-ip2− connectors. Constructed from the same mixed ligands, both 2 and 3 exhibit robust three-dimensional (3D) frameworks consisting of helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}2+ chain and corner-sharing triangular {Co2(μ3-N1,N2,N4-datrz)2}2+ layer, respectively. By contrast, two bis-monodentate NO2-ip2− and two μ-N1,N4-datrz− anions connect tetrahedral Co(III) sites into a (4, 4) grid-like layer of 4. Thus, the substituent of the isophthalate coligand is observed to virtually influence the overall structures of the resulting complexes by changing the binding modes of the coligand and coordination polyhedra. Additionally, complex 1 exhibits a metamagnetic transition from antiferromagnetic ordering to weak ferromagnetic state. Instead, typically antiferromagnetic interactions are respectively mediated by the cyclic triazolate ligand along the helical chain of 2 and in the distorted triangular layer of 3.

IntroductionMetal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing attention due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in the areas of gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetism and so on . Much effort has been devoted to the construction of MOFs with tunable properties using metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) and organic ligands as linkers . Compared with the way to rationalize novel network topologies and improve the properties by designing the linkers, it is a rather complex process to build MOFs with in situ generated polynuclear units as SBUs . The creation of anticipated cluster, especially high-connected cluster SBUs, is still a challenge. Some compounds based on polynuclear CoII

n
 (n
=2–8) clusters and multicarboxylate have been reported . Dietzel et al. reported a MOF compound with 1D pores containing some Co(II) chains as infinite-rod SBUS and 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate as the linker . Recently, Han and co-workers prepared two 6-connected 3D frameworks with Co5 or Co2 cluster SBUs .

IntroductionThe rational synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable attention because of their structural diversity and potential application in catalysis, gas storage and separation etc. . Chemical synthesis of MOFs is largely dependent on the use of solvents, and the well-known synthetic methods include hydrothermal, solvothermal and ionothermal synthesis . Recently, urothermal synthesis that use urea derivatives as solvents opened a new approach toward the creation of porous framework materials with promising applications . One particular feature of urothermal method is that urea derivatives exhibit a range of binding affinity for various metal cationic sites, which is strong enough to allow them to bond competitively to metal sites during crystallization, and yet weak enough to be readily removed after synthesis to generate porosity and open metal sites.

ConclusionIn summary, through careful consideration of asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand, biphenyl-2,3,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, two distinct nanoporous Cu-MOFs are constructed by modification of reactant ratio. The asymmetrical “short axis – long axis” nature of the ligand possessing long molecular backbone and inclined carboxyls leads to the noninterpenetrating features of the synthesized complexes with high porosity. It also shows a rare example of clusters-based framework with the coexistence of triple polynuclear cluster SBUs of tetranuclear [Cu4(μ
3-OH)2] clusters, dinuclear [Cu2O2] clusters surrounded by cage-like units, and [Cu2(COO)4] paddle-wheel fragments. Whereas, the MOF 2 shows the structural changes with less complicated mononuclear Cu(bptca)2 and paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4. The results reveal the importance of synthetic strategy and external factors such as reactant ratio for structural designing of porous MOFs. Thus, it could be predicted that more porous MOFs with fascinating structural merits and adsorption properties are to be designed and constructed under control.

In this regard, our synthetic strategy was to select an analogue of bpe or dpe: 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), and introduce benzenedicarboxylic acid (5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, OH-H2BDC) as an auxiliary ligand into the reaction systems, with the following considerations: (1) Bpp, compared to bpe or dpe, has a longer and more flexible conformation. Accordingly, it possesses TT, TG, GG and GG′ conformations (T
=
trans, G=
gauche) owing to the free twist of the propyl group (–CH2–CH2–CH2–). Thereby it can adopt different conformations to take part in coordination . (2) The aim of combining OH-H2BDC into the reaction system is to simplify the control and modulation of the final results, because the deprotonated carboxylate groups, which possess rich coordination modes (
), may act as anionic groups and afford neutral metal-organic frameworks. (3) The hydroxyl group (–OH) can provide hydrogen bonding interactions with other groups and further stabilize the structures. On the other hand, the architectures from mixed ligands of bpp and di-or poly-carboxylate ligands, to our knowledge, are still rare to date , although some metal-organic frameworks from the direct assembly of bpp and metal ions have been investigated . Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of three interpenetrated coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]·H2O}
n

n

sym(CO2) is 174cm−1. For 2, one antisymmetric stretching band (1562cm−1) and two symmetric stretching bands (1412 and 1357cm−1) are exhibited, the Δ values are 150 and 205cm−1, respectively. For 3, the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups are at 1564 and 1387cm−1, with a Δ value ca. 177cm−1. In conclusion, we have synthesized and structurally characterized a novel three-dimensional coordination polymer [Cd2(4,4′-bipy)2(H2O)3(SO4)2]·3H2O. Although molecular self-assembly approaches have been explored by Fujita et al. , Yaghi and Li , and several other groups  for making metal 4,4′-bipyridine coordination polymers containing non-coordinating anions such as NO3

− and ClO4

−, the use of the coordinating anion SO4

2− gives rise to a three-dimensional interwoven network structure because of the complex coordination mode of the anion. Such a novel molecular architecture is hitherto unknown. To the best of our knowledge, 1 is the first example of coordination polymers to show second-order nonlinear optical effects. The other known noncentrosymmetric coordination polymers include [Cu(pyrimidine)2]BF4 (2), also a three-dimensional metal-pyridyl compound , [Cu(4,4′-bpy)(H2O)3(SO4)]·2H2O (3) and [Cu(bpe)(H2O)(SO4)] (4) (bpe=trans-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene),  both consisting of linear cationic chains with SO4

2− anions as either spacers or cross-linkers between the chains. If a chiral ligand is used, noncentrosymmetric crystal packing can also be generated as in the case of [Zn(sala)]
n
 (5; H2sala=N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-alanine) and [Zn(sala)(H2O)2]2·2H2O (6) . It should be noted that all these coordination polymers could also display second-order NLO effects. The crystallization of 1, 3 and 4 in the noncentrosymmetric space groups seems to represent a useful way of influencing acentricity in the structure, i.e. in analogy to organic polymer chemistry, a coordinating anion can be used as a cross-linking agent to increase dimensionality and structural complexity. This may open up a new avenue to a potentially large class of second-order nonlinear optical materials.

In general, self-assembly reaction by varying distinct synthetic approaches could result in kinetic or thermodynamic products, respectively, which may be readily interconvertible . CPs 1 and 2 can be obtained from solvothermal and layered diffusion methods, respectively, and thus supposed to be kinetic and thermodynamic products . In order to study the structural transformation behaviors between 1 and 2, we dipped 1 into CH3OH-H2O solution under ambient stirring or placed 2 into Teflon-lined autoclave under solvothermal condition. On one hand, 1 can transform to 2 at ambient stirring condition after one day, as determined by PXRD patterns (a). During this process, the shapes of crystals kept intact, but SC-XRD studies could not be performed despite repeated attempts, due to weak diffraction. On the other hand, transformation from 2 to 1 cannot be achieved only by dipping 2 into solution upon heating. If placing crystals of 2 in solution under solvothermal condition, white powders are generated which are proved to be 1 through PXRD patterns (b). However, the detailed mechanism of such process cannot be determined due to the black-box effect of solvothermal reaction.

3− (1) and HPO4
2− (2)). The structures are characterized by the incorporation of metal cluster secondary building units (SBU). The structure of 1 features a variant of the common {M3(μ3-O)} sbu with the central bridging ligand provided by a phosphate oxygen rather than the more common oxo- or hydroxy-ligand. All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23mL poly-(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. Results and discussionsSynthesesCompounds were synthesized using conventional hydrothermal methods, which are routinely applied in the isolation of organic–inorganic composite materials. At these temperature ranges, typically 120–250°C, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases, exploiting the self assembly of products from these soluble precursors . Under these crystallization conditions, problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, allowing for introduction of a variety of different organic and/or inorganic precursors, as well as organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents. Such conditions may also allow for the isolation of kinetic rather than thermodynamically favored products.

IntroductionRecently, great effort has been devoted to the self-assembly of organic and inorganic molecules in the solid state because it extends the range of new solids with desirable physical and chemical properties . The range and variety of self-assembled inorganic structures that can be constructed relies on suitable metal–ligand interactions and hydrogen bondings, and the various types of polymeric structures include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures . Chiral coordination polymers containing nicotinate ligands , which display optical properties , were the subject of several studies during recent years. Despite some recent progress for the synthesis of chiral coordination polymers, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of these molecules remains an elusive goal, and much more work is required to understand the effects of the metal center and ligand on the patterns of the molecular structure in the solid state. During our investigation on the reactions of transition metal (II) complexes with nicotinic acid, we have obtained two chiral polymeric complexes which show 3-D and 2-D framework structures. The syntheses and crystal structures of Cu(nic)2(H2O)·CH3OH (nic=nicotinate) (1), and Co(nic)2
·H2O (2), form the subject of this report.

Complexes 1 and 2 make interesting comparisons with the mononuclear complexes Cu(nic)2(H2O)4 and Co(nic)2(H2O)4
 and the three-dimensional Cu(II) coordination polymer Cu(nic)2
. The complexes Cu(nic)2(H2O)4 and Co(nic)2(H2O)4 were prepared by the reactions of CuCl2
·2H2O and CoCl2
·6H2O, respectively, with nicotinic acid in NaOH solution (pH=6) at 60 °C. The coordination spheres of these two mononuclear complexes are octahedral, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial positions and two aqua oxygen atoms in the axial positions. The complex Cu(nic)2 was synthesized by treating copper nitrate with nicotinic acid under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, and the Cu(II) centers adopt a coordination geometry intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal. The tridentate nicotinate groups (with bridging carboxylate) link doubly carboxylate bridged Cu(II) dimers into a pleated-sheet structure through the coordination of their pyridyl nitrogen atoms, while the bidentate nicotinate groups link adjacent Cu centers to form zigzag chains along the a-axis and thus cross-link the pleated sheets formed by the Cu centers and tridentate nicotinate groups to result in a complex 3-D framework structure . A complex of the same formula of Cu(nic)2 has also been prepared by reacting Cu(NO3)2
·2.5H2O with nicotinic acid in the mole ratio of 2:1 for three days at 170 °C under hydrothermal conditions .

IntroductionThe synthesis of Porous Metal–Organic Frameworks (PMOFs) has gained much attention in recent years because of a variety of regulated and interesting structural topologies and many-potential applications . The successful preparation of porous materials is mainly dependent on the self assembly of metal ions and multi-dentate linkers with specific coordination geometry. The self-assembly process has been affected by many factors, involving coordination modes, the nature of linkers and reaction conditions . In fact, the key to synthesize these porous materials is the careful design of organic linkers. The nature of organic linkers can directly affect the structure diversity and properties of these materials due to the difference in the size, the flexibility, positions of functional groups and coordination modes to various metal ions . To date, extensive research efforts have been focused on the preparation of new organic linkers and their use in the assembly of new coordination polymers. However, the combination study on positional isomeric effect of organic linkers and the diversity of structure in these solids is of great importance in understanding the relationship between their structure and intrinsic properties.

AbstractMetal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new sort of crystalline materials, have attracted lots of interest in many applications during the past decades. Recently, many efforts have been focused on the development of MOFs as heterogeneous catalysis. In this communication, we selected adenine (ad) and tetracarboxylic acid, namely 5,5′-(1,3,6,8-tetraoxobenzo[Imn] Li et al. (1999), He et al. (2016) phenanthroline-2,7-diyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H4L), as organic linkers to assemble with Zn(II) ions to construct a novel adenine-based porous MOF. There are three different inorganic clusters in the framework, including ZnO2N2, Zn2O2N6, and ZnO5N clusters. Interesting, the resultant porous MOF, namely [H2N(CH3)2]⋅[Zn4(L)1.5(ad)3(H2O)2]⋅4DMF, retains free amino groups in the framework, which can be served as Lewis basic sites to catalyse Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The catalytic study exhibits that the as-synthesized MOF with free amino groups can be used as heterogeneous catalysis with remarkable catalytic efforts and good recycle.

A novel adenine-based MOF has been obtained by mixing ligands.The resultant MOF retains free amino groups in the framework,It can be used as heterogeneous catalysis for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction.Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) , as a burgeoning sort of crystalline materials, have attracted lots of interest in the past decades, not only due to their diverse structures, but also because of their widely potential applications, including magnetism , gas sorption , drug delivery , chemical sensor , optical device , and heterogeneous catalysis 
etc. To date, lots of structures have been successfully prepared through different ligands, metal ions, and synthetic conditions. From the previous investigations, most of organic ligands in MOFs are multicarboxylic acids. Nevertheless, more and more scientists pay attention to the aromatic N-heterocycles, such as adenine, imidazole, triazole, and tetrazolate, because they are able to generate lots of interesting structures and unique properties . Particularly, adenine can be mixed with multicarboxylic acid ligands to prepare many available materials, such as bio-MOFs in Rosi's group . However, only two previous researches have been reported to obtain adenine-based porous MOFs by mixing adenine and tetracarboxylic acid ligands . Therefore, it remains a significant challenge to develop and synthesize such adenine-based MOFs.

AbstractLarge cadmium chalcogenido clusters C2 (Cd32) and C1 (Cd17) CdQ (Q = S, Se) with photoactive dye cations [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ are prepared under solvothermal conditions (Phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine). All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures, while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd17 clusters. Two of the 3-D C2 clusters can be considered as homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (2.0 nm radius) with Cd4Se10 core. Charge-transfer interaction is found between [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cations and CdQ cluster anions. The photocurrent behaviors indicate that (1) the current intensities are greatly increased for the dye cation functionalized Cn clusters, (2) the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, and (3) the current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters.

Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurementAll the solvents used in electrochemical measurements were dried by a standard method and distilled before use, or the chromatographically pure reagent. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed on a CHI650 electrochemistry workstation, using a three-electrode system with a Pt plate working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode (in CH3CN with 0.1 mol L−1 Bu4NClO4). The photocurrent experiments were performed using a quartz cell equipped with the sample coated ITO glass working electrode, a Pt plate auxiliary electrode and a SCE reference electrode, An aqueous solution of Na2SO3 (100 mL, 0.1 mol L−1) was used as the medium in a quartz cell. The photoelectrodes of the compounds were prepared by powder coating method. As a typical procedure, the crystals of compounds (0.005 mmol) were ground and pressed uniformly on an ITO glass (100 Ω/□) with 0.785 cm2 effective area (Ø 1.0 cm). A 150 W high pressure xenon lamp, positioned 15 cm away the surface of the ITO electrode, was employed as a light source. The lamp was kept on continuously, and a manual shutter was used to block exposure of the electrode to the light. The electrode was typically irradiated over 0−400 s with interval 20 s. The applied voltage is 0.0 V for photocurrent measurements. Band-pass filters (380, 400, and 420 nm) were used to cut part or all of the UV light for the study of the effect of wavelength.

Results and discussionSynthesis and characterizationAll materials reported here were synthesized under solvothermal conditions from the Cd(SPh)2 and [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]Br2. The S(-II) and Se(-II) sources were thiourea and selenourea, respectively. The reaction temperatures and solvents for the synthesis of C2 clusters were different from those for the synthesis of C1 clusters. In general, high condensed phase is obtained at high temperature and high volume ratio of the acetonitrile/H2O (modifying the solubility of the clusters). To be specific, the C1 cluster was obtained from the mixed solvent of acetonitrile/H2O (3:1 in volume) at 85 °C, while pure acetonitrile and 110 °C were suitable for the growth of C2 crystals. The optimized conditions of crystallization of these compounds are described in experimental section. The anion structures of all the six compounds were accurately characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Because there are too many heavy atoms in the large clusters (the largest volume of the cell is about 130 thousands) and the serious disorder of the organic moieties, the cations are not completely solved. The [Ru(Phen/bpy)3]2+ cations or Ru2+ (fragment) are found in all the structures of the compounds. The cations have been further characterized by spectra (460 nm MLCT band of [Ru(Phen/Bpy)3]2+ cation) and electrospray mass spectrum analysis (m/z: 321.25, ).  shows the TEM images of the aggregated nanoclusters. X-ray data collection and structure determinationsSuitable X-ray single crystals diffraction data of 1–6 were selected and mounted on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). ConclusionsIn this work, a series of coordination polymers based on equatorial 2D (4,4) layers have been successfully synthesized from reactions of the bib ligand with six kinds of manganese salts. Owing to the diversities on the coordination affinity of counterions, the equatorial 2D layers are further bridged by different linkers to form a 3D homoleptic α-Po framework (1), unchanged 2D (4,4) layer (2–5) and 3D heteroleptic α-Po framework, respectively. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, parallel and incline interpenetration is exhibited in 2 and 3, respectively, which shows that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, different porosity of 4 and 5 reveals that the large counterion is beneficial to porous coordination polymers. Moreover, magnetic studies display that weak ferromagnetic coupling is conducted by the μ2-SO4
2− ion within the 1D SO4
2−–Mn2+ chain of 6.

AbstractTwo novel Cu-based coordination polymers [Cu5(HPyImDC)4]·(NH4)3 (1) and [Cu3(H2O)2(HPyImDC)2(C3N2H10)] (2) containing the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H3PyImDC) ligand have been solvothermally synthesized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 exhibits a three dimensional framework with 1D rhombic channels, which can be simplified into a novel (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (62.144)(62.8)4. Compound 2 is one dimensional chain which packed with each other via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct a three dimensional supramolecular structure. As the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H3PyImDC ligands, compounds 1 and 2 are further studied by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analyses.

The experimental and theoretical efforts have recently been focused on the rational design and controlled synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) due to not only their potential applications but also their intriguing versatile architectures . One of the most effective ways is the appropriate choice of well-designed molecular building blocks (MBB) and metal ions or clusters to achieve the targeting assemblies of such extended crystalline systems with desired structural features and/or physicochemical properties . Although MBBs with 2-fold linear , 3-fold  and 4-fold  symmetries are popular choices for obtaining the well-defined MOFs, 2-fold non-linear MBB is rarely studied. This lies in two aspects: bigger steric hindrance and necessity of the auxiliary ligand known as pillar to sustain the architecture . Compared with BDC , non-linear FDA possesses two advantages as the MBB: the high openness net with the flexible bond angle of two carboxyl (~126°) and the polarity owing to the oxygen atom of ring, which is potentially applied for gas-storage and gas-separation. Due to the non-linear FDA as the MBB, the choice of the pillar would effect the structural formations — porosity and interpenetration. With respect to the steric hindrance and electronic effect, the flexible and rigid pillars are employed to the construction of structure, respectively. In this work, two novel MOFs have been synthesized, in which the flexible bpp results in the robust porous [Zn3·(FDA)3·bpp·H2O]·2H2O (1), and the rigid bipy in 3-/3-D interpenetrated [Zn·(FDA)·bipy]·2H2O (2).

When the reactions were performed in the absence of Na2TeO3, nothing could be obtained except for some yellow precipitation, likely corresponding to complexes of VV. Consequently, it appears that Na2TeO3 exerts the role of reducer for VV. Taking into account the characteristic comparability of identical group elements, we replaced Na2TeO3 with an equal amount of Na2SO3 or Na2SeO3 in the reaction system. When Na2SO3 was used, compounds 1–5 cannot be obtained. However, compounds 1–5 could be obtained when Na2SeO3 was used instead of Na2TeO3, but at a cost of the yield and crystal quality of these compounds. It can be concluded that the reductive ability of Na2TeO3 and Na2SeO3 are comparative and both are weaker than that of Na2SO3, which indicates that weak reducer is propitious to the formation of 1–5. These results prompted us to choose structurally similar ligands that could engage in multiple, simultaneous coordination modes and to use such ligands in the assembly of novel coordination polymers. We identified 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxate (pytac) (
) as one ligand of suitable length and have begun to use it in the preparation of new coordination frameworks . This ligand is similar to pca and ppca in that there exists a terminal and a chelating nitrogen coordination site that can be used for coordinating to metal centers. However, while in the case of pca and ppca the coordination sites are in a linear arrangement with respect to each other, in the case of pytac, the chelating nitrogen is no longer exactly opposite the terminal nitrogen, but rather is oriented approximately perpendicular to it. This spatial arrangement of the nitrogens enables the ligand to function as a ‘bent’ spacer . The ‘bent’ orientation of the ligand's N-donor atoms, as well as the presence of an additional Lewis base site in the form of a ring-sulfur atom, lead us to believe that the use of this ligand could yield equally, if not more, diverse structures compared to those containing the pca or ppca ligands. In this paper we report on our continued results with the use of this ligand that has yielded three new structures: two single-metal coordination polymers 1 and 3, and a mixed-metal coordination polymer 2. Their syntheses and structures are detailed within.

SynthesisSynthesis of 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H4L)5-hydroxy-isophthalic acid diethyl ester (2.38g, 10mmol) and anhydrous K2CO3 (3g, 22mmol) were put in a 50mL round bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere and treated with 20mL of dry DMF. Finally, the resulting solution was poured into ice-water (100mL) with vigorous stirring and was acidified carefully with 4M HCl to obtain a white precipitate. After keeping it overnight in the freezer, the white solid was collected by filtration and dried at air. Yield: 2.02g (96%). IntroductionIn the past decade, the study on the design and synthesis of novel cluster polymers achieved considerable attention due to the structural unpredictability (i.e., which cluster will form and what is the linking mode between the clusters and organic moieties) and potential functional properties in some fields as optics (containing groups IB, IIB or rare-earth metal), electrochemistry based on the metals with many oxidation states, catalysis (poly-acid, zeolite or zeolite-like materials), electrical conductivity (containing group IVA metal) and magnetism . As far as the construction of cluster polymers is concerned, on the one hand, the inorganic salts being prone to form the clusters, such as oxides, halides or sulfides are usually used as the inorganic precursors to form inorganic subunits (SUs) . On the other hand, the literature show that three types of bridges can extend the inorganic SUs into poly-nuclear or high-dimensional (D) cluster polymers: (i) inorganic bridge. With various organic ammines as guest species or organic templating agents, the SUs interact with each other through covalent M–O (X or S) bonds (or through sharing the corner, edge or/and face) between the SUs, producing new polymeric clusters. This is the basic constructing conception of zeolite and zeolite-like materials . (ii) Organic bridge, the most common method. Up to now, lots of bridging organic ligands with N/O/S donors have been chosen to extend the SUs into the 1-D, 2-D, 3-D cluster polymers via covalent interactions or a combination of covalent and non-covalent interactions . (iii) Metal complex bridge. This strategy has been extensively adopted when preparing high-D poly-acids . Some recent reports show that it is being extended to the construction of metal–halo cluster polymers .

Compared with the Ni(II), the structure of copper–halo clusters is richer due to the diversity of coordination geometry of Cu(I). With bridging N-donor ligands, CuX can form various neutral oligomeric and polymeric clusters, namely so-called SUs. The most reports are rhombic dimer, cubane tetramer, zigzag-type and staircase chains . Further, these SUs are extended by organic bridges into the 1-D, 2-D or 3-D networks. It was reported that the size of organic ligands determines the mode of the SUs. In general, the bulky ligands as 4,4′-bpy favor the formation of discrete SUs, whereas the small ones favor the polymeric SUs. In compound [Cu2Br2(tri)] (tri=1,3,5-triazine) , the castellated CuI single chain was reported, while in compound 2, a new castellated CuI double chain was observed in reaction with the pip.

Compound 3 is a twofold interpenetrated three-dimensional framework with free water molecules as space fillers. As shown in 
, each CdII center is in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry. Two chelating carboxylate groups from different OH-BDC ligands and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from a bpp ligand comprise the equatorial basal plane, one water molecule and one pyridyl nitrogen atom from the other bpp ligand occupy the apical sites [OW1–Cd–N1 168.5(2)°]. The chains are further connected by azpy bridges to yield a ladder-type one-dimensional structure, as shown in b, in which the Zn\u2013oba chains construct the \u201cside rails\u201d, and the Zn\u2013azpy\u2013Zn parts construct the \u201crungs\u201d of the ladder framework. The Zn\u22efZn distances bridged by the oba and azpy groups are 14.1\u00c5 and 13.1\u00c5, respectively, which form large cavities with an effective area of about 12\u00d711\u00c52. The cavities in the framework exhibit a compressed octahedral structure at the apexes of the four zinc atoms and two ether\u2013oxygen atoms. The coordinating dmf molecules protrude in the same direction as the corresponding side rail.

(a) {[Co  3  (DMF)  12  ][W(CN)  8  ]  2  } ∞  (1). X-ray crystallographic studies revealed that complex 1 is a neutral, one-dimensional infinite chainlike polymer. The asymmetric unit of the structure consists of one WV(CN)8 3- moiety connected to two different types of CoII centers by cyanide bridges. The W1 atom is coordinated by eight CN groups, with W-C distances ranging from 2.140(5) to 2.175(4) Å in a distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The two Co atoms are all in a slightly distorted octahedral geometry. The equatorial sites of Co1 are occupied by two oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms (O1, O3, N5, and N6 i  ; i = -x + 1, -y + 2, -z + 1), and the apical positions are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O2, O4) from DMF molecules. The other Co atom (Co2), localized at the special equivalent positions (1, 1/2, 0), is coordinated with four oxygen atoms (O5, O6, O5 ii  , and O5 ii  ) from four DMF molecules occupying the equatorial sites and two nitrogen atoms (N2, N2 ii  ) from two adjacent W(CN)8 units at the axial positions (ii = -x + 2, -y + 1, -z). Each WV(CN)8 group connects three Co atoms (Co1, Co1 i  , and Co1 ii  ) via three cyano bridges (C5-N5, C6-N6, and C2-N2) with the Co-NCN distance ranging from 2.096(3) to 2.131(3) Å. W1, Co1, W1 i  , and Co1 i   were joined by four cyano bridges (C5-N5, C6 i   -N6 i  , C5 i   -N5 i  , and C6-N6) to form a 4-metal 12-atom rhombic cycle, Co2W2(CN)4, while Co2 links the cycles in a trans mode through W1-C2-N2-Co2-N2 ii   -C2 i   -W1 ii   linkages to form a 1-D infinite chain, running along one of the diagonal directions of the b and c axes (Figures a and ). This type of 1-D chain has been defined as a 3,2-chain by Černák et al., which has been found in complexes {(DMF)10Ln2[ Ni(CN)4]3}∞ (Ln = Sm, Yb, Er). In complex 1, the shortest metal⋅⋅⋅metal intrachain distances for W1⋅⋅⋅Co1, W1⋅⋅⋅Co2, Co1⋅⋅⋅Co2, W1⋅⋅⋅W1 i  , and Co1⋅⋅⋅Co1 i   are 5.335(1), 5.363(1), 10.252(2), 8.443(1), and 6.491(2) Å, respectively. The adjacent chains are separated well by the coordinated DMF molecules, with a distance of 11.690(3) Å along the a axis (Figure ). No pronounced hydrogen-bonding interaction, except the van der Waals force between the chains, can be found.

Even harmonics can be observed only if a system exhibits a spontaneous magnetization, due to the lack of inversion symmetry with respect to the applied field. Only odd harmonics are expected for a spin glass, while for ferromagnets both even and odd harmonics should be present. The second harmonics (2f responses) for complex 1 have sharp peaks (Figure ), which indicates that a spontaneous moment is formed at that transition (ca. 7.3 K) while the frequency dependence of both components of the nonlinear  susceptibility suggests slow relaxation processes and glassiness. Nonzero values of χ3‘ (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information) could be attributed to the irreversible domain-wall motion. Thus, complex 1 should be a long-range-ordering ferromagnet, but with some glassy behavior or possible related blocking of the domain wall.

The reaction of 1 with elemental sulfur in THF at ambient temperature for 2 days smoothly afforded [{PhC(NtBu)2}2Ge2(μ-S)2Cl2] (2) in moderate yield (0.18 g, 44%) (Scheme ). The isolation of a compound with a terminal >GeS moiety is probably due to the reactivity of the >GeS unit, which can be assumed as an intermediate, that rapidly undergoes a [2 + 2] cycloaddition to yield 2. Yellow crystals of 2 were obtained from a THF solution at -32 °C. The 1H NMR spectrum of 2 shows a singlet at δ 1.18 ppm for the 36 protons of the four tBu groups and a multiplet resonance for the 10 aromatic protons (δ 6.86-7.26 ppm). The tBu protons resonance in 2 exhibits a small downfield shift in comparison with that of the precursor 1 (1 δ 1.08 ppm for tBu protons). The most abundant peak in the EI-MS spectrum of 2 appeared with the highest relative intensity at m/z 371, which corresponds to the half-fragment of 2. To understand the bonding situation of 2, it was structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies.

Thus, in our continuous search toward molecule-based magnets, we select 2,4,6-tris(2-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tptz) as a coligand and observe the behavior of this particular ligand over a Mn-azide system. Here in this paper, we present the synthesis and characterization of a new polymeric Mn-azide complex, [Mn(tptz)(μ1,1-N3)2] n  (1), which is characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and low-temperature magnetic studies. Here each MnII is seven-coordinated and is connected to one another by a double EO bridging azide ligand, forming a 1D chain. The adjacent 1D chains are connected by face-to-face π-π-stacking interactions and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions of the pyridine rings of the tptz ligand, which leads to the formation of a supramolecular 2D sheet. Variable-temperature magnetic measurement exhibits intrachain ferromagnetic interactions and interchain antiferromagnetic interactions with the overall metamagnetic behavior having 3D magnetic ordering at 2.7 K.

The ferromagnetic coupling was confirmed by magnetization measurements performed at 2 K up to an external field of 5 T showing the typical behavior of a soft ferromagnet because coercivity was not observed (Figure b). At higher field, the magnetization in M/Nβ units indicates a saturated S = 5/2 system, 5.18 Nβ. A comparison of the overall shape of the plot with the Brillouin plot for a fully isolated S = 5/2 system indicates faster magnetization, consistent with the ferromagnetic interaction.

This ferromagnetic behavior may be explained by attending to the principal factors that influence the sign of the exchange interaction in the [{μ1,1-N3}2MII] system. The magnetostructural correlation studies have shown a dependence of the ferromagnetic exchange coupling constant (J) on the M-N(azide)-M bridging angle. For Mn, the ferromagnetic exchange appears to increase with an increase of the bridging angle (starting from 100°) involved in the exchange pathway. Very recently, Aromí et al. have deduced from four dinuclear MnII compounds a linear relationship between the exchange integral (J) and the azide bridging angle (θ); J = 0.64θ - 64.5. If this relationship holds for complex 1 [θ = 106.16(4)°], a J value of ca. 3.43 cm-1 is anticipated. The experimental J value (4.07 cm-1) appears to be close to the average among the prospective values using the previous relationship.

To characterize the magnetic transition from intrachain ferromagnetism to interchain antiferromagnetism of 1 in the low-temperature region, field-cooled magnetization was measured under different fields (Figure ). At the lower field of 15, 30, and 50 G, the M vs T curve shows a maximum at ca. 2.7 K (Figure , inset), clearly indicating the occurrence of antiferromagnetic ordering of the ferromagnetic chains below the critical temperature. The magnetization maximum shifts toward low temperature as the applied field is increased to 200, 1000, and 3000 G. However, the magnetization at or above 200 G shows no maximum and tends to saturate at lower temperature, indicating that the interchain antiferromagnetic interactions are overcome by the external field. This behavior is characteristic of a metamagnet built of ferromagnetic chains. The metamagnetic behavior is confirmed by the field dependence of magnetization (Figure ). The sigmoidal shape of the M/Nβ vs H curve at 2 K indicates the field-induced transition from an antiferromagnetic to a ferromagnetic state, which is characteristic of a metamagnet.  The critical field is ~80 G, estimated as the field at which a maximum δM/δ H value is reached (Figure , inset).

The temperature dependence of the ac magnetic susceptibility is also measured at zero dc field and confirms the occurrence of the magnetic transition with T c = 2.7 K, at which the maximum of χ‘ (the in-phase component) occurs. The divergence of χ‘‘ (the out-of-phase component) with the field starts at this temperature (Figure ). This metamagnetic-like transition results from the presence of small antiferromagnetic interactions among the ferromagnetic chains and, in complex 1, can be favored by the heptacoordination of the Mn ions.

Reaction of Cu(I) with L1 and L2 - 3 

Reaction of copper(I) perchlorate with ligand L1 and pyrazine L2 (1:1:1 or 1:1:2 molar ratio) in acetonitrile afforded crystals of 3 suitable for X-ray characterization. The structure of 3 is shown in Figure . It reveals a complex of 2:2:1 stoichiometry containing discrete binuclear subunits of copper(I) bridged by two N 1,N 2-coordinated L1 triazole ligands (SBU). Additionally, the acetonitrile molecule is bound to Cu(I) ion. Consecutive dimers are directly linked by nitrogen atoms of pyrazine L2 resulting in 1D chain coordination polymer of a formula consistent with ∞ 1{[Cu2(μ-L1)2(μ-L2)(CH3CN)2](ClO4)2} (3). The nonbonding distance between two copper atoms of the SBU subunit, equal to 3.644(1) Å, is very close to the value found in 2 (3.685(1) Å). However, in 3 the linkage of the SBU by pyrazine leads to complete flattening of the six-membered cycle defined by two copper and four nitrogen (from L1) atoms. Distance between the copper(I) ions bridged by pyrazine is equal to 6.916(1) Å and approaches the upper limit observed for Cu(I)-pyrazine-Cu(I) (from 6.685 Å to 7.068). This 1D polymer exhibits a zigzag structure with Cu1i-Cu1-N5pyrazine angle equal to 120.3° (i = -x, -y + 1, -z). It is noteworthy that the coordination polymer 3 is the only product of the reaction mentioned above. When a 2-fold excess of L1 was used in the reaction, crystals of 1 were formed.

In conclusion, we have prepared and characterized a new triazole-based [Fe(bntrz)3][Pt(CN)4]⋅H2O (1) salt exhibiting an abrupt spin transition with a transition temperature of ca. 242 K. The cationic [Fe(bntrz)3]2+ complex displays a polymeric chain, similar to that reported for the FeII triazole-based systems exhibiting magnetic bistability around or above room temperature. The present study clearly evidences the starring roles of the ligand substitution and counterion changes to prevail over the implicit crystallogenesis issue in the FeII/trz systems, with the association of bntrz ligand and [Pt(CN)4)]2- anion leading for the first time to robust single crystals of high quality and relatively considerable size (up to 0.45 × 0.04 × 0.04 mm) that withstand the LS/HS first-order spin transition upon repeated SCO cycles. Distinctively from other 1D FeII/trz systems for which the origin of the strong cooperativity remains strictly indefinite because of the lack of structural information, the characteristics of complex 1 led us to single crystal X-ray data collections of high-quality, allowing highly refined structural characterizations of both high and low spin states, and the thermal evolution of the lattice parameters. The polymeric chain structure of 1, crystallographically determined at 296 and 120 K, is built from two different FeII centers for which the average values of the Fe-N distances are in agreement with the complete HS/LS spin transition revealed by the magnetic data. The crystal structures of the LS and HS states definitely confirm the perfect linearity of the chains of such polymeric triazole-based SCO compounds, even in the HS state conversely to what was suggested from the first investigations based on EXAFS and WAXS studies. The thermal variation of the lattice parameters shows anisotropic changes at the transition temperature, and proves that the most pronounced structural changes occur along the 1D covalent chain. The intermolecular interchain contacts occur through hydrogen bonding via the [Pt(CN)4]2- anions leading to an overall 3D arrangement. Although displaying cooperativity, the absence of a wide hysteresis loop in the SCO of 1 reveals that the strong short-range "FeII-(Rtrz)3-FeII" interactions along the chain are not sufficient to drive the existence of long lifetime metastable states at the origin of thermal hysteresis; it also confirms that the overall long-range interactions, with an emphasis on the direct contacts between the chains, should play a crucial role to promote significant elastic strains that stabilizes the spin state changes. The exceptional resilience of the present crystals upon repeated switching cycles is most likely due to the accommodation of the molecular volume and the anisotropic expansion/contraction of the unit cell upon SCO transition, which allows the existence of a mismatch free HS/LS interface resulting from the capability of the "FeII-(Rtrz)" chains to glide from each other and accommodate the structural modifications despite the sharp transition. This observation is similar to that of the spin-crossover single crystals [{Fe(NCSe) (py)2}2(m-bpypz)] (with py = pyridine and bpypz = 3,5-bis(2-pyri-dyl)pyrazolate) recently reported by K. Boukhedadden et al. In this context, we are currently investigating by optical microscopy the response of a single crystal of 1 upon thermal SCO transition in order to visualize the nucleation, the growth, and the propagation of HS and LS domains accompanying the first-order transition. The observation of the orientation and the dynamics of the HS/LS interface should allow for a better understanding of the role of the anisotropic changes of the lattice parameters on the exceptional resilience of this material. On the other hand, we are also currently exploring other systems exhibiting similar chain, but with different crystal packing to enhance/control the interchain interactions and produce hysteretic features. In fine, the aim is to establish thorough and systematic magneto-structural correlations that are essential to understand the physicochemical origin of the strong cooperativity in such striking materials, and also to rationalize the tuning of the SCO properties.

Magnetic Properties. No X-band EPR signals could be observed on a powdered sample of 1 at either 77 K or room temperature. These data are indicative of strong coupling between the two copper centers in the solid state. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data for 1 were collected over the temperature range 10-300 K. The shape of the χm vs T plot for 1 shows a maximum at 150 K indicative of antiferromagnetically coupled Cu(II) centers. Simulation of the data using a spin-exchange Hamiltonian, H = -2JS 1⋅S 2, where S 1 = S 2 = 1/2 gives -2J = 168 cm-1 consistent with the lack of an observable EPR signal for a solid sample of 1. The exchange coupling in 1 is due to the fact that the μ-phenoxo oxygen bond is equatorial to both Cu2 and Cu1. In dinuclear square pyramidal Cu(II) complexes of this type, the unpaired electron resides in the d x   2  -  y   2  orbital. This coordination mode provides significant orbital overlap between the magnetic orbital d x   2  -  y   2  of Cu2 with the magnetic orbital d x   2  -  y   2  of Cu1 so exchange coupling occurs.

The solution spectrum of 1 at room temperature (Figure ) displays an isotropic signal with g = 2.128 and A = 6.87 mT. Lowering the temperature to 77 K provided an essentially axial EPR signal which was simulated using an S = 1/2 spin Hamiltonian, and the resulting fit provided g  x , g  y , and g  z  values of 2.097, 2.116, and 2.323, respectively, and an A  z (63Cu) = 16.2 mT (Figure ). The X-band EPR spectra of a methanolic solution of 1 at 77 K also reveals a ΔM s = 2 transition at g = 4.5 (Figure ). The temperature dependence of all of the observed signals between 4 and 70 K exhibited Curie law behavior. These data suggest that the two Cu(II) ions in 1 are either weakly ferromagnetically or antiferromagnetically coupled in solution, similar to met-hemocyanin. Computer simulation of the g ~ 2 signal does not match the experimental spectrum  exactly in that the intensities of some features are not reproduced accurately, even though the resonance positions are precisely duplicated. There are two phenomena that likely account for this. The first is the presence of an underlying ΔM s = 2 transition that is predicted from the observation of its high-field partner (note the very broad absorption centered at 4250 G) (Figure ). The second phenomenon is that, in conjunction with the ΔM s = 2 transition, off-axis extrema will occur in the EPR spectrum and lead to increased EPR absorption at field values other than those at which the principal g-values occur. However, double integration of the g ~ 2 signal reveals that this signal accounts for only ~3% of the spins in the sample.
