Conclusion

Three new cobalt(III) and copper(II) complexes, formulated as [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1), [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)].ClO4 (2) and [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3) have been synthesised with the tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1Z,3E)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol= LH] and azide ions. Interestingly, 2 is the first dinuclear copper(II) square planar complex with a tridentate Schiff base and a single μ1,3-azido bridge. Another intriguing fact in this complex is the presence of a very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (J =-252(1)cm-1) through the single μ1,3-azido bridge. This value is more than twice the highest value reported to date for a double μ1,3-azido bridged copper(II)-dinuclear compound (J =-105cm-1) . Last, but not the least, the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the 1-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase and 2 have shown to have reasonably good catalase activity.

For 1 single crystal X-ray analysis shows that the asymmetrical structure unit of 1 contains one crystallographic independent PbII ion (Pb1), one μ 1,1-(N)CS bridges, one de-protonated L and one terminal coordinated water molecule (O3). As shown in  , Pb1 is in the hemi-directed geometry and seven-coordinated by one water molecule (O3), two bridged μ 1,1-(N)CS nitrogen atoms (N4 and N4A), two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) and two triazole atoms (N1 and N2) forming a quite distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry. The Pb(II) coordination geometry has close relationship with the 6s electrons. The stereo-chemical active 6s electrons of Pb usually produce hemi-directed coordination geometry, however, the difference between hemi-directed and holo-directed geometry around Pb(II) is ambiguous sometimes . With the extending of bonding limit, the potential ligands, which are a little far from Pb(II) center due to the repulsion of the 6s electrons, will be found and the hemi-directed coordination sphere will be completed to holo-directed. For 1 the hemi-directed geometries of Pb1 also can be extended by weak Pb⋅⋅⋅S interactions (Pb(1)-S(1), 3.292(2)Å) into holo-directed geometries. The carboxylic acid group of HL is de-protonated, N2, N3, O1 and O2 of L are involved in the coordination of two central lead(II) ions (Pb1 and Pb1A) forming tetra-dentate coordination modes. The result is also different form previously reported bi-dentate chelate coordination modes . All the bond distances and angles are listed in the , all the Pb-O and Pb-N bond distances are below 2.8Å, such bond distances are reasonable and can find a nearly ideal value assumed for oxidation state II on the PbII ions. The five-membered triazole ring is almost coplanar with mean deviation of 0.0014(3)Å.

The aldol reaction is also a key carboncarbon bond-formingreaction in nature and repertoire of the synthetic chemist []. Enamine catalysis is commonly used in electrophilic α-substitution reactions of ketones and aldehydes []. The chiral POMOFs NH2-Co-PYIs were assessed as catalyst for the asymmetric aldol reactions between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone in DMSO or CH3OH/ H2O at room temperature. As listed in   (see SⅡ for additional information), the corresponding catalytic and enantioselective activities varied significantly with different aldehydes. The reactions catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYIs in DMSO media produced aldol products in general yields (60-75%) and with fair to good enantioselectivity for anti-isomers (enantiomeric excess (ee), 48-63%). As is expected, a chirality induction effect was observed in the reaction between various aromatic aldehydes and cyclohexanone employed in DMSO. Thus, NH2-Co-PYIs represent the first examples of POM-based heterogeneous asymmetric catalysts for this important reaction, providing a convenient route to aldol reaction. To investigate the influence of the solvent, we employed the reactions in CH3OH/H2O media (1:1 ratio). Although the conversion is low, the higher diastereo-selectivity (>98%) and excellent enantioselectivity were obtained, especially, up to 89.15% for the 2-(Hydroxy-(4-nitrophenyl)methyl)-cyclohexan-1-one catalyzed by NH2-Co-PYI1. It's worth noting that catalyst NH2-Co-PYIs in CH3OH/H2O media always exhibited excellent specificity for the syn conformation of the product corresponding to the aldol reactions of the nitrobenzaldehydes rather than the anti conformation reported in previous literatures []. (Table S1) In NH2-Co-PYI1, the co-existence of imine as Lewis base and exposed Co2+ ions as Lewis acid catalytic sites within one framework will enhanced the activity of the enamine in aldol reaction and avoid the side reactions, such as self-aldolization. A control experiment with free PYI in a homogeneous manner suggested the yield and enantioselectivity are lower than that in the heterogeneous catalyst.

In our investigation of the photocatalytic properties ( ), the amount of 1ZnMOF, P25, TiO2, and loaded catalyst was 60mg. The concentration of methylene blue was 12ppm. Apparently, the 1ZnMOF exhibits no apparently photocatalytic activity toward methylene blue. The degradation rate of the TiO2 prepared in our lab was only 17%. When the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio of TiO2@1ZnMOF was 1:6, the degradation rate was 14%, which was lower than that of TiO2 alone because of the lower content of TiO2. While the content of TiO2 in the loaded catalysts was 25%, the degradation rate reached 43%. Remarkably, we achieved a degradation rate of 64% when the TiO2/1ZnMOF mass ratio was 2:3. Compared with the P25, whose degradation rate was 31%, the loaded and compound catalysts exhibit better photocatalytic efficiency. Based on a related paper , the mechanism for catalytic degradation of methylene blue is proposed as follows: methylene blue molecules adsorb on the surface of TiO2 and contact the TiO2 nanoparticles directly, which induces surface lattice distortion in a region of several atom layers because of lattice matching in order to provide a key intermediate state during photocatalyzing; then, the distorted lattice atoms absorb photons and tend to recover, which induces a kind of surface lattice driving force by light, and the absorption of photons can increase the lattice energy of TiO2 causing the distorted lattice atoms to recover. This surface latticed driving force can cut the molecule bond and result in the degradation of methylene blue; the distorted lattice is recovered along with the degradation of methylene blue molecules. Thus, in the photocatalytic process, TiO2 can be visualized as a lattice engine based on the variation distortion …recovery…distortion…recovery...of the lattice , which leads to the degradation of organic molecules. In our work, the 1ZnMOF is soaked in the solution of tetrabutyl titanate solved in anhydrous ethanol, a thin layer of tetrabutyl titanate was formed on the surface of the 1ZnMOF microspheres. After the deionized water was dropped onto the soaked 1ZnMOF, the microspheres were loaded with and even coating of TiO2 nanoparticles. The loaded catalysts exhibited improved photocatalytic efficiency compared to P25 and the TiO2 prepared in our lab. One possible mechanism of TiO2@1ZnMOF enhancing the catalytic degradation of methylene blue is TiO2 coating 1ZnMOF to disperse small TiO2 particles and increase its surface area, which is conducive to the photocatalytic reaction (TiO2@1ZnMOF in Fig. S14) compared with pure TiO2 particles that can easily form block product. In contrast, MOFs usually provide a rigid scaffold and possess chromophoric sensitizers serving as a "lantern," which results in the transformation of a large number of photons per unit volume from MOFs to TiO2, thus increasing the quantity of absorbed photons and enhancing the photocatalytic effect.

The main findings of this structural study reflect the stability of the strong-to-medium hydrogen bond in the title compound under multiple temperature conditions. No significant difference is seen in the hydrogen bond geometry as the temperature is increased, and importantly the position and shape of the difference Fourier peak does not change ()-these Fourier images are known to be a sensitive indicator of any anomalous behaviour. In addition, there is no evidence for disorder of the hydrogen atom in the room temperature data, where this effect would be likely to be greatest. Full anisotropic refinement of the hydrogen atoms was possible with the low temperature neutron data, giving O-H bond lengths of 1.075(15) and 1.057(12)Å at 30 and 100K, respectively. Refinement of the fractional coordinates and an isotropic displacement parameter was possible for H1 for the X-ray data, giving O-H bond lengths of 0.81(3) and 0.77(3)Å at 100 and 300K, respectively. The shortening of the X-ray bond lengths with respect to those determined in the neutron experiment is the usual effect of observing the electron density rather than the nuclear position. The fact that the neutron bond lengths do not increase with temperature reflects the invariance of this hydrogen bond, and the slight elongation of these with respect to the expected covalent O-H distance of around 1Å reflects the relatively short, strong nature of this hydrogen bond. The bond lengths determined are all in agreement with the positions of the highest difference Fourier peaks.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  shows that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P-1, and the basic structural unit consists of the cationic lanthanide-organic hybrid chain [Dy(HL)(L)1.5(H2O)3]4+, the Keggin-type polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4-, and eight lattice water molecules (Fig. S1 and Fig. S2). In the cationic dysprosium-organic chain of 1, each Dy3+ ion adopts an octa-coordinated environment with five oxygen atoms derived from the carboxylate groups of three different L ligands and three coordinated water molecules ( ). The bond distances of DyO are in the range of 2.230(17)-2.592(14) Å and the ODyO bond angles vary from 52.1(5)° to 159.6(7)°. It is interesting that the L ligands can be regarded as three different types labeled with La, Lb and Lc as shown in b. Although each carboxylate group on the La and Lb ligands displays a monodentate coordination mode with one Dy center, La and Lb ligands exhibit two different configurations, that is, the La ligand adopts cis-configuration and the Lb ligand possesses trans-configuration (a and b). For Lc ligand, one carboxylate group exhibits a bidentate coordination mode with one Dy center and the other carboxylate group is protonated (a and b). Based on above coordination mode, each Dy1 atom connects Dy2 atom via two La ligands to form a cyclic-like unit (a and c). Furthermore, the Dy1 atom on each circle unit links the Dy2 atom on the other cyclic unit via the linear Lb ligand to form an infinite 1D chain. Moreover, each Dy center also connects one semi-cyclic-like Lc ligand (a and c). Such a structural feature just looks like a "train" with many semi-open cavities that can carry "guest" polyoxoanions (c).

The polyoxoanion [PMo11VO40]4- shows interesting reversible multi-electron redox processes . Thus, it is interesting to explore its electrochemical behaviors and changes when such multi-electron carrier is encapsulated into the cationic metal-organic open frameworks. Herein, the electrochemical behaviors of compound 1were investigated with the 1-modified carbon paste electrodes (1-CPE) because of its very low solubility in water and common organic solvents. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements of 1-CPE at different scan rates were measured in the potential range from +800 to -150mV in 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 (a). As shown in a, four pairs of reversible redox peaks of 1-CPE appear in the range of +800 to -150mV, and the mean peak potentials ( E  1/2 =(E cp +  E  ap)/2) are 502, 363,221 and -25mV with the scan rate of 100mV/s (Fig. S5). The reversible peak I-I' is attributable to a one-electron redox process of V center and the reversible peaks II-II', III-III' and IV-IV' correspond to a two-, four-, and six-electron redox process of Mo centers, respectively . The peak currents are proportional to the scan rate up to 200mV/s, indicating that the redox process of 1-CPE is surface-controlled (a inset).

In the electrochemical studies of POM-based hybrid materials, one of the most interesting works is to discover their potential electrocatalytic properties, since many of them can be potentially good electrocatalysts to reduce the polluting substances in water such as iodate, nitrite and hydrogen peroxide . Especially when the POMs are combined into the metal-organic frameworks, they can not only avoid the partial loss in organic and/or aqueous media but also retain the electrocatalytic activity, representing one type of ideal electrocatalysts. The electrocatalytic properties of 1-CPEs were studied toward the reduction of nitrite in an aqueous solution. At 1-CPE in a 0.5M H2SO4 +0.1 Na2SO4 aqueous solution, the CV for the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrite is shown in b. With the addition of nitrite solution, all reduction peak currents increased while the corresponding oxidation peak currents markedly decreased, revealing that nitrite was reduced by all reduced polyoxoanion species. It is worth emphasizing that the fourth reduced species shows the best electrocatalytic activity, suggesting that the increase of reduction extent of the Keggin anion species may enhance their catalytic activities. It's also noteworthy that no obvious response was observed in the range +800 to -150mV on a bare CPE and the reduction of nitrite at a bare electrode generally requires a large overpotential (b). Moreover, the peak currents of 1-CPE keep almost unchanged over 100 cycles at a scan rate of 100mV/s when the potential range is maintained between +800 and -150mV, indicating that 1-CPE possesses a relatively high stability .

Crystal Structure of {[Ag(L1 )2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of {[Ag(L 1)2]⋅(CF3SO3)⋅4H2O} n  (1) consists of one silver atom and two L1  ligand molecules ( a). In each ligand molecule (N,N'-bis(4-pyridyl)idene-1R,2R-diaminocyclohexane), the inner imino N-atoms are oriented in different directions, with the nearly gauche N-C-C-N torsion angles equal to 59.71° and 63.99°, which makes them inert to metal ion coordination. As a result, only the peripheral pyridyls coordinate to the silver ions. Every silver ion has a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment, being bound to four nitrogen donors from the four adjacent molecules of L1 , with Ag-N bond distances in the range 2.247(3)-2.423(4)Å, and bond angles around the neighboring atoms ranging from 89.0(1)° to 143.4(1)°. The Ag(I) centers are extended by L1  ligands along two directions (b), resulting in a (4,4)-connected two-dimensional layer with a corrugated surface, in which four L1  ligands bridge four adjacent Ag atoms to form a 60-membered metallocycle with two opposite Ag⋯Ag distances of 17.758 and 13.256Å (c). Significantly, these two-dimensional layers stack in a parallel fashion, producing a one-dimensional channel when viewed down the crystallographic b axis (d and e). These channels are filled by the uncoordinated CF3SO3 - anions and guest H2O molecules. The shortest Ag⋯Ag distance between adjacent layers is 9.182Å. This result suggests that similar coordination complexes can be formed by L1  ligands and silvers ions, even when different counter anions are used . However, if the 4-substituted pyridine moiety on L1  was replaced by a 3-substituted pyridine moiety (L2 ), we found that a one-dimensional helical chain of L2  with Cd(II) can be formed ( ).

Ga(OH)(btec)⋅0.5H2O (MIL-61) was subjected to 1H and 13C{1H} decoupled NMR measurements. The 1H NMR spectrum is displayed in   and is composed of at least five overlapping signals. NMR parameters and assignment are given in  . The signal at  δ = 4.3   ppm  can be assigned to the GaOHGa   μ 2  -bridging hydroxides. GaOH groups generally resonate at lower frequency, around 0 to -1 ppm . The shift toward lower shielding may be due to the implication of these protons in hydrogen bond network with the occluded water molecule. Typically, the peak at  δ = 5.5   ppm  is attributable to water molecule of the structure. This resonance accounts for 15% of total NMR signals intensity, very close to the expected value 17% based on global chemical formula. The signal of the two aromatic protons of organic molecule is featured at  δ = 8.6   ppm  with an intensity of 41% of total NMR signal as expected (theoretical 33%). Two distinct low-field signals at  δ = 10.8  and 13.0 ppm are observed due to carboxylic acidic protons (COOH)  indicating that some carboxylic acid groups are still protonated. According to quantification of these signals ( 13 % + 13 % = 26 % ) and by comparison to the theoretical amount of carboxylic acid (33% of proton), one can conclude that half of the carboxylic groups are protonated in good agreement with the structure determination. The existence of two different resonances for these carboxylic acid protons could account for two different local environments in the solid. This is consistent with different interaction types through hydrogen bonds as evidenced by the structure determination ().   displays the 13C{1H} decoupled NMR spectrum. The signals at  δ = 123.3 , 142.3 and 145.2 ppm are attributable to aromatic carbons of the carboxylic acid molecule. Signals at lower field on one hand  δ = 165.2   ppm  and on the other hand  δ = 176.2  and 174.7 ppm can be assigned to the carbons of the unprotonated carboxylate functions and protonated carboxylic acid functions respectively. Here again, we can distinguish between the two different carboxylic acid groups due to the different hydrogen bond networks.

Structure description of Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 ⋅7H2O (1)

X-ray single crystal diffraction reveals that compound 1 possesses a centrosymmetric Cu4O4 core based on a stepped topology ( ) . The Cu4O4 core is composed of two crystallographically independent Cu (II) atoms [namely, Cu1 and Cu2]. Cu1 and Cu2 both possess the configuration of a distorted square pyramid, however, there are two sets of coordination environments around the copper atoms. Cu1 is located in a plane consisting of two nitrogen atoms (N3 and N4) from a chelating phen molecule and two hydroxides (O7 and O7#1), and the axial position is occupied by the phenolato oxygen atom (O3). For Cu2, the plane is composed of two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2) from the phen molecule, one carboxylate oxygen (O1) and one phenolato oxygen atom (O3), and the corresponding axial position is taken by one hydroxide ion (O7#1). Cu1 and Cu2 atoms, with two symmetry-related copper centres, are connected into a Cu4O4 core by two μ3-hydroxo groups and two phenolato oxygen atoms. The Cu4O4 core consists of a stepped structure in which three Cu2O2 planes are formed by Cu2 Cu1 O3 O7#1 I, Cu1 Cu1#1 O7 O7#1 II and Cu2#1 Cu1#1 O3#1 O7 III. Planes I and III, with a maximum deviation of 0.1308Å from their least-squares planes, are parallel to each other, but both have the same bihedral angle of 103° with plane II. In the Cu4O4 core, we observed that the four Cu atoms form a flat rhomboid with sides Cu1⋯Cu2 and Cu1#1⋯Cu2 of lengths 3.18 and 3.59Å, respectively, a short diagonal (Cu1⋯Cu1#1) of 2.94Å and a long diagonal (Cu2⋯Cu2#1) of 6.10Å. Offset π-π interactions between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.43Å and offset angle of 28.74° stabilize the tetranuclear complex. To the best of our knowledge, only one copper complex constructed from mixed organic ligands with a stepped topology has previously been reported .

The 2D layers are connected into a 3D supramolecular network by water heptamers ( ), the geometrical parameters of the hydrogen bonds are given in . In addition to hydrogen bonding, inter-layer contacts are strengthened by intermolecular π-π interactions between adjacent Cu4(OH)2(ssal)2(phen)4 units (offset π-π interaction between phen molecules with a face-to-face distance of 3.47Å and offset angle 36.53°). Interestingly, the water heptamers and sulfonate anions are interconnected into a 2D supramolecular layer with very large rhombic windows (with dimensions of 12.57×17.77Å) through hydrogen bonding ( ). The tetranuclear Cu (II) units are right inside the large rhombic windows between the 2D layers ).

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis  revealed the existence of the dilacunary species, [Mo6O22]8-, which is a new member for the POMs family. The dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- in 1 is derived from saturated β-octamolybdate through the removal of two MoO2 groups (). The molecule structure of compound 1 consists of copper-complex fragments-substituted dilacunary β-octamolybdate unit [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22], a [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster, two protoned water molecules and a K+ cation. Compound 1 is the first transition-metal-substituted derivative of [β-Mo8O26]4-. An ORTEP drawing of the asymmetry unit of 1 with the atom-labeling scheme is shown in  , which includes only seven molybdenum and two copper atoms. The well-known [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster consists of eight distorted corner- and/or edge-sharing MoO6 octahedra  with Mo-O distances in the range 1.690(3)-2.446(2)Å and bond angles in the range 69.30(8)-174.34(11)°. Each [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster forms covalent interactions with two [Cu(phen)] complexes through bridging terminal oxo-groups of β-octamolybdate. As shown in  , [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment is a 2D network, which is composed of dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- linked with four [Cu(phen)] complexes by sharing oxygen atoms. Molybdenum oxo-groups of [Mo6O22]8- anion possess two coordination modes, MoO5 square pyramidal geometry and MoO6 octahedron. The [Mo6O22]8- anion acts as a multidentate ligand linked with Cu ions. The lacunary sites of [Mo6O22]8- anion are occupied by four [Cu(phen)] complexes to form a Cu-complex fragments-substituted POMs. The Cu1 atom locates in the {CuO3N2} square pyramid corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.970(2)Å), bonds to two terminal oxo-groups of two MoO6 octahedra belonging to the [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster (Cu-O=2.394(3) Å) and dilacunary β-octamolybdate anion [Mo6O22]8- (Cu-O=1.959(2) Å), respectively, and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.995(3)-2.017(3)Å). The Cu2 atom locates in the {CuO2N2} planar square corner-sharing with a MoO6 octahedron and a MoO5 square pyramid (Cu-O=1.929(2)Å), bonds to a terminal O atom of the corner-shared MoO6 octahedron (Cu-O=1.944(3)Å), and contacts with two nitrogen donors of one phen ligand (Cu-N=1.971(3)-1.975(3)Å). Distance of Cu1⋅⋅⋅Cu2 is 4.095Å. Cu1A and Cu2A are symmetrically equivalent copper atoms of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Their coordination environments are the same to those of Cu1 and Cu2, respectively. Therefore, the structure may also be described as four [Cu(phen)] complexes that take the place of two MoO2 groups located symmetrically in the [β-Mo8O26]4- shell to form the hybrid [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment. [{Cu(phen)}4Mo6O22] fragment and [β-Mo8O26]4- cluster are alternatively adjacent to each other and connected via terminal O atom of MoO6 octahedron to form a novel 1D linear chain ( ). The isolated K+ cations and protoned water molecules acting as charge-compensating cations, occupy inter-chain (SI.1). The bond valence sum calculations  for compound 1 indicate that all Mo atoms are in the +6 oxidation state with an average value of 5.939, all Cu atoms are in the +2 oxidation state with an average value of 1.686. Direct evidence for this is also provided by XPS measurements. As shown in the XPS spectra of 1(SI.2), two peaks at 232.4 and 235.8eV can be attributed to Mo6+ (3d5/2) and Mo6+ (3d3/2), respectively . The two peaks at 934.3 and 954.3eV can be attributed to Cu2+ (2p3/2) and Cu2+ (2p1/2), respectively .

Studies on tppz metal(II) complexes have illustrated the ability of this polydentate organic ligand to mediate magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers bridged by the central pyrazine moiety and hence separated by more than 6.4Å . The largest antiferromagnetic interaction has been found in the dinuclear complexes [Cu2(tppz)(H2O)4](ClO4)4⋅2H2O (J =-61.1cm-1) and [Ni2(tppz)(H2O)6](NO3)4⋅2.5H2O (J =-76cm-1) . Interestingly, the relatively good efficiency of the tppz bridge in transmitting magnetic interactions between paramagnetic centers contrasts with much poorer ability of unsubstituted pyrazine bridges in its metal complexes, where negligible or weak antiferromagnetic interactions were observed (with J values ranging from -0.14cm-1 in [Ni(pyz)2Cl2] to 15.1cm-1 in Cu(pyz)2(ReO4)2) . In binuclear ruthenium(II) complexes, tppz bridges have been found to mediate intermetallic electronic communication through the π symmetry orbitals . In turn, the mononuclear complexes of Co(II) of formula [Co(tppz)2]2+ with tppz ligands coordinated in a tridentate coordination mode attract scientific interest due to thermally induced spin crossover behaviour from a high-spin S Co =3/2 at high temperatures to a low-spin S Co =1/2 at lower temperatures .

Ag1 ion displays a T-shaped geometry, being coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from different 4,4'-bpp ligands (bpp-A and bpp-B) and an oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc. The bond distances of Ag-N, Ag-O [Ag1-N1: 2.187(5)Å; Ag1-N3 2.211(5)Å; Ag1-O3 2.544(5)Å] and angle of N-Ag-N or N-Ag-O [ranging from 92.88(19)° for N3-Ag1-O3 to 166.90(19)° for N1-Ag1-N3] are comparable to those observed in related structures of silver(I) complexes. The Ag2 center in an almost linear fashion is coordinated by one pyridine nitrogen from 4,4'-bpp ligand and one oxygen atom from the 1,3-bdc ligand. The Ag-N distance and Ag-O distance are 2.117(6) and 2.114(5)Å, respectively, and N-Ag-O angel bent to 168° falls in the expected values.

Computational Studies

We have performed DFT and TD-DFT calculations on a dimer model of 1a to explore the assignments of the emission bands observed in the luminescence spectra. Our model is in good agreement with experimental data. Ground state geometry computational results for 1a (Fig. 6), which are summarized in Table 4, show a partially distorted tetrahedral copper(I) center coordinated to two nitrogen atoms and two iodine atoms. The slight distortion of the tetrahedron is apparent in the reduced N-Cu-I angle of ~107°. Dimeric Cu2I2 clusters form planar rhombic metal-halide centers with µ2-bridging I atoms [19-29]. Calculated atom⋯atom distances for the rhombic centers are in agreement with the experimental values (Fig. 7). The calculated Cu⋯Cu distance of 2.88 Å for the 1a dimer is in good agreement with the experimental value, which ranges from 2.67 to 2.71 Å between 100 and 250 K (see Table 3). The structural accuracy of our dimer model is further supported by the agreement between the TFD-calculated and experimental infrared spectra (Figure S6).

It is well known that some metal-organic complexes (MOCs) could be used as green photocatalysts for the removal of organic pollutants from water [13, 14]. During the photocatalytic process of MOCs, UV-Vis light induces organic ligands to produce X-metal (X = N, O, S) charge transfer by promoting an electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The HOMO strongly demands one electron to return to its stable state. Therefore, one electron was captured from water molecules, which were oxygenated into the ⋅OH active species, to complete the photocatalytic process [15-17]. RhB is the most common organic dyes in waste water [18, 19], therefore it was selected as model pollutant to investigate its degradation in the presence of the complex in this work. The photocatalytic behaviors of the complex in RhB solution are shown in Fig. 5. The absorbance peaks of RhB solution decreased obviously along with the reaction time at the presence of the complex. The degradation ratios of RhB are 23.38 % for 10 min, 47.71 % for 20 min, 58.80 % for 30 min, 88.47 % for 40 min and 92.72 % for 50 min of UV irradiation (Fig. 6). The color change photograph of RhB solution is shown in Fig. 7. These results demonstrate that the complex is an excellent photocatalyst for degradation of RhB solution [20-28].

Conclusions

In summary, a three-dimensional network built of cobalt sulfate sheets and ethylenediamine pillars has been synthesized and characterized. The layered structure of the cobalt sulfate is unique in their regular alternating arrangement of the CoO4N2 octahedra and the SO4 tetrahedral units. The presence of ethylenediamine pillars, which link the adjacent sheets in an ABAB stacking fashion, results in intersecting channels in an infinite coordination network. The crystal structure has been fully characterized and reveals both coordination and hydrogen bonds to be important in introducing the order to the structure. The compound is thermally stable and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature with an effective magnetic moment per CoII atom of 4.6 μB, which is comparable to analogous structures with longer diamines.

Abstract

A pillared-layered coordination polymer of formula Co(H2NCH2CH2NH2)SO4 (1) has been synthesized under solvothermal condition, and fully characterized. The three-dimensional structure of 1 is built up from cobalt sulfate sheets, each of which is composed of regularly alternating CoO4N2 octahedra and SO4 tetrahedra, with ethylenediamine pillars connecting the adjacent sheets. The coordinate covalent and hydrogen bonds have been revealed to exhibit an important role in the organization of the structure. The compound is found to be thermally stable up to, and above, 573 K and exhibits paramagnetic behavior at room temperature.

In order to investigate the properties of complex 1 for sensing metal ions, the luminescence enhancement effects of various metal ions [MCln; M = K+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Sr2+, Ba2+, Al3+, Cr2+, Co2+, Co3+, Ni2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Fe2+, Fe3+] on 1 in an 10-2 M DMF suspension were investigated under excitation at 286 nm (Fig. 4a). The luminescence intensity was significantly quenched on the addition of the Fe3+ ion in solution compared to the blank sample, while other metal ions only slightly affect the luminescence intensity. The quenching effect may be largely ascribed to the interactions between the Fe3+ ion and the N- uncoordinated group of complex 1. This would allow electrons to transfer from 1 to Fe3+, resulting in a less effective intramolecular energy transfer from the ligands to the Cd(II). A similar mechanism has been proposed for other systems [35, 36]. The selectivity of the system was further studied using different ion mixtures in DMF solution. The luminescence of 1 was slightly weakened by mixed ions in the absence of Fe3+ (Fig. 4b); however, the luminescence was immediately and completely quenched by the addition of Fe3+ to the mixture. Hence, complex 1 has high selectivity for Fe3+ over other metal ions. The PXRD pattern of complex 1 after sensing Fe3+ was in good agreement with the as-synthesized sample, demonstrating that the basic framework remains unchanged after sensing (Fig. S6). Moreover, ICP experiments were performed to monitor the release of Cd2+ ions from complex 1 after the Fe3+ ion sensing experiment and the concentration of Cd2+ ions was found to be 0.17 μg ml-1, which is close to that of the blank sample (0.16 μg ml-1). Therefore, it can be concluded that there is no release of Cd2+ from complex 1 during the sensing experiments and that the framework of the complex remains unchanged.

Stability of the Catalyst

Catalytic stability is a crucial factor in deciding practical uses. The reusability of the non-noble bimetallic Ni1Cu2/C500 catalyst was investigated for four cycles (Figure S5). After each cycle, the catalyst was removed from the liquid phase through a simple separating and drying process without any regeneration step. Then, fresh substrate LA and 1,4-dioxane solvent were added to the reactor for the next cycle under the action of recovery catalyst. The results of the four-run tests are illustrated in Figure S5. It can be seen that the Ni1Cu2/C500 catalyst can still exhibit good stability after recycling at least four times with almost no obvious loss in the GVL yield. The XRD pattern of the reused Ni1Cu2/C500 after the fourth recycling test is illustrated in Figure S6. The diffraction peaks of homo-Ni gradually emerged, which were likely due to the structural reconstruction. In addition, TEM and XPS analysis of the Ni1Cu2/C500 catalyst after four runs, as shown in Figures S7 and S8, confirms that active sites of metals remain highly dispersed and with nearly no agglomeration, and the chemical state of the Cu metal component of the alloy was maintained, which is the evidence of an unchanged structure, crystal phase, and chemical forms. Furthermore, a comparison table is summarized in Table S6, and the catalytic performance of the noble-metal-free Ni1Cu2/C500 achieved in this work is much superior to those reported in the previous works for the LA hydrogenation to GVL.

Catalytic Performance in the Hydrogenation of LA

As shown in a, the catalytic performance of the set of Ni x Cu y /C500 catalysts was first screened in a batch reactor in 1,4-dioxane as a solvent at 160 °C and 2 MPa of H2 pressure for 3 h. The homometallic Ni/C500 showed a very low GVL yield, less than 40%. In comparison, with the formation of the bimetallic NiCu nanoparticles, a higher yield was obtained. The Ni1Cu2/C500 catalyst showed the highest catalytic performance with a 66.8% yield of GVL at the LA conversion of 69.3%. The ligand effect between Ni and Cu could induce the synergetic activities in the Ni x Cu y /C500 catalysts. Besides this, the catalytic performance of Ni1Cu2/C500 was further used to evaluate other reaction parameters. The effect of reaction temperature was then discussed under the constant conditions of 2 MPa H2 and 3 h (b). A remarkable change in the catalytic performance was observed by varying the reaction temperature. LA conversion was found to increase from 7.0 to 99.9% as the temperature increased from 120 to 200 °C, with the corresponding improvement in the GVL yield from 1.5 to 97.1%. However, higher temperatures (>200 °C) decreased the yield of GVL and induced side reactions (e.g., formation of 2-methyltetrahydrofuran and pentanoic acid). A temperature of 180 °C was chosen to explore other factors. The effect of H2 pressure and reaction time was also evaluated and is presented in c,d. Optimum reaction parameters to achieve nearly a full conversion of LA and 93.9% yield of GVL are obtained in 1,4-dioxane at 180 °C, 2 MPa of H2 pressure, and 3 h of reaction time.

We observed that solutions prepared with PTA-OH gel after adding small amounts of ZIF-8, while analogous solutions with PTA do not gel. a shows that the time for gelation of 10 wt % PTA-OH solutions in DMF is highly dependent on their content of ZIF-8. In this plot, the system was considered fully gelled when no flow could be visibly detected in upside-down vials (see b). More precisely, we measured the storage (G') and loss (G") moduli as a function of time for solutions with 10 wt % PTA-OH and different ZIF-8 contents (c). Initially, for all solutions G" > G', similar to solutions without ZIF-8 (Figure S2), the G'/G" ratio is <1. When no ZIF-8 is added, practically no significant change of viscosity or G'/G" with time was observed. This indicates the viscous fluidic behavior of the solutions. For samples with 5-15 wt % ZIF-8, above 12 min (c), G' becomes larger than G", demonstrating that a gel-like behavior is developed. The time corresponding to the crossing of the G' and G" curves (G'/G" = 1) increases as 5 > 10 > 15 wt %. We performed the same experiment, substituting PTA-OH by the analogous nonfunctionalized polytriazole. In this case, due to the lack of solubility at room temperature, the experiments were conducted at 60 °C. As seen in d, no gelation was observed. G'/G" remained constant with time and smaller than 1, characterizing a viscous behavior.

The rheology of solutions with 10 wt % PTA-OH (or PTA) and different contents of ZIF-8 were then investigated in detail. Figure S3a shows first how the viscosity of PTA-OH solutions without ZIF-8 depends on shear rate. As expected, at a low shear rate, the viscosity is constant and the solutions have a Newtonian behavior. As the shear rate increases, a shear thinning is observed, which is usually understood as the elongation or partial disentanglement of polymer coils in solution. The inverse of the shear rate corresponding to the initial viscosity decrease can be correlated to the relaxation time of the system. For weight fractions 10, 12, and 15 wt %, the values at which the shear thinning initiates at 25 °C were 40, 400, and 600 s-1, with the corresponding relaxation times of 0.025, 0.0025, and 0.0017 s. The addition of only 3 wt % ZIF-8 (relative to the polymer content) to the PTA-OH solution causes gelation with a 4 orders of magnitude increase in viscosity, as seen in Figure S3b. By fixing the polymer fraction in 10 wt %, it was possible to observe in Figure S3c an even higher increase of viscosity as the ZIF-8 content increased from 3 to 15 wt %.

By investigating the viscosity of freshly prepared 10 wt % PTA-OH solutions in DMF with 5 wt % ZIF-8 (relative to the polymer content) as a function of temperature, we see in a a clear increase in viscosity (shear thickening) before shear thinning is initiated. The shear rate at which the maximum occurs depends on temperature. For 30 °C or below, the maximum is probably out of the measurement range of the rheometer, with a slight increase of viscosity starting just below 10000 s-1. As the temperature increases to 40, 50, and 60 °C, a maximum is clearly seen, occurring, respectively, at 1100, 400, and 240 s-1. Shear thinning in polymers solutions without additives is understood as simply related to the disentanglement of polymer coils under shearing. Shear thickening and thinning reflect the friction between chain segments and are therefore influenced by the quality of the solvent, which may change with temperature. In the system represented in , the shear thickening and thinning start at a lower shear rate at a higher temperature. A higher mobility of the polymer coils at a higher temperature would explain this behavior with less shearing being enough to disentangle coils under flow. Shear thickening is an indication of the presence of a transient network, caused by the stretching of potential intersegment bridges or by the formation of additional bridges. In our system, bridges are built by the strong interaction between specific groups in the polymer chains and ZIF-8. The kind of interaction is discussed later, based on spectroscopic data. In , the shear thickening is more pronounced at higher temperatures, with differentiated shear thickening for systems above 40 °C. However, one should keep in mind that the viscosity values at a low shear rate are in the range of 0.05-0.15 Pa s. Under these conditions, the interaction with ZIF-8 is still being built. The results in  were obtained with freshly prepared solutions, immediately after mixing the PTA-OH solution and the ZIF-8 dispersion, when gelation still did not start. Figure S4 presents Arrhenius-like plots of viscosity as a function of the inverse of temperature, at different shear rates. The slopes are steeper at 252 and 398 s-1, range at which shear thickening is more pronounced, indicating a relatively high activation energy to break the transient network built by the entangled polymer chains with incipient ZIF-8 connections.

reports the rheological investigation of the systems after the gelation of ZIF-8/PTA-OH was initiated. While no gelation is observed for samples without ZIF-8, with the viscosity remaining lower than 0.1 Pa s (Figure S3a), the viscosity values are orders of magnitude larger, above 400 Pa s, for systems with >5 wt % ZIF-8. For these systems, the shear thickening is higher than 400 Pa s (). The plots in  have multi-inflections first with a light shear thickening, followed by a sharp shear thinning. This behavior indicates the presence of transient networks with a polydisperse set of bridges with different strengths and relaxation times. The first shear thickening probably reflects the tendency of the macromolecule to disentangle, driven by the increasing shear rate (as depicted in b), at the same time suffering a strong resistance to break the strong bridges between the polymer and ZIF-8. As the shear rate is increased, these bridges holding the entangled coils together break, the friction between segments decreases, as well as the viscosity decreases. As the shear rate continues to increase, the remaining links between ZIF-8 particles and the already disentangled macromolecules are also disrupted. As seen later, bridges might be formed by strong hydrogen bonds between the polymer and the linker or potentially by competing to coordinate with the zinc ions.

A good interaction between filler and polymer should contribute to satisfactory mechanical properties. Figure S11a shows stress-strain curves of films prepared with increasing ZIF-8 contents, and additional characterization is reported in Table S2. The integration of stress-strain curves led to the toughness values in Figure S11b. The toughness and tensile strength decrease with the incorporation of ZIF-8. One potential reason might be the local aggregation of the filler that could to be minimized. But independent of that, the toughness and processability of polymers are known to be better than those of MOFs. Polymers are even used to enable MOF processability in the form of fibers. Although lower than that for the pure polymer, the values for PTA-OH/ZIF-8 composites are still high compared to analogous films prepared with other polymers, including other examples with OH functionalization. Creep tests in Figure S11c show that samples submitted up to 0.7% strain could be recovered without permanent deformation. For the preparation of composite membranes for gas separation, the selective layer is ultrathin and deposited on a thicker, porous support. Therefore, the mechanical stability of the selective material becomes less important. The adhesion needs to be enough to avoid the formation of cavities between the polymer and the filler but does not need to secure high toughness.

To determine the various levels of H2O2 in living cells, normal primary uterine fibroblast cells (PCS-460-010) were treated with N-acetylcysteine (NAC) to eliminate intracellular ROS. They were then incubated with varying concentrations of H2O2 to increase intracellular H2O2 levels. After treatment, intracellular H2O2 was quantified with a hydrogen peroxide assay kit. For UCL signal detection, the PCS-460-010 cells were incubated with the nanoassemblies and then confocal images were taken under an optical microscope equipped with a 980 nm laser. As shown in A, the green UCL signal as expected increased, whereas the red UCL signal remained unchanged, with an increase in intracellular H2O2 concentration. The UCL signal allowed a linear relationship ranging from 0.18 to 10.2 μΜ, and the LOD was 0.13 μΜ, which is much lower than the H2O2 level (~35 μM) in human blood plasma.

We analyzed the EER activity of (C2H5)2dtoaCu by CV as well as that of (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu. Figure  shows the CV of (C2H5)2dtoaCu in an aqueous solution of 0.5 M H2SO4 with different concentrations of ethanol. Although two weak peaks (I and II) were observed, the enhancement of the peaks by the addition of ethanol were small, and there was no effect of different concentration of ethanol at 0.6 and 0.8 V. This experimental result indicates that the EER catalytic activity of (C2H5)2dtoaCu is extremely small or nonexistent. In fact, the activation energy of (C2H5)2dtoaCu was about twice as high as that of (HOC2H4)2dtoaCu and (HOC3H6)2dtoaCu according to the theoretical calculation. In addition, (C2H5)2dtoaCu has a different ethanol oxidation pathway by a direct proton-transfer mechanism. These experimental results strongly support our proposed ethanol oxidation reaction mechanism on R2dtoaCu.

Recycling of Adsorbents

The reusability of adsorbents is considered as one of the most important criteria for commercial application of sorbents. In fact, this aspect is directly related to the cost effectiveness of adsorbents or adsorption processes. To learn more about this issue, we performed and investigated the sorption behavior of aqueous FA over 10 adsorption-desorption cycles. The results were then used to evaluate the regenerability of the selected adsorbents. It is worth mentioning that the main mechanism for the adsorption of FA tested at low concentrations in this work (0.2 ppm) by amine functionalized materials should be the hydrogen bond formation. (Refer to adsorption mechanism section.) Therefore, the regeneration of the spent material was found to be easier. Accordingly, U6N was shown to have a better regeneration capability than all of the other materials. For instance, the regenerability of sorbents, if assessed in terms of FA sorption efficiency, indicated the superiority of U6N, because its values for the 1st and 10th cycles were 92 and 80%, respectively. Apart from U6N, the values were CE [82% (1st)-70% (10th)] < U6 [70 (1st)-55% (10th)] < CD [65% (1st)-55% (10th)] (CD) ().

The adsorption-based removal of FA in aqueous phase was investigated using two classes of novel porous materials, MOFs and COPs, at ambient conditions. All of these tested materials were found to be significantly powerful sorbents to capture FA efficiently from water. In particular, comparison of the adsorption capacities for the four tested materials confirmed that U6N (amino-U6) had the best adsorption capacity (93% and 0.56 mg g-1) of the materials tested concurrently [e.g., CE (81.1%, 0.53 mg g-1) > CD (67.2%, 0.43 mg g-1) > U6 (66.9%, 0.42 mg g-1)] at 24 h. Comparison of the adsorption capacity data showed that some materials tested previously by others (e.g., modified alumina nanoparticles and 3D nanoporous MOF) had the maximum values. However, evaluation of the adsorption potential, in terms of the PC, confirmed that U6N was the best sorbent with the highest PC value of 1143 mg g-1 mM-1, while those of modified alumina nanoparticles and 3D nanoporous MOF were only 1.96 and 41.7 mg g-1 mM-1, respectively. The bifunctional acid-base characteristics [e.g., Lewis acid (Zr-sites) and Bronsted base (-NH2 sites)] of U6N should be responsible for its superior FA removal performance. In summary, metal-clusters were able to form electrostatic interactions (>5 Å) with FA molecules, while the NH2 portions of ligands were capable of forming hydrogen bonding (>2.6 Å) with them. On the other hand, as the loading of FA on the U6 was found to be less favorable (-19.3 kJ mol-1), further loading of FA on the metal-clusters resulted in lattice distortion (+93.4 kJ mol-1). The pseudo-second-order model showed the best fit for the sorption processes of FA (R 2 = >0.99) for all of the selected adsorbents. The Temkin and Dubinin-Radushkevich isotherm models indicated that adsorption of FA on the selected adsorbents was accompanied by both physisorption and chemisorption. This synergetic mechanism was also verified with the help of DFT calculations. Finally, regeneration of the spent sorbent was found to be easy, confirming their potential for practical application in removal of FA in water. The results of our study support the significantly high potential of U6N MOF and COPs for the removal of FA in aqueous phase.

Some activity has focused on MOCs-related organ-specific activity, as summarized in . The heterometallic Ru-Re metallacycle MOC 1 (a) reported by Thomas functions as an intracellular singlet oxygen sensitizer that causes plasma membrane damage. Another heterometallic Ru-Pt metallacycle, MOC 2, was synthesized by our group and exhibits near-infrared emission, strong two-photon absorption (TPA), and high 1O2 generation efficiency. MOC 2 accumulates in mitochondria because of the negative potential difference across the mitochondrial membrane. Elevated intracellular ROS levels within mitochondria can trigger caspase activation and apoptosis. MOC 2 partially accumulates in the nucleus in addition to mitochondria. The in vivo two-photon PDT efficacy of MOC 2 was investigated using A549 tumor-bearing nude mice with a xenograft tumor volume of 80 mm3. In the treatment group, the tumors shrank gradually and were reduced to 78% of the original size on day 14, while the tumors in the control group showed more than a 13-fold growth over the same period. No noticeable body weight loss was found during the treatment process, indicating the minimal side effects of MOC 2. Representative images of A549 tumors in mice with these different treatments are shown in b.

Hunter and Ward reported a range of organic molecules with acidic or basic groups that exhibit strong pH-dependent binding inside the cavity of a polyhedral coordination cage, MOC 105 (h). Guest binding in aqueous solution is dominated by a hydrophobic contribution, which is compensated by stronger solvation when the guests become cationic (by protonation) or anionic (by deprotonation). pH-dependent binding was observed for a range of guests with different functional groups (primary and tertiary amines, pyridine, imidazole, and carboxylic acids) so that the pH range can be tuned anywhere in the range of 3.5-11. After treatment with supercritical CO2, a single-crystal sample of MOC 106 transformed into amorphous material with the retention of the cage skeleton, which demonstrated good adsorption properties toward a small drug molecule, ibuprofen (Ibu, G16). An Ibu release experiment in phosphate-buffered saline solution (pH 7.4) revealed that MOC 106 exhibited slow drug release behavior.

By applying a suitable electrical voltage to invert the band slope of the MOF layer and Dirac point of graphene, we can switch our fabricated device from photodetector to light-emitting diode (LED) modes. We measured the electroluminescence spectrum (EL) of our device under the applications of different forward injection currents, as shown in a. Our fabricated flexible vertical phototransistor device possesses a continuous and broad electroluminescence spectrum identical to the observed photoluminescence spectrum covering the whole visible regime under different injection currents from 0.7 to 3 mA. The CRI and the CCT of emitted light are 85 and 5620 K for the CIE color coordinates (0.33, 0.34), respectively. For further clarification of broad-spectrum light emission from our fabricated device, we compared our EL spectrum with the commercial white LED (b) and the solar emission spectrum of AM0 (Figure S14). Surprisingly, our device can provide emission matching the solar-spectrum white light very well, which is very rare in conventional LEDs. The principle of the electroluminescence of our fabricated phototransistor can be explained by the energy-band diagram, as shown in Figure S15. By applying a suitable electrical bias, the barrier potential of asymmetric Schottky junctions is inversed as compared to the mode of photodetection operation. The Schottky barrier at the GrT/MOF interface can become higher than the Schottky barrier at the MOF/GrB interface at a suitable electrical bias. Under this circumstance, the electrons transferred from GrT, and the holes transferred from GrB into the MOF layer, which creates the radiative recombination between electrons and holes from the multiple energy states of MOFs and generates the white light emission. The estimated EQE in the electroluminescence from the light-emissive vertical phototransistor is ~1%. The fill factor for our graphene sandwich GrT/MOF/GrB/PVDF multifunctional white light-emissive vertical phototransistor is much higher compared to the fill factor of a previously reported WLED fabricated by using a GrT/MOF/ZnO/Ag heterostructure. Multiple aspects behind the observation of high fill factor include (a) the short channel length of a graphene sandwich vertical phototransistor reduces the channel resistance compared to the long channel length of MOF/ZnO heterojunctions, (b) asymmetric Schottky junctions at GrT/MOF and MOF/GrB interfaces due to the utilization of piezoelectric PVDF provide less resistance compared to junctions at Ag/ZnO and MOF/Gr interfaces of a GrT/MOF/ZnO/Ag heterostructure, and (c) direct charge transformations between interligand, intermetal, and metal to a ligand by an external applied electric field inside the MOF complex compared to the indirect charge transformations of MOF/ZnO heterostructure. We demonstrated the device's flexibility in electroluminescence under the application of bending strain (ca. <20%), as shown in c. This investigation reveals that the emitted light intensity is higher under the application of downward bending strain as compared to upward bending strain, which is in stark contrast with the investigation of photocurrent under the application of mechanical bending strain. The underlying mechanism can also be interpreted by the Dirac point modulation of graphene through the piezoelectric field created by the PVDF film under bending. Additionally, we investigated applied voltage-dependent light emission under mechanical bending conditions, as shown in d. At a lower injection current, we observed the green emission band dominates in the EL spectrum. Spectacularly, with the enhancement of applied potential, a blue emission peak centered at ~430 nm appears in the EL spectrum. At the application of a higher injected current, the blue emission band dominates over the green emission band in the EL spectrum. The mobile photographs of emitted light at different injected currents are provided in the inset of d, and the corresponding CIE diagram of emitted light at different injection currents is shown in e. These fascinating features can be explained by the band alignment between MOF and graphene through the Dirac point modulation by applied potential, strain, and the charge-transfer mechanism inside the MOF complex, as shown in f. As mentioned earlier, an MOF can cover a wide range of light emissions because of several charge transitions inside the MOF complex. As shown in the PL spectrum of Figure S6, the band gap of the intermetallic charge transformation is much lower than the band gap of interligand charge transformation. Because of the lower band gap effect, at a lower injection current intermetallic and metal-ligand charge transformations dominate in the electroluminescence, which provides the green and yellow emission bands, respectively. However, at a higher injection current, interligand charge transformation is dominant over the metal-ligand charge transformation, which provides the blue emission peak over the yellow emission in the EL spectrum. The different exciton lifetime associated with the different charge-transformation mechanisms provides multiple emission bands in the EL spectrum. For further confirmation of the existence of multiple light emission bands in the EL spectrum, we measured the exciton lifetime from the time-resolved PL study, as shown in Figure S16. This investigation reveals different exciton lifetimes for multiple charge-transfer mechanisms in the MOF complex. All these investigations reveal that the color of the emitted light from our fabricated vertical phototransistor can be tuned by the modulation of the Dirac point of graphene and the charge transfer mechanism inside the MOF complex. Previously, Dirac point modulated light emission has been reported by sandwiching quantum dots between the graphene on a solid substrate of SiO2/Si. In this work, for the first time, we demonstrated the Dirac point-controlled color-tunable light emission by sandwiching MOFs between the graphene on a flexible substrate of PVDF/PDMS. The stability performance of the multifunctional flexible phototransistor in photocurrent generation and light emission is provided in Figure S17.

After confirming the permanent porosity and phase purity of the mechanochemically produced UiO-type MOFs, we evaluated their applicability by assessing their activity as catalysts for hydrolysis of the nerve agent simulant dimethyl 4-nitrophenyl phosphate (DMNP, ). The mechanochemically prepared samples of UiO-66-NH2, previously established to be one of the most potent catalysts for this reaction, expectedly displayed much higher catalytic activity (t 1/2 is ~6 min for the UiO-66-NH2 made by milling in the IST-500 mixer mill) compared to UiO-66, consistent with the previously described behavior of solvothermally prepared UiO's. Interestingly, UiO-66-NH2 prepared by TSE on a 100 g scale showed the best catalytic activity among all tested samples (t 1/2 is ~5 min), which is possibly due to the good dispersibility of the loosely bound particles (b) in water. The UiO-66-NH2 sample obtained from the planetary mill formed large agglomerates in the solid-state (please check the Supporting Information) and the solution, which would not disperse despite the long sonication, and that was the only tested UiO-66-NH2 sample that showed moderate hydrolytic activity under these experimental conditions. It is worth noting that the overall catalytic activity reported here is slightly lower compared to solvothermally prepared UiO-66-NH2 due to the formation of larger agglomerates, resulting in limited dispersibility in water.

Along with a major limitation in the MOF drug delivery system, the hydrophobicity of the particle surface and open pores of Dox-PCN can cause low colloidal stability and premature drug release. To overcome such drawbacks, the Dox-PCN has been modified by an HA biopolymer through the coordination interaction with the Zr cluster and the carboxylic acid of HA. The DLS experiment indicated an increase in the hydrodynamic radius of HA-Dox-PCN (~250 ± 20 nm) compared to that of PCN-224 (~164 ± 20 nm) (e). After HA coating, MOF still showed the spherical morphology (Figure S3). The structural differences among PCN-224, Dox-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN were confirmed by TGA. After modifying the Dox and HA with PCN-224, TGA data show different thermal decomposition processes, although a quantitative calculation of the component ratio is difficult because of the pyrolysis temperature overlap of TCPP, Dox, and HA (Figure S4). Furthermore, surface properties of PCN-224 and HA-Dox-PCN were determined by measuring the ζ-potential in aqueous solution. The ζ-potential experiment indicated a change of the surface charge from a positive potential for PCN-224 (+27 mV) to a negative potential for HA-Dox-PCN (-34 mV) (f). The size and surface charge change indicates that HA was coated successfully on the PCN-224 surface. The HA-Dox-PCN colloidal stability was studied by measuring the size change through varying the time in media. As shown in a, the particle size did not show any significant difference for 48 h, indicative of high colloidal stability. The nanoparticle colloidal stability is important for the safe and effective nanomedicine since low colloidal stability of nanoparticles can lead to capillary blockage in vivo and the nanoparticles are likely to be rapidly removed by the body's reticuloendothelial system.

As shown in b and S6, the amount of HA was independent of the concentration of sodium chloride and sodium acetate. More interestingly, the HA coating was quite stable even at a high salt concentration (200 mM). These results imply that the coating of HA might have happened by the polyvalent coordination bonds, along with simple electrostatic interaction and single coordination bonds. To further investigate the binding between HA and PCN-224, fluorescence titration was performed. Different molecular weights of FITC-modified HA (high-molecular-weight HA (1500-2200 kDa) and low-molecular-weight HA (8-15 kDa)) were prepared to compare the binding constant. The fluorescence of FITC-modified HA (FITC-HA) was significantly quenched when PCN-224 nanoparticles were added, probably due to the energy transfer from FITC to the porphyrin framework (c and S5). The normalized fluorescence intensities of FITC-HA at 520 nm were plotted against the ratio of the nanoparticle to the polymer. The binding constants (K s) were obtained through the nonlinear least-squares curve-fitting analysis. K s of high-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 is 2.9 × 1011 M-1. Meanwhile, that of low-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 was significantly decreased to 3.19 × 107 M-1. These results suggest that a large number of carboxylate groups of HA affect the binding force. Therefore, polyvalent coordination bonds with Zr clusters on the surface of PCN-224 nanoparticles are very important for a robust and stable gatekeeper system.

Results and Discussion

Dielectric Properties

The composition of the three MOFPs differs only in the identity of the A-site pronated amines. MA and DMA ions have polar structures, that is, dipole moments, while the structure of the GUA ion yields no polar axis, and instead, it exhibits a hexapole moment. These characteristic components have a strong impact on the bulk properties of these MOFPs. a-c shows the temperature-dependent dielectric responses (the dielectric constant εr and dielectric loss tan δ) of the three MOFPs. For MA-MOF, the dielectric constant monotonically decreases as the temperature (T) is decreased. A noticeable but small dielectric anomaly near 150 K (inset of a) is obtained and possibly related to the commensurate-incommensurate phase transition as reported recently in the analogous [CH3NH3][Co(HCOO)3] single crystal. In the case of DMA-MOF, a steplike dielectric anomaly occurs around 270 K, associated with a strong dielectric relaxation process over the temperature range between 150 and 270 K as reflected by the frequency dispersion of the dielectric constant. The broad dielectric peak indicates an order-disorder phase transition, which is consistent with previous results. The inset plot displays the logarithm of the applied frequency as a function of inverse temperature corresponding to the peak in tan δ spectra. For the low-temperature region, the data can be well fitted by the Arrhenius law 1     f =   f   0   exp ⁡   -   E   a     R T      Where E a is the activation energy, f 0 is the relaxation frequency constant, and RT is the thermal energy. The fitting results estimate that E a and f 0 are around 0.284 eV and 17 GHz, respectively, which are in the range similar to those for the 120° reorientation of the DMA ion around the C-C axis. In the high-temperature range, the peak of the dielectric losses becomes frequency-independent, which is phenomenologically similar to the ferroelectric-to-paraelectric phase transition with the softening of the phonon modes. c shows the temperature-dependent dielectric properties of GUA-MOF. Its dielectric constant remains almost invariant over a broad temperature range with no evident frequency dispersion. However, it displays the surprising feature that the dielectric constant increases with decreasing temperature, and this trend remains unchanged even at 10 K. This behavior is quite similar to that observed in incipient ferroelectrics such as SrTiO3 and rutile TiO2, although the dielectric constant is several orders of magnitude smaller than those of the other two materials.

Granules and Tablets

Mechanical compression of powder is a traditional shaping method, and the density of the tablets can be adjusted by changing the compression conditions. Pressure is applied to a specific amount of MOF powder through a mechanical device, such as a tablet press, to obtain the shaped sample. MOF-177 powder was compressed into a monolith (D = 5 mm) using a mechanical technique without any binders, resulting in a 78% increase in the maximum excess volumetric hydrogen storage capacity at 6 MPa and 77 K. However, the monolith showed a diminishing micropore volume due to the gradual collapse of MOF-177 crystals to an amorphous phase during densification. This is a natural consequence of mechanical compression depending on the rigidity and the strength of the MOFs framework, where densification may lead to decomposition of the crystallite or interpenetration of particulate (). HKUST-1 was also molded by simple mechanical compression, whereby a 1 mL syringe was filled with powder, which was pressed hard (by hand) during loading (). The CH4 adsorption capacity of the compressed sample was reduced by half compared to that of the HKUST-1 powder. An attempt was made to increase the bulk density by pressing the MOFs onto a wafer at pressures of 0.5, 2, and 5 tons, and the results showed that the total micropore volumes were dramatically reduced. CPO-27-Ni tablets (D = 1 cm, thickness = 0.1 cm) were prepared by pressing (100 MPa) a 0.5 g powder sample with barely a reduction in the specific surface area, and the adsorption of methane was reduced from 157 to 129 N cm3 g-1 at 303 K. Another representative MOF (ZIF-8) was compressed by a universal testing machine, and the impact of compression on the catalytic performance was evaluated. The BET surface area of the compressed ZIF-8 pellets at 5 kN (m = 0.05 g, D = 10 mm) was less than that of the native powder, whereas it was significantly reduced in the compressed HKUST-1, reaching only 25% of the powder sample.

Ribeiro et al. experimentally verified that the specific surface area and CO2 adsorption properties of the ZIF-8 pellets (0.5 g, D = 10 mm, P = 62 and 125 MPa) were slightly affected by the compression molding. The CO2 adsorption isotherm of ZIF-8 pellets overlaps with powder up to 8 bar and a loss of capacity less than 6% at 29 bar. This is related to the large retention of the specific surface area and pore volume of the pellets. The BET surface area of ZIF-8 pellets shows a loss of 7% and 12% compared to powder at a compression of 62 and 125 MPa, respectively. However, the compression molding of the flexible MOF MIL-53(Al) at the same pressure was less effective, with a 46% and 32% loss of the specific surface area compressed at 62 and 125 MPa, respectively. The BET surface area and pore volume of the powder and pressed samples of ZIF-8 and MIL-53(Al) are listed in . To verify that the molded MOFs can be applied to industrial CO2 capture and separation, such as PSA processes, they measured the pellet mass loss rate during pressure change cycles (1, 3, 10, and 13 bar) and demonstrated that both ZIF-8 and MIL-53(Al) pellets () had a mass loss of less than 5%, while MIL-53(Al) had better mechanical properties. The hydrogen storage capacity of the MIL-101 compressed pellets were investigated, and the optimum hydrogen adsorption capacity (40 g/L) was obtained for pellet densities of 0.45-0.47 g/cm3, which is comparable to that of MOF-5 and MOF-177 under the same conditions.

Inorganic Binders

Inorganic binders are considered for the MOFs molding process because of their excellent thermal stability and environmental friendliness. Clay-based binders, such as bentonite and kaolinite, are the most commonly used binders for zeolite shaping, which can yield strength zeolite granules after sintering. However, because calcination degrades MOF materials and destroys their structure at high temperatures, clay-based binders that need high-temperature calcination to gain strength are rarely used alone for the direct formation of MOFs pellets. Binders that can work without requiring calcination are preferred. Valekar et al. effectively prepared MIL-100(Fe), MIL-101(Cr), UiO-66(Zr), and UiO-66(Zr)_NH2 in millimeter-sized pellets using 5 wt % ρ-alumina as the binder and investigated the fundamental property changes and mechanical strength of the MOF monoliths. Their schematic diagrams () show that MOFs and ρ-alumina are combined by the interaction of hydroxyl groups on the particle surface to form a monolithic structure with a certain strength. On the basis of the nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K and applying the BET method, the specific surface area of all four MOFs particles was found to be overproportionally reduced, but it is noteworthy that the CO2 adsorption capacity of MIL-101(Cr) and UIO-66(Zr)_NH2 after spheroidization was basically the same as the weight ratio compared to the pristine MOFs. The mechanical strength of the four molded MOFs containing 5 wt % binders was measured and gave an average crushing strength of 6.7 N (MIL-100(Fe)), 4.1 N (MIL-101(Cr)), 4.7 N (UiO-66(Zr)), and 2.5 N (UiO-66(Zr)_NH2), respectively. This is still insufficient for application in packed adsorption beds, though it can also be improved by increasing the binder content.

To complete our experimental study in this work, we investigated the long-term stability and performance of the MIL-53 adsorbents. We first performed a stability test by immersing the adsorbents (in both powder and pelletized forms) in a C8 isomer mixture for up to 30 days (see  section) and then characterizing the recovered adsorbents. We use the BET surface area and micropore volume as markers of the adsorbent stability. a shows the evolution of textural characteristics in MIL-53(Al), Figure S8 shows the corresponding data for MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Ga), and Table S10 shows the detailed numerical values of BET area and micropore volume obtained in these experiments. All of the MIL-53 adsorbents are seen to be stable in the C8 aromatic isomer mixture, with both powder and pelletized MIL-53 samples showing stable BET area and micropore volume over the entire 30 days of immersion. A minor decrease of 10-20% in BET area and micropore volume is seen in the first 7-15 days, but these quantities remain stable (or slightly increase) in the next 15 days. Among the three MOFs, MIL-53(Cr) and MIL-53(Al) showed essentially the same stability whereas MIL-53(Ga) showed somewhat more loss of porosity in the initial exposure period (Figure S8). This data also demonstrates that under the pelletization pressures used in this work (1000-2000 psi) there is little difference in the textural characteristics of the pellets versus the unpelletized powders. The preservation of crystal structure of all of the materials was also confirmed by XRD after pelletization and after the stability tests (data not shown). Having confirmed the long-term stability under static immersion conditions, we studied the dynamic cycling performance of MIL-53(Al)the most oX-selective materialvia four breakthrough adsorption-desorption cycles carried out over a period of more than 2 days. The results (b) indicate no significant changes in the oX selectivity and total capacity of MIL-53(Al) during the cycling experiments. The consistency in the capacity values over several cycles also indicates satisfactory performance of hexane in removing the adsorbed C8 aromatics during the desorption phases. This was further confirmed by calculations based upon a desorption run on MIL-53(Al) shown in Figure S9. On desorbing a xylene-saturated MIL-53(Al) column using hexane, the calculated desorption selectivities closely matched experimental adsorption selectivities with a oX/pX selectivity of 5.3 (Table S11).

Prior to measurement, the sample was evacuated for 8 h at 200 °C. Twenty-five sample points were taken; the surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation according to DIN 66131 ("Determination of specific surface area of solids by means of gas adsorption using the method of BET") using data points within the range 0.05 < p/p 0 < 0.2.

Figure a shows data for the lower humidity level, RH = 45%. For samples exposed for the two shortest time periods, 0.5 and 2 h, the decrease in maximum hydrogen uptake is less than 3% compared to the baseline (unexposed) material. This indicates that the MOF-5 powders do not undergo "sudden death" when exposed to moderately humid conditions for short times. For a 24-h exposure, the peak in the adsorption isotherm also decreases by only slightly (~5%), from 5.7 to 5.4 wt %. However, more significant changes are observed for longer exposures; for example, uptake drops to half of that for the pristine material after 66 h exposure. In contrast, at the higher RH value (61%), Figure b, significant decreases in hydrogen storage capacity appear after 2 h of exposure. After 24 h uptake decreases by approximately 50%, which is an order of magnitude larger than the losses seen at RH = 45%. After 48 h the powder has lost essentially all of its gas storage capability (uptake below 0.5 wt %).

To quantify the amount of water vapor adsorbed by MOF-5, water adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at 25 °C using a gravimetric apparatus, Figure . Here the x-axis represents RH, and the y-axis represents the weight percent ([m(water)/m(MOF-5)] × 100) of adsorbed water. Three adsorption/desorption cycles were performed using the same powder sample. During the first uptake cycle less than 1 wt % of water is adsorbed for RH up to 45%. The water uptake then jumps dramatically to more than 12 wt % at RH values between 45-55%. For higher RH the uptake saturates at capacities of 12-14 wt %. This adsorption behavior is consistent with a type V isotherm, which is expected for systems exhibiting relatively strong adsorbate-adsorbate interactions in comparison to (weaker) adsorbate-adsorbent interactions.

Because gravimetric uptake is related to geometric properties of MOFs such as specific surface area and micropore volume, a loss in hydrogen capacity can also presumably be related to a comparable loss in these quantities, as previously discussed.

Another observation relates to the "kinetic stability" of the densified MOF. Here kinetic stability refers to the rate of degradation/decomposition of the MOF at a given RH, temperature, and exposure time. We first recall that in powders, Figure a, the exposure time at which a significant decrease in excess hydrogen uptake was observed at RH = 45% was 2 h. In contrast, for pellets a much longer exposure time of ~24 h is required to achieve a comparable loss in H2 capacity. Similar trends hold for longer exposure times: powders exposed to RH = 45% for 66 h exhibit a H2 capacity of 3 wt %, whereas for pellets the uptake is significantly higher, 4.1 wt %, Figure a. This behavior also carries over to samples exposed to the higher humidity RH = 61% environment: after 2 h exposure, powder MOF-5 has a H2 capacity of 4.9 wt %, while for pellets the capacity is essentially unchanged from that of the unexposed material, 5.6 wt %, as shown in Figures b and b, respectively.

The lithium storage properties of the distorted metal-organic framework-derived nanosized ZnO@C are significantly improved by the introduction of Ag2S quantum dots (QDs) during the processing of the material. In the thermal treatment, the Ag2S QDs react to produce Ag nanoparticles and ZnS. The metal nanoparticles act to shorten electron pathways and improve the connectivity of the matrix, and the partial sulfidation of the ZnO surface improves the cycling stability of the material. The electrochemical properties of ZnO@C, Ag2S QDs-treated ZnO@C, and the amorphous carbon in ZnO@C have been compared. The small weight ratio of Ag2S QDs to ZnO@C at 1:180 shows the best performance in lithium storage. The exhibited specific capacities are improved and retained remarkably in the cycling at high current rates. At low current densities (200 mA g-1), treatment of ZnO@C with Ag2S QDs results in a 38% increase in the specific capacity.

Similarly, no alterations were observed in the SEM images of the [BMIM][BF4]/UiO-66 composite obtained at two different magnifications, 50 k× and 10 k×, as presented in b,c and S6, respectively, verifying the integrity of the surface morphology upon the incorporation of IL molecules. The nature of the molecular interactions between bulk [BMIM][BF4] and UiO-66 was elucidated using IR spectroscopy, as presented in d. In summary, the characteristic IR bands of pristine UiO-66 illustrated blue shifts for the vibrational modes of Zr-(OC) and Zr-O, and the cation of the IL, [BMIM]+, showed red shifts upon the incorporation of IL into UiO-66. Hence, these shifts confirm the presence of the intermolecular interactions between the [BMIM]+ cation of [BMIM][BF4] and the Zr metal nodes of UiO-66. Moreover, conductor-like screening model for realistic solvents (COSMO-RS) solubility calculations (Figure S9) demonstrated that N2 has almost negligible solubility in [BMIM][BF4] at the BET measurement conditions.
