ML-Guided Generation of a New IL/MOF Composite

The main target of this work is to integrate ML into the molecular simulations of IL/MOF composites to precisely direct experimental efforts to the synthesis of new composites for CO2/N2 separation. To achieve this, we first focused on the CO2/N2 selectivity of pristine MOFs to identify a host material for IL incorporation. a shows that the ML-predicted selectivities of pristine MOFs strongly agree with the GCMC-simulated ones at 1 bar and 298 K, suggesting that ML models are useful to accurately assess the gas separation performances of pristine MOFs that exist in our database. We compared the ML-predicted selectivities of Cu-BTC and ZIF-8, two hosts that were previously used to make [BMIM][BF4]/MOF composites, with the GCMC-based selectivities, and the good agreement confirmed the validity of ML models to accurately estimate the CO2/N2 selectivity of any type of MOF. To further show the consistency between ML predictions and the results of simulations and experimental measurements, we identified the top three MOFs (refcodes: QOVDEL, REQBAS, and FUSMEM) exhibiting the highest CO2/N2 selectivity in the test set. Table S4 shows CO2 and N2 uptakes and the corresponding CO2/N2 selectivities of these MOFs obtained from simulations and ML models. These MOFs exhibit high CO2/N2 selectivity in the range of 38-50, and they are good candidates for making [BMIM][BF4]-incorporated composites. However, to the best of our knowledge, none of these MOFs are commercially available. Hence, we specifically aimed to focus on a commercially available MOF (i) to avoid potential reproducibility problems in synthesizing these materials and (ii) to prove the transferability of our ML models and the validity of our methodology by studying a MOF that was not present in our original data set yet commercially available at a certain quality through reliable vendors. Thus, we chose a zirconium-based MOF, UiO-66, as the host material for the following practical and theoretical reasons: UiO-66 is robust and offers high chemical stability and moisture resistance. To confirm the latter, we calculated Henry's coefficient for water, K H2O = 2.3 × 10-6 mol/kg/Pa for UiO-66, which was lower than the corresponding value of a well-known moisture stable ZIF-8, K H2O = 5.0 × 10-6 mol/kg/Pa. Therefore, UiO-66 is expected to preserve its stability during wet flue gas separation under real operating conditions. a shows that the ML-predicted CO2/N2 selectivity of pristine UiO-66 strongly agrees with the simulated ones. Theoretical reasons for selecting UiO-66 as the host material of the composite were obtained from the detailed feature importance analysis of ML models given in . Pore volume and porosity are the two important features that determine the gas adsorption properties of the IL/MOF composites. b shows that a good CO2/N2 selectivity in the range of 8-15 can be achieved if the [BMIM][BF4]/UiO-66 composite with an IL loading of 10.4 wt % is generated, leading to a porosity of 0.35 and a pore volume of 0.51 cm3/g. The PLD of this new composite was calculated as 3.66 Å, so that both CO2 (3.3 Å) and N2 (3.64 Å) molecules can adsorb into the pores of the composite. It is important to note that the new composite has a large enough PLD for the entrance of both gas molecules, independent of their corresponding solubilities in the IL, so that molecular simulations can compute the adsorption of gas molecules, which are modeled as hard spheres.

CMMFTP Biocompatibility and Therapeutic Selectivity

Microacidity and hydrogen peroxide overexpression are the characteristics of the tumor microenvironment, and the concentration of hydrogen peroxide in tumor cells reaches 1 × 10-6 M, which is 100 times higher than that of normal cells. We have shown earlier that CMMFTP was not able to undergo the Russell reaction and the Fenton-like reaction at pH 7.4 and in the absence of H2O2, implying that CMMFTP cannot produce cytotoxic ROS in normal cells but can produce cytotoxic ROS only in acidic and hydrogen peroxide overexpressing tumor cells. Therefore, CMMFTP treatment is selective to tumors and mainly produces cytotoxic ROS in tumor cells, presenting a temporal CDT effect. Normal cell mouse fibroblasts (L929 cells) and HeLa cells were utilized to investigate the biocompatibility and therapeutic selectivity of CMMFTP by analyzing the cell viability after 4 and 24 h of drug administration through the MTT method (c,d). For L929 cells, cell viability was maintained at 100% with drug concentrations ranging from 0 to 400 μg mL-1, indicating that CMMFTP is not toxic to normal cells and is safe even at doses up to 400 μg mL-1. Under the same conditions, HeLa cells showed a significant decrease in cell viability after 4 and 24 h of dosing, with only 5% viability at 24 h (dose 400 μg mL-1), which suggested that the Fenton-like reaction and the Russell reaction occurred under the tumor microenvironment stimulation, generating a high concentration of ROS to kill cancer cells. The above analysis demonstrated that CMMFTP is biocompatible and has significant therapeutic selectivity.

Due to the unique fluorescence property of TCPP, CMMFTP was capable of being applied in fluorescence imaging. HeLa cells and 4T1 cells were used as model cells to examine the phagocytosis and fluorescence imaging functions of CMMFTP. Cells treated with CMMFTP (100 μg mL-1) were incubated for different times. As shown in a, the red fluorescence of TCPP was observed in the cytoplasm after incubation for 30 min, which indicated that CMMFTP was engulfed by the cells. With prolonged incubation time (60 and 90 min), the red fluorescence of TCPP increased obviously, suggesting that CMMFTP was internalized in a time-dependent manner. Meanwhile, the morphology of the cells treated with different concentrations (0-400 μg mL-1) of CMMFTP was also observed from 0 to 30 min (Figure S5). As the drug concentration increased, the intracellular red fluorescence intensity was gradually enhanced. Moreover, HeLa cells and 4T1 cells treated with CMMFTP showed strong red fluorescence under fluorescence microscopy and clear cell images, indicating that CMMFTP has good fluorescence imaging potential and is expected to act as a nanofluorescent imaging agent.

The change in the chemical composition and/or architecture of various materials such as gels, polymer networks, and spider silks are known to have a direct effect on their mechanical properties. Therefore, measurements of the storage and loss Young's compression modulus, E' and E", respectively, were carried out as a function of the oscillatory deformation frequency ω at a fixed strain amplitude (1%) within the linear viscoelastic regime. Over the entire frequency range, these values are essentially constant and E' is approximately 1 order of magnitude higher than E", confirming that the samples behave as elastic solids (Figure S11).

The large deformation behavior and the resistance to elastic deformation of the fully matured gel samples, 1a-f, were characterized by uniaxial compression tests. Stress-strain curves show four characteristic regimes (a). First, a linear elastic regime is observed at low strain (ε < 15%), in which the materials deform elastically and can return to their original shape when the applied stress is removed. In this regime, the compressive elastic modulus (E) can be extracted from the slope of the linear fits. Then, a plateau regime occurs for 15 < ε < 40%. The transition between the two regimes is characterized by the yield point, which indicates the limit between the elastic deformation and the beginning of plastic behavior. b shows the plot of the compressive elastic modulus (E) as a function of TFA equivalent added to the samples. When increasing the TFA content for the samples 1a-f, the elastic modulus, the yield strain and stress decrease (b inset), indicating a reduction in the resistance of the materials to permanent deformation. Indeed, as for zirconia, alumina and Kaolin colloidal systems, it is expected that the yield point decreases as the particle size of the suspension increases. After the plateau regime (ε > 40%), strain hardening (or densification) is observed as the stress rises steeply. In this regime, the strengthening of the gel samples by plastic deformation occurs as a consequence of the colloidal gel networks rearrangement. Finally, above ~80% strain, the stress drops suddenly, which is characteristic of the gel fracture. Samples with lower TFA content are more ductile and can undergo increased plastic deformation before breaking as seen from the maximum stress and strain reached for 1a compared to 1f (1.8 × 105 Pa, 90.4%; and 3.8 × 104 Pa, 84.2%, respectively). This is confirmed from the direct observation of the inverted gels, which shows the gels prepared with 12.0 and 24.0 equiv of TFA to be more brittle (Figure S12).

Water Adsorption Cycles

All four cycles of water adsorption measured on 3 at 30 °C exhibit remarkable type IV adsorption isotherms, featuring a well-defined hysteresis loop with two virtually vertical and nearly parallel branches (). This is generally associated with porous materials having a narrow pore-size distribution. At relative humidity of 53% (at 30 °C) it approaches full loading of water. Although a small decrease of adsorption capacity between each cycle is observed, this is remarkable for a UiO-67-type MOF. While the cause of this decrease in capacity is unknown, it is likely connected to missing linker defects, as this has been shown to have a significant impact on Zr MOF stability, and is present in the measured sample of UiO-67-BN. It may also be affected by the harsh regeneration between each cycle, heating the powder at 250 °C overnight in vacuum. Further investigations of the synthesis and measurement conditions will clarify whether this is indeed the case.

  shows the hysteresis measurements of M vs H with longitudinal-MOKE (L-MOKE, upper part) and polar-MOKE (P-MOKE, lower part) intensities as a function of Ni film thickness ((a, d) 8 ML, (b, e) 9 ML, and (c, f) 20 ML) on clean Cu(100) and subsequently deposited F4-TCNQ (3 Å) atop. According to the M-H loops plotted in Figures S2 and S3 in this work, the Ni film shows the first SRT from in-plane to out-of-plane magnetization at about 9.5 ML and maintains that out-of-plane magnetization with the Ni thickness increasing to about ~20 ML. These results agree well with previous work that demonstrates a similar transition thickness. Upon capping Ni surfaces (8 and 9 ML) with F4-TCNQ (3 Å), a remarkable enhancement of the in-plane coercive field along the easy axis was obtained with L-MOKE (a,b). In the P-MOKE measurement, the coercive magnetic hysteresis loops become appreciable after F4-TCNQ capping on Ni at 8 and 9 ML (d,e). The highly coercive hysteresis loops in both L- and P-MOKE after molecular adsorption on Ni films (8 and 9 ML) show that the ferromagnetic order is significantly enhanced relative to the original anisotropy. When F4-TCNQ was capped on 20 ML Ni, the in-plane coercive field showed remanence of almost 100%. This result is due to the limitation of the magnetic field supply that did not magnetically saturate the sample; no variation of hysteresis loops in L-MOKE (c) was observed. The out-of-plane coercivity was slightly increased after contact with F4-TCNQ, as shown in f. As a result, the enhancement of ferromagnetic ordering in the region near the first SRT is attributed to the surface modification of the magnetic texture by F4-TCNQ. As the Kerr intensity is proportional to magnetization, the MOKE results indicate that F4-TCNQ capping enhances the Kerr intensity, magnifies the magnetization, and thus alters the magnetic textures.

The in situ Raman spectra of the corner MOF-AgNC nanocomposite also exhibited that no CO2 reduction reaction occurred without irradiation assistance (as hollow green squares in D and Supporting Information Figure S15 and Table S5). With irradiation assistance, the CO2 concentration decreased with the reaction time and was accompanied by an increase in the HCOO- concentration. The changes in CO2 and HCOO- concentrations became more obvious with the increase of irradiation intensity as shown in D and Supporting Information Figures S16-S20 and Table S5. Moreover, the HCOOH generated by the CO2 reduction reaction also exhibited a first-order reaction (ln(I'/I' t = 0) had a linear relationship with t), as shown in E. However, the reaction rate (rate constant K) of the CO2 reduction reaction on the corner MOF-AgNC nanocomposite was faster than that on core-shell MOF-AgNC, which should be due to the lower product diffusion resistance (uncoated AgNCs) on corner MOF-AgNC than that on core-shell MOF-AgNC. The rate constant of the first-order reaction also exhibited a linear relationship with the irradiation intensity, as shown in F and Supporting Information Table S6. However, the CO2 reduction reaction in the corner MOF-AgNC nanocomposite exhibited a higher sensitivity to irradiation intensity than the CO2 reduction reaction in the core-shell MOF-AgNC nanocomposite (as shown in the slope of the K-irradiation intensity plot in F and F). The morphology and properties of MOF-AgNC nanocomposites remained unchanged after CO2 absorption and CO2 reduction reactions under irradiation, indicating that MOF-AgNC nanocomposites have high stability as photocatalysts for CO2 reduction reaction as shown in Supporting Information Figure S21 (SEM images in (A) and (B), extinction spectra in (C), and Raman spectra in (D)). These MOF-AgNC composites were again used to test the reactivity of CO2 reduction under external irradiation, and results showed good reproducibility, as shown in Supporting Information Figure S28.

To further investigate the effect of substituents of benzylamine on catalytic performance, the photocatalytic oxidation activity of HNU-64 for other benzylamine derivatives was explored. In similar experimental conditions, conversions of benzylamine derivatives with -CH3, -OCH3, and -Cl after 6 h are 65.5, 51.2, and 63.1%, respectively (entry 5-7 in ). No other products except imines were detected, and the selectivity of their respective imines can be determined to be >99%. TOF values of the three reactions are 3275, 2560, and 3155 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1, suggesting that HNU-64 has a good catalytic effect on benzylamine derivatives. The conversion of Cl-, OCH3-, and CH3-substituted benzylamines decreased significantly, indicating that the effect of electron donor groups (OCH3 and CH3) and electron-drawing group (Cl) will not improve the conversion. Combined with these results, it can be found that the conversions are reduced when the para-position hydrogen of benzylamine substitutes for larger groups such as -CH3, -OCH3, and -Cl, which is attributed to the steric hindrance of a larger substituent affecting the entry of amine molecules through the channels of HNU-64 instead of electronic effect of substituent groups. In addition, the catalytic performances of HNU-64-CH3  and HNU-64-Cl for photocatalytic oxidation were also studied. As shown in , HNU-64-CH3  and HNU-64-Cl can also catalyze the coupling of benzylamine oxidation under similar mild conditions. After 7 hours, TOF values are 3921 and 3887 μmol⋅g-1⋅h-1, and the reaction selectivity is more than 99%. Therefore, the three isostructural uranyl MOFs have good photocatalytic performance in the oxidation of benzylamine. The lower conversion and TOF values of HNU-64-CH3  and HNU-64-Cl than those of HNU-64 are on account of their functionalized channels blocking the passage of amine molecules via steric hindrance.

To clarify the potential mechanism of their catalytic activity, the electronic band structures and optical properties of three uranyl MOFs were then investigated by electrochemical and spectral measurements. According to the Mott-Schottky plots, the positive slopes suggest that they are typical n-type semiconductors (Figure S10a). In n-type semiconductors, the CB minimum position is thought to be approximately equivalent to the flat band position. The CB edges of HNU-64, HNU-64-CH3 , and HNU-64-Cl are approximated to be -0.87, -0.91, and -1.10 V versus Ag/AgCl, respectively (Figure S10a). In the UV-vis absorption spectra, they have broad absorption bands, indicating a strong capability of visible-light harvesting (a). According to the Tauc plots, the optical band gap energies are estimated to be 2.52, 2.55, and 2.61 eV for HNU-64, HNU-64-CH3 , and HNU-64-Cl, respectively (inset in a). Combining their optical band gap energies and CB edges, the VB maximum potentials are then calculated to be 1.65, 1.64, and 1.51 V versus Ag/AgCl, respectively (b). The CB and VB levels in the three uranyl MOFs possess enough potential energy for O2 photoreduction to ⋅O2 - and oxidation of benzylamine. To elucidate the roles of possible active species in photocatalysis, a series of quenching experiments were investigated. As shown in Figure S12, when 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidoxyl as the 1O2 scavenger and p-benzoquinone as the ⋅O2 - scavenger are added, decreased conversion proves that 1O2 and ⋅O2 - are main reactive oxygen species in the reaction. The addition of electron scavenger AgNO3 or hole scavenger KI into the mixture also leads to markedly decreased conversions, which demonstrates the importance of photogenerated electrons and holes in the photocatalysis. In addition, a slight decrease of benzylamine conversion is observed with tert-butanol (t-BuOH) as the hydroxyl radical (⋅OH) scavenger, suggesting that ⋅OH contributes little to the formation of imines. Such results prove that 1O2 and ⋅O2 - as main reactive oxygen species play a vital role in the reaction pathway together with the effect of photogenerated electrons and holes.

To mend this problem, also stacks of pCOFs comprising finite numbers of layers were investigated. Such calculations provide access to the vacuum level above the slabs as a unique and system-independent reference energy. First, calculations confirm the assessment that the position of the CBM does not qualify as a reliable energy reference, as when comparing the 1- and 11-layer slabs the CBM energy relative to the vacuum level is lowered by 0.09 eV for pCOF-CN and raised by 0.21 for pCOF-NH2. Moreover, using the vacuum level as an energy reference provides access to the arguably most relevant quantity describing the dipole-induced effects, namely the difference between the electrostatic energy in the center of the pore (at the position of the central pCOF layer) and the electrostatic energy outside the COF, E  pore-vac  *elstat . Here, the * denotes the fact that one is now dealing with a system of finite thickness. The values of E  pore-vac  *elstat  are shown in b as a function of the number of layers in the slab, N. One observes a pronounced dependence of E  pore-vac  *elstat  on N, with values for pCOF-CN starting at +0.27 eV for the monolayer and saturating at +0.89 eV for the 11-layer stack. For pCOF-NH2 the values vary between -0.13 eV and -0.50 eV. This supports the notion that the shift is collective in nature, as it increases with the number of neighboring layers. The collectivity is further confirmed by the data in c, where the evolution of E  pore-vac  *elstat  is shown as a function of the position along the pore axis revealing pronounced edge effects.

The metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) UiO-66-NH2 and HKUST-1 were adhered to chemically inert polypropylene (PP) fibrous mats with poly(ether-block-amide), aka PEBA or PeBax, using a phase inversion technique. Two types of PeBax were used to investigate the effects of a hydrophilic vs hydrophobic treatment on uptake and permeation properties of the chemical warfare agent simulant 2-chloroethyl ethyl sulfide (CEES). Furthermore, the underlying PP fiber density was altered to understand CEES permeation properties. It was found that using the hydrophobic PeBax 2533 and a higher fiber density led to better barrier properties, with the best material providing ~250 min protection to a permeation rate of 0.1 μg/min/cm2 in comparison to ~150 min for the activated carbon fiber Stedcarb. CEES uptake ranged from ~1.0 to 2.4 mol/kg for composites in comparison to 3.6 mol/kg for the pure MOF. Furthermore, the technique allowed for incorporation of different MOFs, and even a mixture of MOFs, on the same fiber substrate. Finally, the PeBax formulation was able to stabilize HKUST-1 against moisture, potentially opening the door for applications of this MOF in high-humidity environments.

Visual Detection of the Portable Test Paper Based on Smartphones

The paper sensor has the advantages of high practicability, low cost, and fast detection. Thus, it can be used for the identification and semi-quantitative detection of analytes. The prepared 1-Eu was used as a fluorescent probe to realize semi-quantitative detection of MDZ. The test strips were soaked in different concentrations of MDZ, and the red fluorescence of 1-Eu on the test strips was gradually quenched with the increase in concentration. Photos of test strips were taken with smartphones, and their RGB values were measured with the Color Picker software. In order to minimize the error, calibration curves were made between the red channel and MDZ concentrations after multiple readings. As shown in , with the increase of MDZ concentration, the color of the test paper gradually changes from bright pink to dark purple, and the value of B/R increases correspondingly, showing a good linear correlation (R 2 = 0.994). According to 3σ/slope, the LOD value of the detection limit is 14.7 ppm. Therefore, the paper sensor has potential application value in the rapid and sensitive detection of analytes.

As the synthesized 1-Eu and 1-Tb are isomorphic, a series of doped 1-Eu   x   Tb  1-x   with color luminescence were successfully synthesized by adjusting the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the complex. In Vivo Antitumor Therapeutic Effect

In order to evaluate the in vivo antitumor therapeutic effects of proximal and distal tumors, a 4T1 bilateral subcutaneous tumor-bearing model was established. In this model, mice were first inoculated with 4T1 cells on the one side and then inoculated on the other side 3 days later (A). Inhibiting of PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway is a common method of clinical immune checkpoint blocking therapy in recent years. Therefore, we used the antibody of PD-1 (aPD-1) to interrupt PD-1/PD-L1 signaling pathway in combination with 3D Cu@COF-TATB to enhance antitumor immunity in vivo. The tumor-bearing mice were randomly assigned into seven groups and intratumorally injected with (1) PBS; (2) PBS + laser; (3) 3D COF-TATB; (4) 3D Cu@COF-TATB; (5) 3D COF-TATB + laser; (6) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser; (7) 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1, respectively. As illustrated in B and SI Figure S8A, the tumor inhibition effect of PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group was negligible, which indicated that laser alone and 3D COF-TATB had poor therapy efficacy against tumor. And the inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moderate because 3D Cu@COF-TATB only produced ⋅OH by CDT. After laser irradiation, the growth of tumors was suppressed in 3D COF-TATB + laser group through PDT to some extent. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser group showed obvious tumor inhibition due to the production of multiple ROS through PDT and CDT, indicating that the multiple ROS-based strategy had better antitumor effect. H&E staining analysis was also observed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser radiation induced extensive tumor cells apoptosis (D), which was consistent with the above results. We further studied the abscopal antitumor effect of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB. The distant tumors grew rapidly in PBS, PBS + laser and 3D COF-TATB group. In the 3D Cu@COF-TATB, 3D COF-TATB + laser, 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser and 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 groups, the distal tumors showed varying degrees of inhibition. And 3D Cu@COF-TATB + laser + aPD-1 had the best inhibitory effect on distal tumors, suggesting that 3D Cu@COF-TATB combining with aPD-1 caused systemic immune responses to inhibit the growth of abscopal tumor (C and SI Figure S8B). CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumors were studied by the immunofluorescence staining assay to proof the immune response. After treatments, the tumors of mice were gained and stained. SI Figure S9 showed that 3D Cu@COF-TATB+laser + aPD-1 group exhibited the most CD3+ and CD8+ T cells in tumor slides, which indicated the most significant immune response. Additionally, body weights (E) of mice remained negligible changed during treatments, which showed the biocompatibility of the materials. H&E staining images of major organs (heart, liver, spleen, lung, and kidney) indicated that no obvious damage was caused to normal tissues (SI Figure S10). These experiments indicated the good biological safety and tumor inhibition effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB, which will advance the application potential in vivo.

We further studied the intracellular therapeutic effect of the 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB by MTT assays. The survival rate of 4T1 cells was up to more than 90% under laser irradiation alone, which indicated that the power and irradiation time that we chose had low cytotoxicity. In the absence of laser irradiation, 4T1 cells had a lower survival rate after incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB than that of 3D COF-TATB, indicating the good CDT effect of 3D Cu@COF-TATB. And cells treated with 3D COF-TATB or 3D Cu@COF-TATB showed significant concentration-dependent toxicity under laser irradiation (A). In addition, the cell killing efficiency of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB was verified by the live/dead cell staining assay. As shown in B, cancer cells pretreated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation exhibited strongest red fluorescence and weakest green fluorescence among all the groups, implying that the 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation had the most severe lethality to living cells. Subsequently, 2,7-dichlorofluorescein diacetate (DCFH-DA) was used to study the ability of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB to produce ROS in vitro. As illustrated in C,D, 4T1 cells incubated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation showed the most intensely green fluorescence, suggesting the excellent ROS production performance in cancer cells. In addition, compared with 3D COF-TATB, the cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB exhibited stronger green fluorescence signal, which indicated that Cu2+ could be reduced to Cu+ by GSH and further catalyze the transformation of H2O2 into ⋅OH to generate more ROS in cells. These results were further demonstrated via flow cytometry assay. 4T1 cells treated with 3D Cu@COF-TATB and laser irradiation showed the strongest fluorescent signal in E, which also suggested its ability to produce ROS. Excess ROS can trigger mitochondrial destruction to induce cell apoptosis. The mitochondrial membrane potential (MMP) of 4T1 cells with different treatments were studied by rhodamine 123. As shown in SI Figure S7, the MMP decreased with the increase of ROS. In particular, the MMP decreased the most obviously in the group of 3D Cu@COF-TATB under laser irradiation, which verified that the serious mitochondrial destruction was caused by excess ROS.

The Cu catalytic site in 3D Cu@COF-TATB has the ability to catalyze the conversion of H2O2 to ⋅OH through the Fenton-like reaction. As shown in D,E, the blue MB was degraded to colorless and the absorption intensity of MB at 664 nm significantly decreased with the addition of 3D Cu@COF-TATB and H2O2. Preparation and Characterizations of 3D Cu@COF-TATB

The 3D porphyrin-based COF-TATB was first prepared by a classical solvothermal method (Supporting Information (SI) Figure S1). The as-prepared 3D COF-TATB was then ground and crushed in mortar to obtain uniform COF particles in nanometer scale. The crystal structures of 3D COF-TATB was proved via the PXRD analysis. As shown in SI Figure S2, a strong peak at 6.67° and an acromion at 7.20° were observed. The 3D COF-TATB was further modified with Cu2+ through the coordination between the porphyrin ring and Cu2+ to obtain 3D Cu@COF-TATB. From the FT-IR spectrum (A), the characteristic peak of 3D COF-TATB at 1610 cm-1 indicated the formation of C = N linkage. And the characteristic peak of N-H bond in the porphyrin ring of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was moved from 964 to 999 cm-1, which confirmed the successful coordination of Cu2+. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (B) and Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (SI Figure S3) images showed that 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB had uniform morphology and size. Moreover, the hydrodynamic sizes of 3D COF-TATB and 3D Cu@COF-TATB were about 100 nm by dynamic light scattering (DLS) (C). The stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was further studied. In SI Figure S4, the hydrodynamic size of 3D Cu@COF-TATB was basically unchanged for 7 days, indicating the long-term stability of 3D Cu@COF-TATB.

In underliquid environments, the achievement in this work could improve the collection of a small amount of oil in wastewater treatment system. The frequently used sponge does not perform well in collecting such micro-oil droplets in water due to the lack of adequate contact area with wastewater. As shown in  and , however, the wedge tracks installed around a sponge with superhydrophobicity/superoleophilicity could capture and transport the oil droplets to the sponge, thus enhancing the oil collection efficiency. a demonstrates clearly that droplets of 1,2-dichloroethane were captured and self-transported to the tail of the wedge and eventually absorbed by the sponge, even on a tilted wedge-shaped surface. A simple schematic device of micro-oil droplets collection is shown in b and . Importantly, the droplet capture, transportation, and collection were demonstrated in c-d. The captured droplets move on the wedge tracks and are absorbed by the sponge. As shown in e, the oil collection capacity (1,2-dichloroethane) for a sponge with two wedges was 2.1 times that of the sponge only without wedges, and the collection capacity could be further improved with more wedges attached on the sponge. Based on the above observation, an adaptive strategy for small amount of oil collecting underliquid can be envisioned.

Complex surface dynamics is the key to limit the photoelectrochemical performance of hematite, while its core content is the hole trapping and release by surface traps. Deep traps are accompanied by extremely fast capture rates and extremely slow release rates, which severely suppress the hole transport process. Herein, we proposed a unique method to progressively convert deep traps on the hematite surface for fast hole transfer via in situ one-step metal organic framework modification. This stepwise deep-trap passivation is achieved by hematite corrosion first on the surface and subsequent construction of a porous titanium layer. The gentle trap finishing helps prevent surface losses caused by excessively intense trap passivation. The hematite corrosion can initially passivate 80% of the surface deep traps, while the subsequent porous titanium layer can completely passivate the deep traps. In addition, the accurate optimization of the porous titanium layer can reconstruct the benign shallow traps on the surface, acting as superior oxygen evolution reaction active sites. This sophisticated surface-trap adjustment is accompanied by the rapid reduction of deep traps and the gradual increase of shallow traps, obtaining a superior surface state that is conducive to charge transport and interface catalysis. The obtained treated hematite yields a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA⋅cm-2 at 1.23 VRHE, increased by 570% compared to the pristine hematite.

One important parameter in evaluating a photoswitchable system is its stability. Typically, the metastable c-AB decays to t-AB in a wide range of time scales, depending heavily on the local environment. We have investigated this process by first irradiating the sample with UV light and then taking UV/vis measurements in regular intervals Δt. The resulting spectra were evaluated at the minimum of the ΔA spectrum in the π-π* band with results shown in . In all cases, the trend can be fitted well with an exponential function, but the fit is significantly improved if the first data point is neglected. The decay constant t 1 of the exponential function shows a linear dependence on measurement frequency Δt -1, similar as in ref . This behavior is caused by the influence of the measurement light. Extrapolating this trend toward zero removes the influence of the measurement and yields t 1 = 260 min ± 34 min. This result means c-AB relaxes faster in HKUST-1 than it does in solution, where it has a half-life of around 2 days. AB in molecular sieves shows comparable or a little longer stability times than the values we report here.

Crystallographic study shows that the CdII center in 2 has a similar coordination environment as that in 1 except two chloride ions, rather than sulfate anion and  molecule, occupying the axial positions with a Cl1-Cd-Cl2 angle of 176.67(4)° [ and Table S1). Complex 2 is also a hinged 1D chain containing 24-membered rings with a Cd⋯Cd intra-chain distance of 12.91 Å, which is longer than that in 1 []. However, there are definite differences between complexes 1 and 2. In contrast to the near perpendicular orientation of the  planes to the chain plane in 1, the  planes in 2 are nearly parallel to the chain plane since the dihedral angles between the  plane and the chain plane defined by cadmium and  carbon atoms are 13.0 and 11.5°, respectively. And the shortest H⋯H distance between two benzene rings within the 24-membered ring is 2.94 Å, which is too narrow for another  to pass through the ring. As a result, the structure of 2 is a hinged 1D chain; no interpenetration of 1D chains was observed. Conclusions

By employing a rigid sulfonic ligand with a RE ion nitrate, a series of isomorphic LREH frameworks were successfully synthesized. These compounds have unusually high thermal stability even at 351 °C. Investigation of the photoluminescence properties of these compounds was carried out, and they display different colour luminescence emission due to the different RE ions coordinated. These results indicate that different RE ions can tune the fluorescence colour by means of a different coordination environment, and can even quench emission around a certain wavelength. Moreover, all compounds exhibit strong purple emission, suggesting that they might be good candidates for photoactive materials. A large magnetic susceptibility has also been measured, leading the compounds to be promising multifunctional materials. It is anticipated that the research presented here will provide a possibility for the rational design and synthesis of more intriguing MOFs possessing different properties. Further research on the catalytic activity of these compounds is in process and the results should be anticipated.

A discrete CuII6 cluster and a 3D MnII-CuII framework based on assembly of Mn2Cu4 clusters: synthesis, structure and magnetic properties

The synthesis, single-crystal structure characterization and detailed magnetic study of a homometallic hexanuclear CuII cluster [Cu6(μ3-OH)2(ppk)6(H2O)2(NO3)4] (1) and a three-dimensional (3D) compound [{MnCu2(dpkO2H)2(dpkO2)N3}⋅(NO3)⋅H2O]n (2) (ppk = phenyl-2-pyridyl ketoxime; dpk = di-2-pyridyl ketone) consisting of heterometallic MnII-CuII hexanuclear cores as secondary building units are reported in this paper. In compound 1, two symmetry-related Cu3 triangles consisting of a hydroxido-bridged trinuclear unit, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(ppk)3(H2O)(NO3)]+, are assembled through nitrate bridging giving rise to the homometallic Cu6 cluster. Compound 2 contains heterometallic {MnII2CuII4} cores, which are further connected to each other through an azido bridging ligand in all the crystallographic directions, resulting in a 3D metal-organic framework. Construction of such a heterometallic 3D framework from {MnII2CuII4} units is until now, unknown. Magnetic studies of both 1 and 2 were performed in detail and both compounds show dominant antiferromagnetic interaction in the respective clusters. Compound 1 reveals significant spin frustration and anti-symmetric exchange interaction in the trinuclear cores, with a significantly high value of Jav (-655 cm-1). Furthermore, compound 2 exhibits a dominant antiferromagnetic interaction, which is also supported by an extensive magneto-structural correlation which considers the different magnetic pathways.

Our group has been actively working on the synthesis and magnetism of homo/heterometallic clusters and higher dimensional networks. In this research, the focus is on synthesizing an antiferromagnetically coupled, geometrically frustrated, trinuclear CuII core and it is envisaged that such trinuclear cores could be connected into a larger hexanuclear cluster. An attempt has also been made to synthesize heterometallic clusters based higher dimensional network. However, it is not very straightforward to obtain the desired topology because it is difficult to have control over the self-assembly process. Judicious ligand design is very important and blocking ligands are widely used to create small clusters, whereas multidentate bridging ligands such as azido, halogeno, hydroxido, and oxido groups can be used to join such clusters. Chakraborty et al. have already shown that appropriate polytopic ligands such as phenyl-2-pyridyl ketoxime (ppk) and di-2-pyridyl ketone (dpk) with well-defined and appropriately separated coordination compartments can achieve formation of the desired polynuclear clusters. The versatile binding sites of these two ligands () facilitate bridging of a number metal centres, resulting in the formation of polynuclear clusters. Reports in the literature show that CuII-oximato chemistry is prone to produce characteristic topologies, including triangular systems containing one central μ3-hydroxo or alkoxo donor. The same established ppk ligand has been used to generate a new trinuclear core and has further exploited the binding ability of anions (which are typically present on the axial site of the penta-coordinated CuII ion) to obtain a nitrate-ion-bridged hexanuclear compound [Cu6(μ3-OH)2(ppk)6(H2O)2(NO3)4] (1). Furthermore, spontaneous self-assembly of a dpk ligand with two different 3d transition metal ions, MnII and CuII, in the presence of an azido ligand produced a novel 3D framework based on a MnII2CuII4 core. Metal-assisted nucleophilic attack on the keto group of dpk is known to generate new ligands () in situ in aqueous/alcoholic solution and it has previously been shown by Chakraborty et al. that such in situ generation of new functionalities can indeed produce the growth of a heterometallic cluster with interesting topology. In this research, a single crystal of [{MnCu2(dpkO2H)2(dpkO2)N3}⋅(NO3)⋅H2O]n (2) was successfully synthesized, with a 3D framework where the hexanuclear heterometallic MnII2CuII4 clusters are connected through azido ligands, and the assembly of such MnII2CuII4 clusters to achieve a 3D framework is reported for the first time. The magnetic behavior of 1 and 2 has also been studied, and both of them exhibit dominant antiferromagnetic behavior. The antisymmetric exchange interaction (ASE) in the antiferromagnetically coupled trinuclear core of 1 is studied in detail, and demonstrates very strong antiferromagnetic interaction (J = -655 cm-1). The different complex coupling interactions operating in 2 have also been determined and a magneto-structural correlation considering several magnetic exchange pathways is presented.

In this work, we present a successful paradigm to design and construct a novel CdS-based MOF, named DLNU-M-CdS(H2TD) (H2TD = 1,3,4-thiadiazole-2,5-dithiol), based on the above strategy for realizing co-catalyst-free highly efficient photocatalytic H2 production with TEOA as the sacrificial hole-scavenger. The choice of the H2TD ligand is based on the following considerations: (i) the high polarizability and the conjugate structure enable the electron-rich H2TD molecule to show good photoelectronic properties; (ii) the N atom distribution in H2TD provides more chances to connect with the hydroxyl-rich TEOA molecule through the intermolecular hydrogen bond. From the viewpoint of regular hard acid theory in coordination chemistry, the thiolate in H2TD provides a soft-base linkage, which should be easy to combine with a soft-acid linkage for constructing a stable coordination compound. Among soft-acid-type metal ions, Cd2+ ions are preferentially used to connect with the H2TD ligand, since the formed CdS-based MOFs would be capable of initiating the photocatalytic proton reduction by virtue of the suitable reduction potential of the Cd 5s orbital in the CdS crystal (). By combining first-principles calculations with time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectroscopy, we demonstrate that the electron-donating process from TEOA to H2TD occurs during the photocatalytic reaction, which induces fast directional electron transfer in the path of TEOA → H2TD → Cd → H+ to greatly hinder the recombination of photoinduced charge-carriers in the MOF. Upon UV-visible-light irradiation, the H2 production rate of the DLNU-M-Cd(H2TD) photocatalyst reaches 26.1 mmol g-1 h-1, which is almost the highest value among the data obtained from the reported co-catalyst-free MOF photocatalytic systems.

The existence of two-step relaxation of the magnetization was also supported by the dynamic investigations of magnetic behaviors in the Cole-Cole plots in the form of χ' versus χ''. The two separate relaxation processes are obviously observed in the Cole-Cole diagrams at 2.5 and 3.0 K (). The relaxation time for each process can be extracted by fitting the data to two relaxation processes using the sum of two modified Debye functions:  where χS,tot = χS1 + χS2 represents the sum of the adiabatic susceptibilities of the two relaxing species; Δχi is the difference between the adiabatic susceptibility (χSi) and the isothermal susceptibility (χTi) of each magnetic phase. The fitting parameters obtained are summarized in Table S4 in the ESI. The obtained α1 value is 0.26 for 2.5 K and 0.036 for 3.0 K, and the α2 value is 0.25 and 0.13 for 2.5 and 3.0 K, respectively, indicating the narrow distribution of relaxation times. Multiple relaxation processes can be observed in polynuclear lanthanide compounds possessing distinct anisotropy centers because the single ion behavior often dominates the molecular behavior. For the present complex, however, there is one unique TbIII ion in an asymmetric unit. A similar multiple relaxation pathway upon the application of a static dc field has been observed in a few monomeric Dy complexes. Further investigations including theoretical calculations and magnetic dilution will be essential to elucidate the mechanism operating in the present compound due to the complexity of the relaxation mechanism of lanthanide ions. For complexes 2 and 3, the ac magnetic measurements under zero dc field show that there are no appreciable frequency-dependent out-of-phase signals, indicating that no slow magnetic relaxation occurs in complexes 2 and 3 (Fig. S8 and S9).

Surface areas

Langmuir surface areas of the six M2(dobdc) compounds were determined through 77 K N2 adsorption measurements (Fig. S6). Comparisons made on a per gram basis () immediately imply differences in the as-prepared materials. These problems are not resolved when taking variations in formula weight of the series into consideration, as the normalized Langmuir surface area of Zn2(dobdc) is still nearly 24% less than that of Mn2(dobdc). Further, for all of the analogs including Mg, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu, the number of N2 per unit cell range from 39 to 45 N2 at 1 bar, while Zn is significantly lower at 35 N2 per unit cell. There has been some debate over reasons for the overall lower surface area associated with Zn2(dobdc), relative to the other analogs. Possible reasons could be related to any or a combination of the following: structural changes in the framework, the presence of an amorphous impurity, remaining ligand/solvent blocking the pores or open metal sites, or crystalline defects such as intergrowth that can block N2 access to the channels.

Since the binding energy associated with adsorption at site II is thought to be somewhat similar across the series, it is expected that materials that bind CO2 more strongly will exhibit a much larger contribution from site I CO2 adsorption at low pressures and room temperature. For a qualitative comparison to the Fe analog, room-temperature neutron diffraction data were collected for Zn2(dobdc). The data, collected at an equilibrium pressure around 0.65 bar, reveal an approximate 3:1 ratio for occupancies in site I and II, respectively, and a total occupancy of 0.62 CO2 per zinc(II). The room temperature data collection reveals a slight elongation of the M-O(CO2) distance and also a rearrangement of the secondary adsorption site that makes the intermolecular distances entirely too short for the two sites to be simultaneously occupied. Therefore, we consider that the overall weaker interaction at the open metal will not allow stabilization of the secondary adsorption site, and this directly correlates to less efficient packing of CO2 molecules on the framework surface relative to the other analogs, except for Cu2+. As in the case of Fe2(dobdc), the refined CO2 occupancy for Zn2(dobdc) correlates well with that determined from the isotherms collected at 298 K (). In contrast to the room-temperature results for Fe and Zn, those previously obtained from Mg2(dobdc) treated under similar conditions reveal no occupancy of site II within the error of the diffraction experiment and a nearly full occupancy of site I. These results are not surprising, as occupation ratios are expected to increase with larger differences in binding energy of site I and II, as predicted by a Boltzmann distribution.

Structural studies with low CO2 coverage

In order to study the structural characteristics of the framework as a function of CO2 loading, detailed powder diffraction experiments (10 K) were carried out on Fe2(dobdc) using a high-resolution neutron diffractometer. Analysis of data obtained from the bare framework revealed no excess scattering density in the channels, indicating that the materials were completely activated. Rietveld refinement of the host framework, followed by Fourier difference analysis allowed the subsequent elucidation of CO2 site positions and occupancies. The material was first loaded with 0.5 CO2 per iron(II) site at room temperature. After slowly cooling, the adsorption of CO2 was less than was initially loaded, 0.350(6) CO2 per iron(II), due to a small fraction of CO2 freezing in the gas line of the top-loading CCR. Comparing the bare framework to that of the first loading reveals a decrease in unit cell volume from 4041.3(1) Å3 to 4021.4(2) Å3, which results from compression of the a and b axes upon adsorption (). The overall reduction in unit cell volume is 0.5%, a value that is slightly less than that previously reported for the CO2-loaded Mg analog. At this low-loading, there is population of a single site, site I, that is in close proximity to the iron(II) center, revealing that the open metal site is indeed responsible for the high initial isosteric heat of CO2 adsorption (). The adsorbed CO2 has an angular orientation with respect to the framework surface, with an M-O-C angle of 106(2)°, a direct result of weak, secondary van der Waals interactions with the framework ligand. The observed Fe2+-O(CO2) distance is 2.29(3) Å, a value that, within error of the experiment, is similar to those observed for the Mg and Ni analogs.

After fitting each isotherm with a dual-site Langmuir-Freundlich equation, the isosteric heats of CO2 adsorption were calculated for each framework and show the following trend at a loading of 0.1 CO2 per M2+: Mg > Ni > Co > Fe > Mn > Zn >Cu (), with -Qst values that range from 22.1(2) to 43.5(2) kJ mol-1 (). In good agreement with experimentally determined heats of adsorption, DFT calculations show binding enthalpies, -ΔH, that range from 27.1 to 40.9 kJ mol-1 at 0.167 CO2 per M2+. While the theoretically determined trend, Mg > Ni > Fe > Mn > Co > Zn > Cu, is slightly different from the experimental one, these differences are only observed for intermediate adsorbents including Mn, Fe, and Co, which exhibit similarities in CO2 binding strength. A full comparison of our experimental data and the DFT results is provided in .

To correlate structure with CO2 adsorption properties for this isostructural series, Mg-, Mn-, Co-, Ni-, Cu-, and Zn-frameworks were synthesized and characterized in addition to Fe2(dobdc). While the CO2 adsorption properties of many of these materials have been previously reported, there are some inconsistencies, likely due to variations in synthetic procedures and/or sample activation or handling, making it difficult to assess the accuracy of some reported results. shows the adsorption isotherms obtained for the seven analogues in the M2(dobdc) series at 298 K. The data is plotted as mol CO2/mol M2+ rather than the typical units of mmol CO2/g sample to avoid the effects of slight variations in formula weight. In the low-pressure regime, there is a notable difference in the CO2 adsorption properties, indicating that the open metal site dominates the adsorption process. Although binding strengths at the primary adsorption site vary throughout the series, upon saturation of the metals at higher pressures or lower temperatures, it is expected that the isotherms will begin to resemble one another due to the isostructural nature of the frameworks. Indeed, approaching 1 bar, the capacity of the Mg, Ni, Fe, and Co frameworks are already very similar with ~1.1 CO2 per metal(II) indicating that these materials are already approaching the saturation capacity of the primary adsorption site.
